The apostate church needed His searching and judging. Here, to the church in Sardis, He was the One who has the seven Spirits of God and the seven stars. The dead, reformed church needed the sevenfold intensified Spirit of God and the shining leaders. The sevenfold intensified Spirit is living and can never be replaced by the dead letters of knowledge ([link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link]).
Many have considered the reformed Protestant Church to be living, but the Lord says that she is dead. Hence, she needs the living Spirits and the shining stars.

verse.text: Become [xref]a[/xref]watchful and establish the [note]1[/note]things which remain, which were about to die; for I have found none of your works [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]completed before My God.
verse.note: "The things which remain" are the things that had been lost and were restored by the Reformation, such as justification by faith, the open Bible, etc. Though these things had been restored, they were about to die. Hence, they needed to be revived. This is the actual situation of the Protestant churches.
Nothing begun in the Reformation has ever been completed. Therefore, the church in Philadelphia is needed for the completion.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Remember therefore how you have received and heard, and keep [i]it[/i] and [xref]b[/xref]repent. If therefore you will not watch, I will [xref]c[/xref]come as a [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]thief, and you shall by no means know at what [xref]e[/xref]hour I will come upon you.
verse.note: A thief comes to steal precious things at an unknown time. Since the reformed Protestant churches are dead, they will be unaware of the Lord's coming as a thief in His secret appearing to His seekers. Hence, there is the need of watchfulness.

verse.text: But you have a few names in Sardis who have not [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]defiled their garments, and they will walk with Me in [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]white because they are worthy.
verse.note: Garments in the Bible signify what we are in our walk and living. To defile one's garments means particularly to stain them with deadness. Death is more defiling before God than sin ([link]Lev. 11:24-25[/link]; [link]Num. 6:6-7[/link], [link]9[/link]).

White signifies not only purity but also approvedness. White garments here signify the walk and living that are unspotted by death and that will be approved by the Lord. This is a qualification for walking with the Lord, especially in the coming kingdom.

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]overcomes will be [note]2[/note]clothed thus, in [xref]b[/xref]white garments, and I shall by no means [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]erase his name out of the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]book of life, and I will [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]confess his name before My Father and before His angels.
verse.note: To overcome here is to overcome the deadness of the Protestant churches, i.e., to overcome dead Protestantism.

Being clothed in white garments, as promised here, will be a prize to the overcomers in the millennial kingdom. What they have been walking in in this age will be a prize to them in the coming age. Every Christian needs two garments. The first is the garment of justification for our salvation, signifying Christ, the Christ whom we received, as our objective righteousness ([link]Luke 15:22[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). The second is the garment of approvedness for our acceptance, signifying Christ, the Christ whom we live out, as our subjective righteousness ([link]Phil. 1:21[/link]; [link]3:9[/link]). The white garments mentioned here refer to the second garment, which is needed for us to receive the reward and enter into the kingdom to walk with the Lord, that is, to reign with Him ([link]2 Tim. 2:11-12[/link]). See note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 19[/link].

The entire verse is the Lord's promise to the overcomers. It will be fulfilled in the millennial kingdom after the Lord comes back. That a name is erased out of the book of life indicates that that name has already been written in the book of life. The book of life is a divine record of the names of those who partake of the blessings that God has prepared for them. The names of all the saints chosen by God and predestinated to partake of these blessings are written in this book ([link]Luke 10:20[/link]). These blessings are in three stages: (1) in the church, (2) in the millennial kingdom, and (3) in eternity. The blessings in the stage of the church, such as forgiveness, redemption, regeneration, eternal life, the divine nature, etc., are the initial portions. All God's chosen ones whose names are written in the book of life have a share in these initial portions to begin their spiritual life. If they cooperate with God's supplying grace, they will mature in life in the church age, and this earlier maturity in life will constitute a prize with which the Lord will reward them at His coming back. That prize will be the entrance into the millennial kingdom and participation in the divine blessings in that stage, such as the joy and rest of the Lord ([link]Matt. 25:21[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:9-11[/link]), the reign over the nations ([link]2:26-27[/link]; [link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]), etc., which God has prepared as an incentive for His chosen ones to go on with Him in the church age. However, many of His chosen ones, after receiving His forgiveness, redemption, eternal life, divine nature, etc., will not cooperate with His grace and will not go on with Him. Hence, they are unable to mature in life in the church age and thus will not be ready at the Lord's coming back to enter into the millennial kingdom and share in the divine blessings of that age as a prize. Therefore, during the millennial kingdom their names will be erased from the book of life. After being disciplined by the Lord and growing in life unto maturity during the millennial kingdom, they will share in the divine blessings in the stage of eternity, such as the eternal priesthood with God's eternal presence, the eternal kingship ([link]22:3-5[/link]), the New Jerusalem, the tree of life ([link]22:14[/link]), the water of life ([link]22:17[/link]), etc. At that time their names should again be written in the book of life. This means that all God's chosen ones whose names are written in the book of life and who have been brought into the participation of the divine blessings in the stage of the church "shall by no means perish forever" ([link]John 10:28[/link]); that is, they shall by no means lose the divine blessings of eternity. But some, those who do not cooperate with the Lord in the church age, will be dispensationally disciplined by the Lord during the millennial kingdom and will miss the divine blessings in that stage.
Lit., scroll.

In the kingdom age the Lord will confess the name of the overcomer because the overcomer's name will not have been erased out of the book of life but will still be written in it. This implies that if the believers are not overcomers, in the kingdom age their names will be erased out of the book of life (see note [link]5[sup]3[/sup][/link]) and therefore will not be confessed by the Lord.

verse.text: He who has an [xref]a[/xref]ear, let him hear what the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit says to the churches.

And to the messenger of the church in [note]1[/note]Philadelphia write: These things says the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Holy One, the [xref]b[/xref]true One, the One who has the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]key of David, the One who opens and no one will shut, and shuts and no one opens:
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]brotherly love.[/i] As a sign, the church in Philadelphia prefigures the proper church life recovered by the brothers raised up by the Lord in England in the early part of the nineteenth century. Just as the reformed church, prefigured by the church in Sardis, was a reaction to the apostate Catholic Church, prefigured by the church in Thyatira, so the church of brotherly love was a reaction to the dead reformed church. This reaction will continue as an anti-testimony to both apostate Catholicism and degraded Protestantism until the Lord comes back.
To the church of brotherly love, the Lord is the Holy One, the true One, by whom and with whom the recovered church can be holy, separated from the world, and true, faithful, to God.
To the recovered church, the Lord is also the One who has the key of David, the key of the kingdom, with authority to open and to shut. The Lord uses this key to deal with the recovered church.

verse.text: I [xref]a[/xref]know your works; behold, I have put before you an [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]opened door which [xref]c[/xref]no one can shut, because you have a [note]2[/note]little power and have [xref]d[/xref]kept My [note]3[/note]word and have not [xref]e[/xref]denied My [note]3[/note]name.
verse.note: As the One who has the key of David and who opens and no one will shut, the Lord has given the recovered church an opened door, which no one can shut. Since the recovery of the proper church life began, in the early part of the nineteenth century, until now, a door has always been opened wide to the Lord's recovery. The more organized Christianity tries to shut the door, the wider it is opened. In spite of much opposition, today the door is open worldwide. The key is in the hand of the Head of the church; it is not in the hand of the opposers.
This indicates that what pleases the Lord is not our doing much for Him but our doing our best for Him with what we have.

The Lord's word is the Lord's expression, and the Lord's name is the Lord Himself. The apostate church has deviated from the Lord's word and become heretical. The reformed church, though recovered to the Lord's word to some extent, has denied the Lord's name by denominating herself, taking many other names, such as Lutheran, Wesleyan, Anglican, Presbyterian, Baptist, etc. The recovered church not only has returned in a full way to the Lord's word but also has abandoned all names other than that of the Lord Jesus Christ. The recovered church belongs to the Lord absolutely, having nothing to do with any denominations (any names). To deviate from the Lord's word is apostasy, and to denominate the church by taking any name other than the Lord's is spiritual fornication. The church, as the pure virgin espoused to Christ ([link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]), should have no name other than her Husband's. All other names are an abomination in the eyes of God. In the recovered church life there are no teachings of Balaam ([link]2:14[/link]), no teachings of the Nicolaitans ([link]2:15[/link]), no teachings of Jezebel ([link]2:20[/link]), and no mysterious doctrines of Satan ([link]2:24[/link]); there is only the pure word of the Lord. The recovered church has no denominations (names); it has only the unique name of the Lord Jesus Christ. The deviation from the word to heresies and the exalting of many names other than that of Christ are the most striking signs of degraded Christianity. The return to the pure word from all heresies and traditions and the exalting of the Lord's name by abandoning every other name constitute the most inspiring testimony in the recovered church. This is why the church in the Lord's recovery has the revelation and presence of the Lord and expresses the Lord in a living way, full of light and with the riches of life.

verse.text: Behold, I will make those of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]synagogue of [xref]b[/xref]Satan, those who call themselves [xref]c[/xref]Jews and are [note]2[/note]not, but lie — behold, I will cause them to come and [xref]d[/xref]fall [note]3[/note]prostrate before your feet and to know that I have [xref]e[/xref]loved you.
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
See note [link]9[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

The Jewish synagogue holds on to Judaism, which comprises the mediatorial priests, the ordinances of letters, the material temple, and the earthly promises. The recovered church has subdued Judaism by exposing its error and stubbornness in holding on to the above four things and has caused the Jews to know that the Lord has loved her.

verse.text: Because you have [xref]a[/xref]kept the [note]1[/note]word of My [xref]b[/xref]endurance, I also will [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]keep you out of the hour of [xref]d[/xref]trial, which is about to come on the whole inhabited earth, to try them who [xref]e[/xref]dwell on the earth.
verse.note: The word of the Lord's endurance is the word of the Lord's suffering. The Lord today is still bearing rejection and persecution by His endurance. We are the joint partakers not only of His kingdom but also of His endurance ([link]1:9[/link]). Hence, His word to us today is the word of endurance. To keep the word of His endurance, we must bear His rejection and persecution.

[i]Trial[/i] here undoubtedly denotes the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]), which is about to come on the whole inhabited earth, as indicated by the fifth trumpet, the sixth trumpet, and the seven bowls of the seventh trumpet ([link]8:13-9:21[/link]; [link]11:14-15[/link]; [link]15:1[/link]; [link]16:1-21[/link]). The trial also includes the supernatural calamities of the sixth seal and the first four trumpets at the beginning of the great tribulation. The Lord promised the recovered church that He would keep her out of the hour of trial (not only out of the trial, but out of the [i]hour[/i] of trial) because she has kept the word of the Lord's endurance. This promise of the Lord, like His promise in [link]Luke 21:36[/link], indicates that the saints who keep the word of the Lord's endurance will be raptured before the great trial, implying that those who do not keep the word of the Lord's endurance will be left in the trial.

verse.text: I [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]come quickly; [xref]b[/xref]hold fast what you have that no one take your [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]crown.
verse.note: In this epistle the Lord brings the church in His recovery into the sensation of His coming, because she loves Him.
The recovered church has gained the crown already. However, if she does not hold fast what she has in the Lord's recovery until the Lord comes back, her crown may be taken away by someone.

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]overcomes, him I will make a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]pillar in the [xref]c[/xref]temple of My God, and he shall by no means go out anymore, and I will write upon him the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]name of My God and the name of the city of My God, the [xref]e[/xref]New Jerusalem, which descends out of heaven from My God, and My [xref]f[/xref]new name.
verse.note: To overcome here is to hold fast what we have in the recovered church.

In [link]2:17[/link] the overcomer will become a transformed stone for God's building. Here the overcomer will be made a pillar built into the temple of God. Because he is built into God's building, he shall by no means go out anymore. This promise, as a prize to the overcomer, will be fulfilled in the millennial kingdom.

That the name of God, the name of the New Jerusalem, and the Lord's new name are written upon the overcomer indicates that the overcomer is possessed by God, by the New Jerusalem, and by the Lord; that God Himself, His city (the New Jerusalem), and the Lord Himself all belong to him; and that he is one with God, with the New Jerusalem, and with the Lord. The name of God denotes God Himself, the name of the New Jerusalem denotes the city itself, and the name of the Lord denotes the Lord Himself. That the name of God, the name of the New Jerusalem, and the name of the Lord are written upon the overcomer indicates that what God is, the nature of the New Jerusalem, and the person of the Lord have all been wrought into the overcomer. The mentioning of the New Jerusalem as a prize to the overcomer indicates that this promise will be fulfilled in the millennial kingdom. The New Jerusalem in the millennial kingdom will be a prize only to the overcoming saints, whereas the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth will be the common portion of all the redeemed for eternity.

verse.text: He who has an [xref]a[/xref]ear, let him hear what the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit says to the churches.

And to the messenger of the church in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Laodicea write: These things says the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Amen, the faithful and true [xref]c[/xref]Witness, the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]beginning of the creation of God:
verse.note: The Greek word means [i]opinion, judgment, of the people[/i] or [i]of the laymen.[/i] As a sign, the church in Laodicea prefigures the degraded recovered church. Less than one century after the Lord recovered the proper church in the early part of the nineteenth century, some of the recovered "assemblies" (called such by the Brethren) became degraded. The degraded recovered church differs from the reformed church, signified by the church in Sardis, and from the proper recovered church, signified by the church in Philadelphia. It will exist until the Lord comes back.

In addressing each of the seven churches, the Lord referred to what He is and what He does, respectively, according to the situation and condition of each. Here, in addressing the church in Laodicea, He referred to Himself as "the Amen, the faithful and true Witness, the beginning of the creation of God." [i]Amen,[/i] from Hebrew, means [i]firm, steadfast,[/i] or [i]trustworthy.[/i] The Lord is the firm, steadfast, and trustworthy One. Hence, He is the faithful and true Witness. This indicates that the degraded church in Laodicea is not firm, steadfast, trustworthy, or faithful and true as the Lord's witness. [i]The beginning of the creation of God[/i] refers to the Lord as the origin or source of God's creation, implying that the Lord is the unchanging and ever-existing source of God's work. This indicates that the degraded recovered church has changed by leaving the Lord as the source.
Or, origin, source; that is, the originating source.
verse.xref: [link]Isa. 65:16[/link] (True God; Lit.; the God of Amen); [link]2 Cor. 1:20[/link]

verse.text: I [xref]a[/xref]know your works, that you are neither cold nor [note]1[/note]hot; I wish that you were cold or [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]hot.
verse.note: Lit., boiling. So in the next verse.

verse.text: So, because you are lukewarm and neither hot nor cold, I am about to [note]1[/note]spew you out of My mouth.
verse.note: To be spewed out of the Lord's mouth is to be rejected by the Lord and to lose the enjoyment of all that the Lord is to His church.

verse.text: Because you [note]1[/note]say, I am [xref]a[/xref]wealthy and have become rich and have need of nothing, and do not know that you are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]wretched and miserable and poor and [xref]c[/xref]blind and [xref]d[/xref]naked,
verse.note: The degraded recovered church boasts of her riches (which are mainly in the knowledge of doctrines). She does not realize that she is poor in life, blind in sight, and naked in conduct. Therefore, she needs to buy gold to make herself rich, white garments to cover her nakedness, and eyesalve to cure her blindness, as mentioned in the next verse.

In the eyes of the Lord the degraded recovered church is (1) wretched because she is proud of being rich in the vain knowledge of doctrine, but in reality is sorely poor in the experience of the riches of Christ; (2) miserable because she is naked, blind, and full of shame and darkness; (3) poor because she is poor in the experience of Christ and in the spiritual reality of God's economy; (4) blind because she lacks true spiritual insight in the genuine spiritual things; and (5) naked because she does not live by Christ or live Christ as her subjective righteousness, as the second garment in her daily walk.

verse.text: I counsel you to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]buy from Me [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]gold [xref]c[/xref]refined by [xref]d[/xref]fire that you may be [xref]e[/xref]rich, and [note]3[/note][xref]f[/xref]white garments that you may be clothed and [i]that[/i] the shame of your [xref]g[/xref]nakedness may not be manifested, and [note]4[/note]eyesalve to [xref]h[/xref]anoint your eyes that you may see.
verse.note: Buying requires the paying of a price. The degraded recovered church must pay a price for gold, white garments, and eyesalve, which she desperately needs.

In the Bible our operating, working faith ([link]Gal. 5:6[/link]) is likened to gold ([link]1 Pet. 1:7[/link]), and the divine nature of God, which is the divinity of Christ, is typified by gold ([link]Exo. 25:11[/link]). By faith we partake of the divine nature of God ([link]2 Pet. 1:1[/link], [link]4-5[/link]). The degraded recovered church has the knowledge of the doctrines concerning Christ but not much living faith to partake of the divine element of Christ. She needs to pay the price to gain the golden faith through the fiery trials that she may participate in the real gold, which is Christ Himself as the life element to His Body. Thus she can become a pure golden lampstand ([link]1:20[/link]) for the building of the golden New Jerusalem ([link]21:18[/link]).

In figure, garments signify conduct. White garments here signify conduct that can be approved by the Lord. Such conduct is the Lord Himself lived out of the church, and it is required by the degraded recovered church for the covering of her nakedness.

The eyesalve needed to anoint their eyes must be the anointing Spirit ([link]1 John 2:27[/link]), who is the Lord Himself as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]). The degraded recovered church needs this kind of eyesalve also for the healing of her blindness. For the three items mentioned in this verse, she must pay the price.

verse.text: As many as I [xref]a[/xref]love I reprove and [xref]b[/xref]discipline; be [note]1[/note]zealous therefore and [xref]c[/xref]repent.
verse.note: Lit., boiling. Dead, vain knowledge and doctrinal forms have made the degraded recovered church lukewarm. She needs to repent of her lukewarmness and be zealous, boiling, burning, that thereby she may regain the enjoyment of the reality of Christ.

verse.text: Behold, I stand at the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]door and [xref]b[/xref]knock; if anyone [xref]c[/xref]hears My [xref]d[/xref]voice and [note]2[/note]opens the door, then I will [xref]e[/xref]come in to him and [note]3[/note]dine with him and he with Me.
verse.note: This door is not the door of the hearts of individuals but the door of the church. The Lord as the Head of the church is standing outside the degraded church, knocking at her door. The degraded recovered church must realize this!

The door is the door of the church, but the door is opened by individual believers. The church in Laodicea has knowledge but does not have the Lord's presence. The Lord is dealing with the whole church, but the acceptance of the Lord's dealing must be a personal matter. The Lord's dealing is objective, but the believers' acceptance must be subjective.
The Greek word denotes taking the principal meal of the day at evening. See note [link]7[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]overcomes, to him I will give to [note]2[/note]sit with Me on My [xref]b[/xref]throne, as I also [xref]c[/xref]overcame and [xref]d[/xref]sat [xref]e[/xref]with My Father on His throne.
verse.note: Here to overcome is to overcome the lukewarmness and pride of the degraded recovered church, to pay the price to buy the needed items, and to open the door so that the Lord can come in.

To sit with the Lord on His throne will be a prize to the overcomer, that he may participate in the Lord's authority and be a co-king with Him in ruling over the whole earth in the coming millennial kingdom.

verse.text: He who has an [xref]a[/xref]ear, let him hear what the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit says to the [note]1[/note]churches.
verse.note: The seven churches not only signify prophetically the progress of the church in seven ages, as we have seen, but also symbolize the seven kinds of churches in church history: the initial church, the suffering church, the worldly church, the apostate church, the reformed church, the recovered church, and the degraded recovered church. The initial church had its continuation in the suffering church; the suffering church became the worldly church; and the worldly church became the apostate church. Hence, the first four churches issued eventually in one kind of church, that is, the apostate church, the Roman Catholic Church. Then the reformed church, as a reaction to the apostate church, came into existence as another kind of church, a church not fully recovered. Hence, after this, the recovered church was raised up as a full recovery of the proper church life. This can be considered the third kind of church. Through the degradation of the recovered church, the degraded recovered church came into being. This can be counted as the fourth kind of church. These four kinds of churches will all remain until the Lord comes back. Undoubtedly, only the recovered church can fulfill God's eternal purpose, and only she is what the Lord is after. We must take the Lord's choice.

verse.text: After these things I saw, and behold, a [xref]a[/xref]door [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]opened in heaven, and the first [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]voice which I heard was like a trumpet speaking with me, saying, [xref]d[/xref]Come up here, and I will show you the things that must take place after these [xref]e[/xref]things.
verse.note: God's plan is hidden in heaven. When God finds a man on earth after His heart, heaven is opened to him. It was opened to Jacob ([link]Gen. 28:12-17[/link]), to Ezekiel ([link]Ezek. 1:1[/link]), to Jesus ([link]Matt. 3:16[/link]), to Stephen ([link]Acts 7:56[/link]), and to Peter ([link]Acts 10:11[/link]). Here and in [link]19:11[/link] it was opened to John, the writer of this book, and it will be opened to all believers in the Lord in eternity ([link]John 1:51[/link]).
The voice heard in [link]1:10[/link].

verse.text: Immediately I was in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]spirit; and behold, there was a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]throne set in heaven, and upon the throne [i]there was[/i] [xref]c[/xref]One sitting;
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

In this book the throne of God is the center of God's administration. In the Epistles the throne is the throne of grace, from which we receive mercy and find grace ([link]Heb. 4:16[/link]). In this book the throne is the throne of judgment, from which the world receives judgment. Eventually, after all God's judgments have been executed, the throne of God will be the throne of the supply of eternal life, out of which will proceed the living water of life, in which the tree of life grows, as the supply of God's redeemed in eternity.

verse.text: And He who was sitting was like a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]jasper stone and a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sardius in appearance, and [i]there was[/i] a [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]rainbow around the throne like an [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]emerald in appearance.
verse.note: According to [link]21:11[/link], the jasper is "a most precious stone...as clear as crystal." Its color must be dark green, which signifies life in its richness. Jasper here, as indicated in [link]21:11[/link], signifies God's communicable glory in His rich life ([link]John 17:22[/link], [link]2[/link]). God's appearance is like jasper, as also the appearance of the holy city, New Jerusalem, will be ([link]21:11[/link]). The city's wall and first foundation are built with jasper ([link]21:18-19[/link]).

The sardius too is a most precious stone, and its red color signifies redemption. While jasper signifies God as the God of glory in His rich life, sardius signifies God as the God of redemption. On the breastplate of the high priest in the Old Testament, the first stone was a sardius and the last a jasper ([link]Exo. 28:17[/link], [link]20[/link]). This signifies that God's redeemed people have their beginning in God's redemption and their consummation in God's glory of life.

The rainbow is a sign of God's covenant with man and all living creatures that He will not destroy them again with a flood ([link]Gen. 9:8-17[/link]). This book shows that God will judge the earth with all its inhabitants. The rainbow around His throne signifies that God is the covenanting God, the faithful God, who will keep His covenant while executing His judgment upon the earth. He will not judge mankind again with a flood nor destroy all mankind, but will keep a part of mankind to be the nations on the new earth for His glory ([link]21:24[/link], [link]26[/link]).

The rainbow around God's throne is like an emerald in appearance. An emerald is a precious stone whose grass-green color signifies the lives on earth. This indicates that as God is executing His judgment upon the earth, He will remember His covenant and will spare some of the lives on earth, as indicated in [link]Gen. 9:11[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]around the throne [i]there were[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]twenty-four thrones, and upon the thrones [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]twenty-four [note]2[/note]elders sitting, clothed in [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]white garments, and upon their heads golden [xref]e[/xref]crowns.
verse.note: Twenty-four is formed by multiplying twelve by two. Twelve indicates the completion of God's administration ([link]Matt. 19:28[/link]). David divided both the priests and the Levites into twenty-four groups to carry out God's administrative service. Therefore, before they are replaced by the church, the twenty-four angelic elders are the ones who carry out God's administration. Twelve multiplied by two signifies strengthening by doubling, indicating that the divine administration carried out by the twenty-four angelic elders is strong.

The elders here are not the elders of the church but the elders of the angels, because here, before the Lord's second coming, they are sitting on thrones already (cf. [link]Matt. 19:28[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4[/link]). Among God's creation the angels are the most ancient ones. Their elders are the elders of the whole creation of God. That they sit on thrones with golden crowns on their heads indicates that they must be the ones who rule the universe until the millennial kingdom, when the authority to rule the earth will be given to the overcoming saints ([link]Heb. 2:5-9[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:26-27[/link]; [link]20:4[/link]). That they are clothed in white garments and have a harp and golden bowls full of incense ([link]5:8[/link]) indicates that now they are also priests before God; in the millennial kingdom, however, the reigning overcomers will be the priests of God and of Christ ([link]20:6[/link]). The elders' golden crowns indicate that they are also ruling ones. Therefore, they are priests serving God and kings reigning over His creation.
The white garments here indicate that these angelic elders are sinless and, unlike the redeemed saints, have no need to be washed by the blood of the Lamb ([link]7:14[/link]).

verse.text: And out of the throne come forth [xref]a[/xref]lightnings and voices and thunders. And [i]there were[/i] [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]seven lamps of fire burning before the throne, which are the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]seven Spirits of God;
verse.note: The seven lamps here are based upon the seven lamps of the lampstand in [link]Exo. 25:37[/link] and [link]Zech. 4:2[/link]. The seven lamps of fire, which are the seven Spirits of God, signify the enlightening and searching of the sevenfold intensified Spirit of God. In [link]Exo. 25[/link] and [link]Zech. 4[/link] the seven lamps, signifying the enlightening of the Spirit of God in God's move, are for God's building, either for the building of the tabernacle or for the rebuilding of the temple. Here the seven lamps are for God's judgment, which will issue also in God's building — the building of the New Jerusalem.
See note [link]4[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And before the throne [i]there was[/i] as it were a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glassy sea like [xref]b[/xref]crystal; and in the midst of the throne and around the throne, [i]there were[/i] [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]four living creatures [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]full of eyes in front and behind.
verse.note: This glassy sea is not of water but of fire ([link]15:2[/link]). Since the deluge, God, in accordance with His promise that He would not judge the earth and all living creatures again with water ([link]Gen. 9:15[/link]), always exercises His judgment upon man with fire ([link]Gen. 19:24[/link]; [link]Lev. 10:2[/link]; [link]Num. 11:1[/link]; [link]16:35[/link]; [link]Dan. 7:11[/link]; [link]Rev. 14:10[/link]; [link]18:8[/link]; [link]19:20[/link]; [link]20:9-10[/link]; [link]21:8[/link]). God's throne of judgment is like the fiery flame out of which a fiery stream issues ([link]Dan. 7:9-10[/link]). The flame of God's judging fire sweeps all negative things in the entire universe into this glassy sea, which eventually becomes the lake of fire ([link]20:14[/link]). The glassy sea, being the aggregate of all God's fiery judgment, is like crystal, signifying that every negative thing under God's judgment is crystal clear. Here we have the rainbow around the throne of God, signifying that God will keep His promise recorded in [link]Gen. 9:8-17[/link]. We also have the glassy sea of fire, indicating that God will judge all negative things still with fire.

The twenty-four elders around the throne of God represent all the angels, whereas the four living creatures represent all other living creatures. The first, which is like a lion, represents the beasts; the second, which is like a calf, represents the cattle; the third, which is like a man, represents mankind; and the fourth, which is like an eagle, represents the fowl ([link]v. 7[/link]). Of the six categories of living things created by God ([link]Gen. 1:20-28[/link]), two are not represented here — the creeping things on the earth and the living things in the water. The head of the creeping things is the serpent, a symbol of God's enemy, Satan, who will be cast into the lake of fire and will have no place in the new heaven and new earth. The living things in the water are in the water of God's judgment, which will no longer exist in the new heaven and new earth ([link]21:1[/link]). Hence, for eternity these two categories are not represented before God.[br][br]Among the four living creatures, the calf is clean, but the lion and the eagle are unclean ([link]Lev. 11:3[/link], [link]27[/link], [link]13-19[/link]). After being redeemed, they all became clean ([link]Acts 10:11-16[/link]). Among them the calf and the man are meek and gentle, but the lion and eagle are wild and fierce. Through redemption they can all dwell together ([link]Isa. 11:6-9[/link]). Christ's redemption is not only for man but for all things ([link]Col. 1:20[/link]), for He died on behalf of everything ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]).

Eyes enable living things to receive light and vision. The four living creatures are full of eyes, not only in front and behind but also around and within ([link]v. 8[/link]), indicating that they are absolutely not opaque but are crystal clear in every aspect. In the presence of God we, the redeemed people, should be like this.

verse.text: And the first living creature was [note]1[/note]like a [xref]a[/xref]lion, and the second living creature like a [xref]a[/xref]calf, and the third living creature had a face like that of a [xref]a[/xref]man, and the fourth living creature was like a flying [xref]a[/xref]eagle.
verse.note: In appearance, the four living creatures resemble the cherubim in [link]Ezek. 1:5-10[/link] and [link]10:14-15[/link]. In that they each have six wings ([link]v. 8[/link]), they are like the seraphim in [link]Isa. 6:2[/link]. (The cherubim in [link]Exo. 25:20[/link] and [link]1 Kings 6:27[/link] have two wings, and the cherubim in [link]Ezek. 1:6[/link] have four wings.) They must be a combination of the cherubim and the seraphim. As the seraphim, they are for God's holiness ([link]Isa. 6:3[/link]), referring to God's nature, and as the cherubim, they are for God's glory ([link]Ezek. 10:18-19[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:5[/link]), referring to God's expression. Hence, they stand for God's nature and expression.

verse.text: And the four living creatures, each one of them having [xref]a[/xref]six wings apiece, are full of eyes around and within; and they have no rest day and night, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Holy, holy, holy, [xref]c[/xref]Lord God the Almighty, [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]who was and who is and who is coming.
verse.note: The mentioning of [i]holy[/i] three times, as in [link]Isa. 6:3[/link], implies that God is triune.
The use of three tenses in speaking of God's existence also implies that God is triune. See note [link]4[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And when the [i]four[/i] living creatures give [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory and honor and thanks to Him who sits upon the throne, to Him who [xref]b[/xref]lives forever and ever,
verse.note: The praises of both the four living creatures in this verse and the twenty-four elders in [link]v. 11[/link] are composed of three items, implying that both the living creatures and the elders are praising the Triune God. The first two items, glory and honor, are the same in both places, but the last item is different: In the praises of the four living creatures the last item is thanks — they are redeemed and are grateful for the redemption of God's grace; whereas in the praises of the twenty-four elders the last item is power — as the rulers of the universe (they are not the redeemed creatures), they appreciate the power of God, by which they rule.

verse.text: The twenty-four elders will [xref]a[/xref]fall before Him who sits upon the throne and worship Him who lives forever and ever; and they will [note]1[/note]cast their crowns before the throne, saying,
verse.note: According to the preceding verses, this section of the holy Word implies that when the redeemed saints — represented by the man among the four living creatures, who are redeemed — have been perfected and glorified to be the proper priests and kings ([link]20:6[/link]), the temporary priests and kings, the twenty-four angelic elders, will resign from their offices. This is implied by the fact that they will cast their crowns before the throne.

verse.text: You are [xref]a[/xref]worthy, our Lord and God, to receive the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]glory and the honor and the power, for You have [xref]c[/xref]created all things, and because of Your [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]will they were, and were created.
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup][/link].

God is a God of purpose, having a will of His own pleasure. He created all things for His will that He might accomplish and fulfill His purpose. This book, which unveils God's universal administration, shows us the purpose of God. Hence, in the twenty-four elders' praise to God concerning His creation, His creation is related to His will.

verse.text: And I saw on the right hand of Him who sits upon the throne a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]scroll written within and on the back, sealed up with [note]2[/note]seven seals.
verse.note: This scroll must be the new covenant, the grand title deed in the universe, enacted with the blood of the Lamb for God's redemption of the church, Israel, the world, and the universe. This book is a record of God's thought concerning the church, Israel, the world, and the universe.

The seven seals with which the scroll is sealed up are actually the contents of the scroll and the contents of the book of Revelation. The book of Revelation is just the opening, the unveiling, of the seven seals.

verse.text: And I saw a strong angel proclaiming with a loud voice, Who is [xref]a[/xref]worthy to open the scroll and to break its seals?
And no one [xref]a[/xref]in heaven nor on the earth nor under the earth was able to open the scroll or look into it.
And I wept much because [note]1[/note]no one was found worthy to open the scroll or look into it.
verse.note: If actually no one in the whole universe was found worthy to open the scroll, we would surely need to weep, for the whole universe would be vanity, with none qualified to unveil its secret.

verse.text: And one of the elders said to me, Do not weep; behold, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Lion of the tribe of [xref]b[/xref]Judah, the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Root of David, has [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]overcome so that He may open the scroll and its seven seals.
verse.note: The lion is a symbol of Christ, portraying Him as a strong fighter against the enemy, as prophesied in [link]Gen. 49:8-9[/link]. Christ's overcoming qualifies Him to open the scroll and its seven seals.

The title [i]Root of David[/i] (He is also the Root of David's father, Jesse — [link]Isa. 11:1[/link]) signifies that Christ is the source of David. Therefore, David, His forefather, called Him "Lord" ([link]Matt. 22:42-45[/link]).

As the Lion of the tribe of Judah, Christ overcame and defeated the rebellious Satan, the enemy of God, and as the redeeming Lamb, He took away the sin of fallen man. By so doing, He removed the hindrances to the fulfillment of God's purpose. Therefore, He is worthy to open the scroll concerning God's economy.

verse.text: And I saw in the midst of the throne and of the four living creatures and in the midst of the elders a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Lamb [note]2[/note]standing as [note]3[/note]having [i]just[/i] been [xref]b[/xref]slain, having [note]4[/note]seven [xref]c[/xref]horns and [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]seven [xref]e[/xref]eyes, [note]6[/note]which are the [xref]f[/xref]seven Spirits of God sent forth into [xref]g[/xref]all the earth.
verse.note: In [link]ch. 4[/link] is the scene in the heavens, its center being the throne of God, on which God sits, ready to execute His universal administration for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose. Here in [link]ch. 5[/link] is the same scene in the heavens after Christ ascended there. He was recommended to the apostle John as the Lion of the tribe of Judah by one of the elders, but He appeared to John as a Lamb. As the Lion, He is the Fighter against the enemy; as the Lamb, He is the Redeemer for us. He fought to redeem us, and He won the battle over the enemy and accomplished redemption for us. To the enemy He is a Lion; to us He is a Lamb. Hence, He is the Lion-Lamb.

As far as redemption is concerned, Christ sat down at the right hand of God in the heavens after His ascension ([link]Heb. 1:3[/link]; [link]10:12[/link]), whereas regarding the carrying out of God's administration, He is still standing in His ascension.

[i]Having just been slain[/i] indicates that the Lamb had just been slain and also that the scene in the heavens that is depicted in this chapter took place immediately after Christ's ascension into the heavens.

Horns signify strength in fighting ([link]Deut. 33:17[/link]). Christ is the redeeming Lamb, yet He has horns for fighting. He is the fighting Redeemer. His fighting is complete (perfect and complete) in God's move, as signified by the number seven.

Eyes are for observing and searching. Christ as the redeeming Lamb has seven observing and searching eyes for executing God's judgment upon the universe to fulfill God's eternal purpose, which will consummate in the building up of the New Jerusalem. Therefore, in [link]Zech. 3:9[/link] He is prophesied as the stone, the topstone ([link]Zech. 4:7[/link]) with seven eyes for God's building. These seven eyes are the seven Spirits of God sent forth into all the earth, and they run to and fro through the whole earth ([link]Zech. 4:10[/link]). See note [link]14[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
According to Greek grammar, the antecedent of [i]which[/i] is [i]seven eyes.[/i] Hence, the seven Spirits of God refer only to the seven eyes of the Lamb, and not to His seven horns.

verse.text: And He came and took [i]the scroll[/i] out of the right hand of Him who sits upon the throne.

And when He took the scroll, the [xref]a[/xref]four living creatures and the [xref]b[/xref]twenty-four elders fell before the Lamb, each having a [xref]c[/xref]harp and [xref]d[/xref]golden [note]1[/note]bowls full of [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]incense, which [i]bowls[/i] are the [xref]f[/xref]prayers of the saints.
verse.note: The bowls are the saints' prayers brought to God by the angelic elders (cf. [link]8:3-4[/link]), whereas the incense is Christ added to the saints' prayers. See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 8[/link]. That in their worship to God the twenty-four angelic elders are holding the golden bowls full of incense shows that they, as priests, are ministering to God by bringing the saints' prayers to Him.
Lit., incenses.

verse.text: And they sing a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]new song, saying: You are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]worthy to take the scroll and to open its seals, for You were [xref]c[/xref]slain and have [xref]d[/xref]purchased for God [note]3[/note]by Your [xref]e[/xref]blood [i]men[/i] out of [xref]f[/xref]every tribe and tongue and people and nation,
verse.note: The song here is new because the Lamb whom it praises had just been slain.

In the whole universe no one is worthy to open the mystery of God's economy but Christ, the overcoming Lion and the redeeming Lamb. As the overcoming Lion, He defeated Satan for God, and as the redeeming Lamb, He put sin away for us. He is the only One qualified to unveil and carry out the mystery of God's economy.
Lit., in.

verse.text: And have made [note]1[/note]them a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom and priests to our God; and they will [xref]b[/xref]reign [note]3[/note]on the earth.
verse.note: [i]Them[/i] refers to the redeemed ones ([link]v. 9[/link]). That the twenty-four elders referred to these redeemed ones as [i]them[/i] in their praise proves that the praising elders are not of the church but of the angels.
The kingdom is for kingship, for the exercising of God's authority, and the priests are for the priesthood, for the accomplishing of the divine ministry.
Or, over.

verse.text: And I saw, and I heard the voice of [note]1[/note]many angels around the throne and of the living creatures and of the elders, and their number was [xref]a[/xref]ten thousands of ten thousands and thousands of thousands,
verse.note: The many angels, represented by the twenty-four elders, follow the elders to render to the Lamb the angelic praise.

verse.text: Saying with a loud voice, [xref]a[/xref]Worthy is the [xref]b[/xref]Lamb who has been [xref]c[/xref]slain to receive the [xref]d[/xref]power and [xref]e[/xref]riches and wisdom and strength and honor and [xref]f[/xref]glory and [xref]g[/xref]blessing.

And [note]1[/note]every creature which is [xref]a[/xref]in heaven and on the earth and under the earth and on the sea and all things in them, I heard saying, To Him who sits upon the throne and to the [xref]b[/xref]Lamb be the blessing and the honor and the glory and the might forever and ever.
verse.note: All the creatures, who are represented by the four living creatures, follow the living creatures to give the Lamb the universal praise of all creatures other than the angels.

verse.text: And the four living creatures said, [xref]a[/xref]Amen. And the elders fell down and worshipped.

And I saw when the [xref]a[/xref]Lamb [note]1[/note]opened one of the [xref]b[/xref]seven seals, and I heard one of the [xref]c[/xref]four [note]2[/note]living creatures saying like the [xref]d[/xref]sound of thunder, [xref]e[/xref]Come.
verse.note: The opening of the seven seals by the Lamb occurred immediately after Christ ascended to the heavens. Through His incarnation, crucifixion, and resurrection, Christ became fully qualified in His ascension to open the mystery of God's economy, which is contained in the seven seals.
Because God's economy concerning the creatures is contained in the seven seals, the four living creatures are interested in announcing, respectively, the opening of the first four seals.

verse.text: And I saw, and behold, a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]white horse, and [note]2[/note]he who sits on it had a [note]3[/note]bow; and a [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]crown was given to him, and he [xref]c[/xref]went forth [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]conquering and to conquer.
verse.note: White signifies clean, pure, just, and approvable. The white horse is a symbol of the preaching of the gospel, which is clean, pure, just, and approvable in the eyes of both man and God.

The first four seals consist of four horses with their riders, as in a four-horse race. The four riders are not persons but personified things. It is evident that the rider of the second horse, the red horse, is war ([link]v. 4[/link]), that the rider of the third horse, the black horse, is famine ([link]v. 5[/link]), and that the rider of the fourth horse, the pale horse, is death ([link]v. 8[/link]). According to historical facts, the rider of the first horse, the white horse, must be the gospel, not Christ or Antichrist as some interpret. Immediately after Christ's ascension, these four things — the gospel, war, famine, and death — began to run like riders on four horses, and they will continue until Christ comes back. Beginning from the first century the gospel has been spreading throughout all these twenty centuries. Simultaneously, war among the human race has been proceeding. War has always caused famine, and famine issues in death. All these will continue until the end of this age.

A bow with an arrow is for fighting. But here there is a bow without an arrow. This indicates that the arrow has already been shot to destroy the enemy and that the victory has been won for the constituting of the gospel of peace. Now the fighting is over, and the gospel of peace is being proclaimed in a peaceful way.
A crown is a sign of glory. The gospel has been crowned with the glory of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 4:4[/link]).
Or, overcoming and to overcome. Throughout all the centuries, wherever the gospel has been proclaimed, it has conquered and overcome all kinds of opposition and attack.

verse.text: And when He opened the second seal, I heard the second living creature saying, Come.

And [note]1[/note]I saw, and behold, another horse, a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]red one, went forth; and to him who sits on it, to him [i]authority[/i] was given to [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]take peace from the earth, and that [i]men[/i] should slay one another; and to him a great [xref]c[/xref]sword was given.
verse.note: Some ancient MSS omit, I saw, and behold.
Red here signifies the shedding of blood. The red horse is a symbol of the raging of war, which is altogether a matter of shedding blood.
[i]To take peace from the earth, men should slay one another,[/i] and [i]to him a great sword was given[/i] all clearly indicate war.

verse.text: And when He opened the third seal, I heard the third living creature saying, Come. And I saw, and behold, a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]black horse; and he who sits on it had a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]balance in his hand.
verse.note: Black here, indicating dearth ([link]Jer. 14:1-4[/link]), signifies the color of the visage of famished people ([link]Lam. 4:8-9[/link]; [link]5:9-10[/link]). The black horse is a symbol of the spreading of famine, which causes people to have a black visage.
A balance is a scale used to weigh precious things. But here it is used to weigh food (see [link]v. 6[/link]), thus showing that food is scarce (cf. [link]Lev. 26:26[/link]; [link]Ezek. 4:16[/link]).

verse.text: And I heard as it were a voice in the midst of the four living creatures saying: A [note]1[/note]choenix of wheat for a [note]2[/note]denarius and three choenixes of barley for a [note]2[/note]denarius; and do not harm the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]oil and the wine.
verse.note: A dry measure almost equal to a quart.
A denarius (singular for [i]denarii[/i]) was the chief silver coin of the Romans; it was considered good pay for a day's labor (cf. [link]Matt. 20:2[/link]).
Oil and wine are for man's pleasure ([link]Psa. 104:15[/link]). They are always in short supply and become precious in a famine. During the famine, oil and wine should be preserved and not harmed.

verse.text: And when He opened the fourth seal, I heard the voice of the fourth living creature saying, Come.

And I saw, and behold, a [note]1[/note]pale horse, and he who sits upon it, his name is [xref]a[/xref]Death; and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Hades followed with him. And authority was given to them over the fourth part of the earth to [xref]c[/xref]kill with the sword and with famine and with [note]3[/note]death and by the [note]4[/note]beasts of the earth.
verse.note: Or, pale green; signifying the facial color of those stricken with the plague. The pale horse is a symbol of the killing of death, which causes a pale appearance.

Hades is the place under the earth where the souls of the unsaved dead are kept before the dead are resurrected for the judgment of the great white throne ([link]20:11-15[/link]). After this judgment the unsaved will be cast into the lake of fire for eternity. Hades can be likened to a temporary jail, and the lake of fire to a permanent prison. Here Hades follows death to receive those whom death kills.
Or, pestilence.
To be killed by beasts is God's judgment ([link]2 Kings 2:24[/link]; [link]17:25[/link]; [link]Num. 21:6[/link]).

verse.text: And when He opened the [note]1[/note]fifth seal, I saw [note]2[/note]underneath the [xref]a[/xref]altar the [xref]b[/xref]souls of those who had been [xref]c[/xref]slain because of the [xref]d[/xref]word of God and because of the [xref]e[/xref]testimony which they had.
verse.note: The seven seals are divided, first, into groups of four and three and, second, into groups of six and one. The number four signifies the creatures, symbolized by the four living creatures, and the number six signifies creation (creation was completed in six days). The number three signifies the Triune God, and the number one signifies the unique God. Hence, both four plus three and six plus one indicate that the seven seals, through God's judgment, bring God's creation, with all the creatures, to God.[br][br]The fifth seal discloses Christian martyrdom from the first century to the time near the end of this age. (This may include the martyrdom of the Old Testament saints — [link]Matt. 23:34-36[/link].) While the preaching of the gospel, as indicated by the first seal, is progressing, the faithful saints are continually being martyred.

In figure, the altar is in the outer court of the tabernacle and the temple, and the outer court signifies the earth. Hence, the area underneath the altar is the region underneath the earth, where the souls of the martyred saints are. It is the Paradise to which the Lord Jesus went after His death ([link]Luke 23:43[/link]). It is in the heart of the earth ([link]Matt. 12:40[/link]) and is a section of Hades ([link]Acts 2:27[/link]), the comfortable section, where Abraham is ([link]Luke 16:22-26[/link]).

verse.text: And they [note]1[/note]cried with a loud voice, saying, How long, O Master, [xref]a[/xref]holy and true, will You not [xref]b[/xref]judge and [xref]c[/xref]avenge our blood on those who [xref]d[/xref]dwell on the earth?
verse.note: According to the word "yet a little while, until also the number...is completed" ([link]v. 11[/link]), this cry of the martyred saints must occur near the end of this age.

verse.text: And to each of them was given a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]white robe; and it was said to them that they should [xref]b[/xref]rest yet a little while, until also [i]the number of[/i] their fellow slaves and their brothers who were [xref]c[/xref]about to be [note]2[/note]killed, even as they were, is completed.
verse.note: The white robes here signify that their martyrdom was approved by God.
This will be the martyrdom during the great tribulation ([link]20:4[/link]).

verse.text: And I saw when He opened the [note]1[/note]sixth seal, and there was a great [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]earthquake, and the [xref]b[/xref]sun became black like [xref]c[/xref]sackcloth made of hair, and the whole moon became like blood;
verse.note: The sixth seal, which marks the beginning of supernatural calamities, is God's answer to the cry of the martyred saints in the fifth seal and is a warning to those who dwell on the earth. According to [link]Joel 2:30-31[/link], there will not be much difference in time between the sixth seal and the first five trumpets ([link]9:1-11[/link]). [link]Joel 2:30-31[/link] first mentions the blood of the first and second trumpets, the fire of the first, second, and third trumpets ([link]8:7-10[/link]), and the smoke of the fifth trumpet ([link]9:1-3[/link]), and then mentions the sun and moon of the sixth seal. A comparison of [link]9:4[/link] and [link]7:3[/link] indicates that the fifth trumpet occurs very close to the time of the sixth seal.

There will be two calamities of the shaking and changing of the earth and the hosts in heaven. The first will occur at the beginning of the great tribulation ([link]Joel 2:30-31[/link]), and the second will occur after the great tribulation ([link]Joel 3:11-16[/link]; [link]Matt. 24:29-30[/link]; [link]Luke 21:25-26[/link]). What is covered in the sixth seal is the first calamity. It can be considered not only a warning but also an initiation of the coming great tribulation.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]stars of heaven fell to the earth as a [xref]b[/xref]fig tree casts its unripe figs when shaken by a great wind.
And [xref]a[/xref]heaven was removed like a scroll being rolled up, and every [xref]b[/xref]mountain and island were moved out of their places.

And the [xref]a[/xref]kings of the earth and the great men and the [note]1[/note]generals and the rich and the strong and every slave and free man [xref]b[/xref]hid themselves in the caves and in the rocks of the mountains;
verse.note: Lit., captains over one thousand men.

verse.text: And they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]say to the mountains and to the rocks, Fall on us and hide us from the [xref]b[/xref]face of Him who sits upon the throne and from the [xref]c[/xref]wrath of the [xref]d[/xref]Lamb;
verse.note: They say this according to the feeling of their conscience, fearing the coming of the judgment of God. It is not a proclamation of God concerning the coming of His judgment.

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]great day of Their wrath has come, and [xref]b[/xref]who is able to stand?

[note]1[/note]After this I saw four angels standing at the [xref]a[/xref]four corners of the earth, holding the [xref]b[/xref]four [note]2[/note]winds of the earth, so that [note]3[/note]no wind would blow on the earth nor on the sea nor on any tree.
verse.note: This chapter is an insertion between the sixth seal ([link]6:12-17[/link]) and the seventh seal ([link]8:1[/link]), showing how God cares for His people while He is about to execute His judgment on the earth.
The winds here are for God's judgment ([link]Jonah 1:4[/link]; [link]Isa. 11:15[/link]; [link]Jer. 22:22[/link]; [link]49:36[/link]; [link]51:1[/link]).

The opening of the seventh seal will bring in the seven trumpets ([link]8:1-2[/link]). At the first trumpet, the third part of the earth and the third part of the trees will be burned up ([link]8:7[/link]). At the second trumpet, the third part of the sea will be destroyed ([link]8:8-9[/link]). Before all this takes place, God will seal all the Israelites whom He intends to preserve ([link]v. 3[/link]).

verse.text: And I saw [note]1[/note]another Angel ascending from the [xref]a[/xref]rising of the sun, having the seal of the [xref]b[/xref]living God; and He cried with a loud voice to the four angels to whom [i]authority[/i] was given to harm the earth and the sea,
verse.note: This Angel, as well as the One in [link]8:3[/link], [link]10:1[/link], and [link]18:1[/link], is Christ. In the Old Testament, Christ was called "the Angel of Jehovah"; that Angel was God Himself ([link]Gen. 22:11-12[/link]; [link]Exo. 3:2-6[/link]; [link]Judg. 6:11-24[/link]; [link]Zech. 1:11-12[/link]; [link]2:8-11[/link]; [link]3:1-7[/link]). Here in the New Testament He is again referred to as an Angel (a messenger). The expression [i]another Angel[/i] indicates that Christ is not a common angel but a special Angel sent by God.

verse.text: Saying, Do not harm the earth or the sea or the trees until we [xref]a[/xref]seal the slaves of our God upon [xref]b[/xref]their foreheads.
And I heard the number of [note]1[/note]those who were sealed, a [xref]a[/xref]hundred and forty-four thousand, sealed out of every tribe of the sons of Israel:
verse.note: These are the Israelites who will keep the commandments of God during the great tribulation ([link]12:17[/link]; [link]14:12[/link]).

verse.text: Out of the tribe of [note]1[/note]Judah, twelve thousand sealed; out of the tribe of Reuben, twelve thousand; out of the tribe of Gad, twelve thousand;
verse.note: Reuben was the firstborn of Israel, but because of his sinfulness he lost his birthright, and Judah prevailed above his brothers ([link]1 Chron. 5:1-2[/link]). Hence, here the tribe of Judah is mentioned first.

verse.text: Out of the tribe of Asher, twelve thousand; out of the tribe of Naphtali, twelve thousand; out of the tribe of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Manasseh, twelve thousand;
verse.note: Because Joseph ([link]v. 8[/link]) and Manasseh, one of Joseph's two sons ([link]Gen. 48:5[/link]), represent two different tribes, Joseph will still have the double portion of the birthright ([link]1 Chron. 5:1-2[/link]) during the millennium ([link]Ezek. 48:4-5[/link]).[br][br]In the account here, as in [link]1 Chron. 2-9[/link], the tribe of Dan was omitted because of its idolatry ([link]Judg. 18:30-31[/link]; [link]1 Kings 12:29-30[/link]; [link]2 Kings 10:29[/link]; cf. [link]Gen. 49:17[/link]). However, Dan will still be counted during the millennium ([link]Ezek. 48:1[/link]) because Jacob's blessing was upon him, so that through the Lord's salvation Dan will still be included as one of the tribes ([link]Gen. 49:16-18[/link]).

verse.text: Out of the tribe of Simeon, twelve thousand; out of the tribe of Levi, twelve thousand; out of the tribe of Issachar, twelve thousand;
Out of the tribe of Zebulun, twelve thousand; out of the tribe of Joseph, twelve thousand; out of the tribe of Benjamin, twelve thousand sealed.

After these things I saw, and behold, [i]there was[/i] a [note]1[/note]great multitude which no one could number, out of [xref]a[/xref]every nation and [i]all[/i] tribes and peoples and tongues, [note]2[/note]standing before the throne and before the [xref]b[/xref]Lamb, clothed in [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]white robes and [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]palm branches in their hands.
verse.note: The great multitude consists of the redeemed ones from the nations, throughout all generations. These constitute the church ([link]5:9[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:25[/link]; [link]Acts 15:14[/link], [link]19[/link]).

[i]Standing before the throne[/i] indicates that the great multitude of the redeemed must have been raptured to the heavens, to the presence of God. [i]Standing[/i]...before the Lamb corresponds with [i]stand before the Son of Man[/i] ([link]Luke 21:36[/link]), which clearly indicates the rapture. That this is mentioned immediately after the opening of the sixth seal implies that the rapture of the believers must begin before the sixth seal. The record in [link]vv. 9-17[/link] describes in a general way the scene from the time of the rapture of the believers to their enjoyment in eternity.

Robes (plural) signify the righteousness of the believers' conduct. White indicates that the conduct of the believers is pure and has been approved by God through having been washed in the blood of the Lamb ([link]v. 14[/link]).

Palm branches signify the victory of the saints over tribulation, which they have undergone for the Lord's sake ([link]v. 14[/link]; cf. [link]John 12:13[/link]). Palm trees are also a sign of satisfaction gained through being watered ([link]Exo. 15:27[/link]). Palm branches were used for the Feast of Tabernacles, in which the people of God rejoiced because of the satisfaction of their enjoyment ([link]Lev. 23:40[/link]; [link]Neh. 8:15[/link]). The Feast of Tabernacles was a type that will be fulfilled by this great multitude of God's redeemed enjoying the eternal Feast of Tabernacles. In the temple of God this multitude will flourish like the palm tree ([link]Psa. 92:12-13[/link]).

verse.text: And they cry with a loud voice, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Salvation to our God who sits upon the throne and to the [xref]b[/xref]Lamb.
verse.note: The loud praise in which only salvation is mentioned indicates that the praisers are the saved ones. The great multitude, those who are saved, are grateful for God's salvation.

verse.text: And all the angels stood around the throne and the [xref]a[/xref]elders and the [xref]b[/xref]four living creatures; and they fell on their faces before the throne and worshipped God,

Saying, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Amen. The [xref]b[/xref]blessing and the [xref]c[/xref]glory and the wisdom and the [xref]d[/xref]thanks and the honor and the power and the strength be to our God forever and ever. Amen.
verse.note: This is similar to the word in [link]Luke 15:7[/link], which says that there is joy in heaven over one sinner who repents. Here the angels say Amen to the redeemed ones' praise of salvation.

verse.text: And one of the elders answered, saying to me, These who are clothed in the white robes, who are they, and where did they come from?

And I said to him, My lord, you know. And he said to me, These are those who come out of the [note]1[/note]great [xref]a[/xref]tribulation, and they have [xref]b[/xref]washed their robes and made them [xref]c[/xref]white in the [xref]d[/xref]blood of the [xref]e[/xref]Lamb.
verse.note: The great tribulation here is different from the great tribulation mentioned in [link]Matt. 24:21[/link]. The great tribulation here refers to the tribulations, sufferings, persecutions, and afflictions experienced by God's redeemed people throughout the ages.

verse.text: Because of this [note]1[/note]they are before the throne of God and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]serve Him day and night in His [xref]b[/xref]temple; and He who sits upon the throne [note]3[/note]will [xref]c[/xref]tabernacle over them.
verse.note: What is depicted in [link]vv. 15-17[/link], similar to what is depicted in [link]21:3-4[/link] and [link]22:3-5[/link], is a portrait of eternity.

This great multitude of redeemed ones has come out of the great tribulation into a heavenly state, into the temple of God, where they serve Him day and night. Their service to God is the issue of God's salvation.

Christ is the tabernacle of God ([link]John 1:14[/link]), and the New Jerusalem, as the ultimate enlargement of Christ, will be God's eternal tabernacle ([link]21:2-3[/link]), in which all God's redeemed ones will dwell with Him forever. God will overshadow them with Himself as the One who is embodied in Christ. Christ, as the embodiment of God, will be their tabernacle. The record in [link]vv. 15-17[/link] very much resembles that in [link]21:3-7[/link].

verse.text: They will not [xref]a[/xref]hunger any more, neither will they [xref]b[/xref]thirst any more, neither will the [xref]c[/xref]sun [note]1[/note]beat upon them, nor any heat;
verse.note: Lit., fall.

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]Lamb who is in the midst of the throne will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]shepherd them and [xref]c[/xref]guide them to [xref]d[/xref]springs of [note]2[/note][xref]e[/xref]waters of life; and God will [xref]f[/xref]wipe away every [note]2[/note]tear from their eyes.
verse.note: Shepherding includes feeding. Under the shepherding of Christ, "I shall not want" ([link]Psa. 23:1[/link], KJV).

The tear in the eyes of the saved ones is a sign of their dissatisfaction. The waters of life are for their satisfaction. Because the Lamb will supply them with waters of life for their satisfaction, they will have no tears of dissatisfaction. The waters of life will be supplied, and the water of tears will be wiped away.

verse.text: And when He opened the seventh seal, there was [xref]a[/xref]silence in [note]1[/note]heaven for about half an hour.
verse.note: Silence in heaven indicates solemnity. At the opening of the seventh seal, all heaven becomes silent because the age is about to be changed from the age of God's toleration to the age of God's wrath.

verse.text: And I saw the [xref]a[/xref]seven angels who stand before God, and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]seven trumpets were given to them.
verse.note: The seventh seal brings in the seven trumpets, which are the contents of the seventh seal. The seven seals are opened secretly, whereas the seven trumpets are sounded openly.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]another Angel came and stood at the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]altar, having a [note]3[/note]golden [xref]c[/xref]censer, and much [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]incense was given to Him to [note]5[/note]offer with the [xref]e[/xref]prayers of all the [note]6[/note]saints upon the [note]7[/note][xref]f[/xref]golden altar which was before the throne.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].
The altar of burnt offering (cf. [link]Exo. 27:1-8[/link]).
The golden censer signifies the prayers of the saints ([link]5:8[/link]), which are brought to God by Christ as "another Angel."
Incense signifies Christ with all His merit to be added to the prayers of the saints that the saints' prayers offered upon the golden altar might be acceptable to God.
Lit., give.
At the opening of the seventh seal, there still will be saints praying on the earth.
The golden altar is the incense altar (cf. [link]Exo. 30:1-9[/link]).

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]smoke of the [note]2[/note]incense went up with the [xref]b[/xref]prayers of the saints out of the hand of the Angel before God.
verse.note: The smoke of the incense indicates that the incense is burned and ascends to God with the prayers of the saints. This implies that the prayers of the saints become effective and are acceptable to God.
Lit., incenses.

verse.text: And the Angel took the censer and [note]1[/note]filled it with the [xref]a[/xref]fire of the altar and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]cast [i]it[/i] to the earth; and there were [xref]c[/xref]thunders and voices and lightnings and an [xref]d[/xref]earthquake.
verse.note: The implication here is that this is the answer to the prayers of the saints, especially the prayer in the fifth seal, mentioned in [link]6:9-11[/link], and the prayer mentioned in [link]Luke 18:7-8[/link]. The prayer of the saints in this chapter must be for the judgment of the earth, which opposes God's economy. The answer to the saints' prayers is the executing of God's judgment upon the earth through the succeeding seven trumpets.
To cast fire to the earth is to execute God's judgment upon the earth. Therefore, the thunders, voices, lightnings, and an earthquake came as signs of God's judgment.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]seven angels who had the seven trumpets prepared themselves [note]1[/note]to trumpet.
verse.note: The seven trumpets were given to the seven angels ([link]v. 2[/link]). But it is after the prayers of the saints ([link]vv. 3-5[/link]) are answered that the seven angels are prepared to trumpet. For God's will in heaven to be carried out on earth, the saints' prayer is required.

verse.text: And the first trumpeted, and there was [xref]a[/xref]hail and [xref]b[/xref]fire mingled with blood, and it was cast to the earth; and the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]third part of the [xref]d[/xref]earth was burned up, and the third part of the trees were burned up, and all green grass was burned up.
verse.note: [i]The third part of the earth[/i] refers probably to certain regions of the earth that are most evil and sinful.

verse.text: And the second angel trumpeted, and as it were a great [xref]a[/xref]mountain burning with fire was cast into the sea; and the third part of the [note]1[/note]sea became [xref]b[/xref]blood,
verse.note: Referring probably to the sea that adjoins the regions that commit evil against God. This part of the sea also will be damaged by God's judgment.

verse.text: And the third part of the creatures which were in the sea [i]and[/i] had [note]1[/note]life died, and the third part of the ships were destroyed.
verse.note: Lit., souls.

verse.text: And the third angel trumpeted, and a great [xref]a[/xref]star fell out of heaven, burning like a torch, and it fell upon the third part of the rivers and upon the [xref]b[/xref]springs of waters.

And the name of the star is called [note]1[/note]Wormwood; and the [note]2[/note]third part of the waters became [xref]a[/xref]wormwood, and many of the men died from the waters because they were made bitter.
verse.note: A bitter plant.

Today those who oppose God and those who practice evil against Him still enjoy God's creation. Because of man's evil opposition against God, the water of God's creation, which is crucial to human life, will probably be damaged in a limited way by God's judgment.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]fourth angel trumpeted, and the [note]2[/note]third part of the [xref]a[/xref]sun and the third part of the moon and the third part of the stars were smitten, so that the third part of them would be [xref]b[/xref]darkened and the day would not appear for the third part of it, and the night likewise.
verse.note: The first four trumpets, which are not yet the direct judgment on men, form one group, like the first four seals. The first trumpet is a judgment on the earth, including the trees and all the grass, as occurred in Egypt ([link]Exo. 9:18-25[/link]); the second, a judgment on the sea, including the living creatures and ships; the third, a judgment on the rivers and springs of waters, as occurred in Egypt ([link]Exo. 7:17-21[/link]); the fourth, a judgment on the sun, the moon, and the stars that they may be darkened, as also occurred in Egypt ([link]Exo. 10:21-23[/link]). By the judgments of these four trumpets, the third part of the earth, the sea, the rivers, and the hosts in the heavens are damaged and are thus caused to be no longer good for man's living. At the sixth seal, before the seven trumpets, there was already a judgment on the earth and on the hosts of the heavens ([link]6:12-14[/link]). The extent of the damage caused by that judgment was not as definite as the extent of the damage caused by the first four trumpets. At the seventh trumpet, through the seven bowls there will be further judgments on the earth, the sea, the rivers, and the sun ([link]16:1-21[/link]). Those will be God's most severe judgments on the earth and heaven.
Referring probably to that part of the sun that shines upon the evil regions of the earth (cf. [link]Matt. 5:45[/link]). God knows which part this is, and it will be damaged by God's judgment.

verse.text: And I saw, and I heard an [xref]a[/xref]eagle flying in [xref]b[/xref]mid-heaven, saying with a loud voice, [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Woe, woe, woe, to those who [xref]d[/xref]dwell on the earth because of the remaining trumpet sounds of the [xref]e[/xref]three angels who are about to trumpet!
verse.note: The last three trumpets will be the last three woes ([link]9:12[/link]; [link]11:14[/link]) of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]), which will occur in the last half of the seventieth week ([link]Dan. 9:27[/link]), a period of three and a half years ([link]Dan. 7:25[/link]; [link]12:7[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:14[/link]), that is, forty-two months ([link]11:2[/link]; [link]13:5[/link]), or twelve hundred and sixty days ([link]11:3[/link]; [link]12:6[/link]).

verse.text: And the fifth angel trumpeted, and I saw a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]star out of heaven [xref]b[/xref]fallen to the earth, and to him was given the [xref]c[/xref]key of the pit of the [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]abyss.
verse.note: The star here refers to Satan, who will be cast down from heaven to earth. The angels are likened to stars ([link]Job 38:7[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:4[/link]). Satan, as the archangel, was the Daystar ([link]Isa. 14:12[/link]). In [link]Luke 10:18[/link] the judgment upon him was mentioned. Here, and in [link]12:9-10[/link], is the execution of that judgment.
The abyss is the dwelling place of the demons ([link]Luke 8:31[/link]).

verse.text: And he opened the pit of the abyss, and [xref]a[/xref]smoke went up out of the pit like the smoke of a great furnace; and the [xref]b[/xref]sun and the air were darkened by the smoke of the pit.
And out of the smoke came forth [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]locusts to the earth, and to them [note]2[/note]power was given, as the [xref]b[/xref]scorpions of the earth have [note]2[/note]power.
verse.note: The locusts here are not like the locusts in [link]Exo. 10:12-15[/link], in that these have tails like scorpions, and stings, and they harm men ([link]v. 10[/link]). They must be demon-possessed, because they come out of the smoke that issues from the pit of the abyss, the dwelling place of the demons ([link]v. 2[/link]).
Lit., authority. So in [link]vv. 10[/link], [link]19[/link].

verse.text: And it was said to them that they should not harm the grass of the earth or any green thing or any tree, but [note]1[/note]men who do not have the [xref]a[/xref]seal of God on their foreheads.
verse.note: The plagues of the first four trumpets are not directly upon man, whereas the woes of the last three trumpets are. Only the Israelites who have the seal of God on their foreheads will not be harmed by the demon-possessed locusts ([link]7:3-8[/link]).

verse.text: And it was given them that they should not kill them, but that they should be tormented [xref]a[/xref]five months; and their torment was like the torment of a scorpion when it strikes a man.
And in those days men will [xref]a[/xref]seek death and shall by no means find it; and they will long to die, and death flees from them.

And [note]1[/note]the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]locusts were like horses prepared for [xref]b[/xref]war, and on their heads [i]there were[/i] as it were crowns like gold, and their faces were like faces of men.
verse.note: Lit., the likenesses of the locusts were like.

[link]Verses 7[/link] through [link]9[/link] are very similar to [link]Joel 2:4-5[/link], [link]25[/link], and [link]1:6[/link], which are words spoken concerning Israel. This, along with the fact that the Israelites need to be sealed by God ([link]7:3-8[/link]) to escape the harm of the locusts, may indicate that the woe of the fifth trumpet will come especially upon the Israelites.

verse.text: And they had hair like the hair of women, and their [xref]a[/xref]teeth were like [i]the teeth[/i] of lions.
And they had breastplates like breastplates of iron; and the [xref]a[/xref]sound of their wings was like the sound of chariots of many horses rushing into war.
And they have [xref]a[/xref]tails like scorpions, and stings; and in their tails is their power to harm men for [xref]b[/xref]five months.
They have a [xref]a[/xref]king over them, the [note]1[/note]angel of the [xref]b[/xref]abyss; his name in Hebrew is [note]2[/note]Abaddon; and in Greek he has the name [note]3[/note]Apollyon.
