verse.note: The angel of the abyss is the beast, Antichrist, who will come out of the pit of the abyss ([link]11:7[/link]; [link]17:8[/link]).
The Hebrew word means [i]destruction;[/i] it is used also in [link]Job 26:6[/link]; [link]28:22[/link]; [link]Prov. 15:11[/link].
The Greek word means [i]destroyer.[/i] As the destroyer, Antichrist will do much destroying ([link]Dan. 8:23-25[/link]).

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]first woe has passed; behold, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]two woes are yet coming after these things.
verse.note: In the first woe, the woe of the fifth trumpet, Satan falls from heaven to earth and Antichrist comes up from the abyss, and the two work together to torment man. Since it is at the fifth trumpet that Satan falls from heaven to damage the earth and persecute the people of God for three and a half years ([link]12:10[/link], [link]12-17[/link], [link]6[/link]); and since it is at the same time (the last three and a half years) that Antichrist comes up out of the abyss to collaborate with Satan to torment people, persecute the saints, and blaspheme God ([link]13:5-7[/link]; [link]11:7[/link]); and since it is in the same three and a half years that the holy city, Jerusalem, is given over to the Gentiles for destruction ([link]11:2[/link]), the woe of the fifth trumpet must be the beginning of the most severe woes of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]; see note [link]2[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]). The second woe, the woe of the sixth trumpet, and the third woe, the woe of the seventh trumpet ([link]8:13[/link]; [link]9:12[/link]; [link]11:14[/link]), must also be two parts of the most severe woes of the great tribulation. These three woes, with the damage from the sixth seal and the first four trumpets, will be a trial upon all those who dwell on the earth ([link]3:10[/link]).
The two woes are the sixth trumpet itself and the woe of the seventh trumpet ([link]vv. 13-21[/link]; [link]11:14-15[/link]), that is, the seven bowls ([link]ch. 16[/link]).

verse.text: And the sixth angel trumpeted, and I heard a voice out of the four horns of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]golden altar which is before God
verse.note: The blood of expiation was put on the four horns of the golden altar, the incense altar, for expiation ([link]Exo. 30:10[/link]), i.e., for redemption. The voice that comes out of the four horns of the golden altar indicates that God's judgment on man is based on the redemption of Christ; i.e., it comes because men do not believe in Christ's redemption.

verse.text: Saying to the sixth angel who had the trumpet, Release the four angels who are bound at the great river [xref]a[/xref]Euphrates.
And the four angels were released, who had been prepared [note]1[/note]for the hour and day and month and year that they might kill the [xref]a[/xref]third part of men.
verse.note: [i]For the hour and day and month and year[/i] indicates that the four angels had been prepared unto the hour, plus the day, plus the month, and plus the year — altogether thirteen months, one day, and one hour — for the killing of men. The killing will last first one hour, then one day, then one month, and finally one year.

verse.text: And the number of the armies of [note]1[/note]horsemen was two hundred million; I heard their number.
verse.note: The two hundred million horsemen from the rising of the sun will join the war at Armageddon ([link]16:12-16[/link]; [link]19:17-21[/link]).

verse.text: And thus I saw the horses in the vision and those sitting on them, having breastplates of [xref]a[/xref]fire and of hyacinth and of [xref]b[/xref]brimstone; and the heads of the horses were like the heads of lions, and out of their mouths proceed fire and [xref]c[/xref]smoke and brimstone.
By these three [xref]a[/xref]plagues the third part of the men were killed, by the fire and the smoke and the brimstone proceeding out of their mouths.
For the power of the horses is in their mouth and in their [xref]a[/xref]tails; for their tails are like [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]serpents and have heads, and with them they harm [i]men.[/i]
verse.note: The horses' tails here, which are like serpents, are more poisonous than the locusts' tails, which are like scorpions ([link]v. 10[/link]). The locusts only torment men for five months ([link]vv. 5[/link], [link]10[/link]), whereas the horses kill the third part of men ([link]vv. 15[/link], [link]18[/link]). This means that the woe of the sixth trumpet is more severe than that of the fifth.

verse.text: And the rest of the men, who were not killed by these plagues, still did [xref]a[/xref]not [note]1[/note]repent of the [xref]b[/xref]works of their hands, so as not to [xref]c[/xref]worship the demons and the [xref]d[/xref]idols of gold and silver and brass and stone and wood, which can [note]2[/note]neither see nor hear nor walk;
verse.note: The goal of God's judgment is that men would repent.
In contrast to [link]Psa. 115:5[/link]; [link]135:16[/link], this verse does not say that the idols cannot speak, because the image of Antichrist does speak ([link]13:15[/link]).

verse.text: And they did [xref]a[/xref]not repent of their murders or of their [xref]b[/xref]sorceries or of their [xref]c[/xref]fornication or of their thefts.

[note]1[/note]And I saw [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]another strong Angel [xref]b[/xref]coming down out of heaven, clothed with a [xref]c[/xref]cloud; and the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]rainbow was upon His head, and His [xref]e[/xref]face was like the [note]4[/note]sun, and His [xref]f[/xref]feet like [note]5[/note]pillars of [note]6[/note]fire;
verse.note: The section from [link]10:1-11:13[/link] is an insertion between the sixth and seventh trumpets.

"Another strong Angel" here, as well as the One in [link]7:2[/link], [link]8:3[/link], and [link]18:1[/link], is Christ. At this point He is coming down out of heaven. This vision, part of the insertion between the sixth and seventh trumpets, is a hint that before the seventh trumpet, Christ is on the way to earth. At this time He is clothed with a cloud and is not yet on the cloud, in contrast to [link]14:14[/link] and [link]Matt. 24:30[/link]; [link]26:64[/link]. To be on the cloud is to come openly, whereas to be clothed with a cloud is to come secretly. This indicates that even after the sixth trumpet, Christ still is coming secretly, not openly. He will come secretly until He is seen by all the tribes of the earth, as mentioned in [link]1:7[/link] and [link]Matt. 24:30[/link], at which time He will come openly.

The rainbow here indicates that Christ in His judgment upon the earth will keep the covenant that God made with Noah concerning the earth ([link]Gen. 9:8-17[/link]). It indicates also that Christ will execute judgment according to the God who sits on the throne with the rainbow around it ([link]4:2-3[/link]), the faithful and covenant-keeping God.

Near the time of His coming to the people on the earth openly, Christ will be like the sun, not like the morning star, which appears before the darkest time, prior to dawn, to those who love Him and wait for Him (see [link]2:28[/link] and note 1; [link]2 Pet. 1:19[/link] and note 4).
Pillars here indicate steadfastness ([link]Jer. 1:18[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:9[/link]).
Fire here signifies the holiness of God ([link]Exo. 19:18[/link]; [link]Heb. 12:29[/link]), according to which Christ will execute His judgment upon the earth.

verse.text: And He had in His hand a [note]1[/note]little opened [xref]a[/xref]scroll. And He placed His [note]2[/note]right foot on the sea and the left on the land;
verse.note: This little opened scroll is the scroll in [link]5:1[/link], which only Christ is worthy to open and which He took out of the hand of God ([link]5:5[/link], [link]7[/link]). Now it is in His hand. In [link]5:1[/link] it was sealed; here it is open. Being only a part of the scroll, it is called here "a little... scroll." The main part of the scroll has already been revealed.

Christ's placing His feet on the sea and on the land is His treading on them, and to tread on them is to take possession of them ([link]Deut. 11:24[/link]; [link]Josh. 1:3[/link]; [link]Psa. 8:6-8[/link]). This indicates that Christ is coming down to take possession of the earth. Only He is worthy to open the scroll of God's economy, and only He is qualified to possess the earth.

verse.text: And He cried out with a loud voice just as a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lion [xref]b[/xref]roars. And when He cried out, the [note]2[/note]seven [xref]c[/xref]thunders uttered their own voices.
verse.note: A lion's roaring is likened to a king's wrath ([link]Prov. 19:12[/link]; [link]20:2[/link]). This indicates that Christ, as the King of the earth, is provoked to wrath.
The seven thunders must be the ultimate utterances of God's full wrath.

verse.text: And when the seven thunders spoke, I was about to write, and I heard a [xref]a[/xref]voice out of heaven saying, [xref]b[/xref]Seal the things which the seven thunders spoke, and do not write them.
And the Angel whom I saw [xref]a[/xref]standing on the sea and on the land [xref]b[/xref]lifted up His right hand to heaven

And [note]1[/note]swore by Him who [xref]a[/xref]lives forever and ever, who [xref]b[/xref]created heaven and the [note]2[/note]things in it, and the earth and the [note]3[/note]things in it, and the sea and the [note]4[/note]things in it, that there shall be [note]5[/note][xref]c[/xref]delay no longer,
verse.note: To swear is the practice of the Old Testament, not of the New ([link]Matt. 5:34-36[/link]).
The main item of the things in heaven is the angels.
The main item of the things in the earth is men.
The main item of the things in the sea is the demons.

Lit., space of time. After the sixth trumpet, there will be no more time of toleration in God's judgment upon the earth. Hence, the seventh trumpet is the most serious of God's judgments. It is God's answer in full to the martyred saints' prayer in [link]6:10[/link].

verse.text: But in the [note]1[/note]days of the voice of the [xref]a[/xref]seventh angel when he is about to trumpet, then the [note]2[/note]mystery of God [note]3[/note]is [note]4[/note]finished, as He has [xref]b[/xref]announced the [note]5[/note]good news to His own slaves the prophets.
verse.note: The trumpeting voice of the seventh trumpet will last a period of days.

In the dispensations from Adam to Moses and from Moses to Christ, everything was unveiled, manifested, and there was no mystery. It will be the same in the dispensation of the millennial kingdom and in the new heaven and new earth — everything will be unveiled and there will be no more mystery. But in the dispensation from Christ to the millennial kingdom, everything is a mystery. The incarnation of Christ, as the beginning of this dispensation of mystery, is a mystery ([link]1 Tim. 3:16[/link]). Christ Himself ([link]Col. 2:2[/link]), the church ([link]Eph. 3:4-6[/link]), the kingdom of the heavens ([link]Matt. 13:11[/link]), the gospel ([link]Eph. 6:19[/link]), the indwelling of Christ ([link]Col. 1:26-27[/link]), and the coming resurrection and transfiguration of the saints as the end of this dispensation of mystery ([link]1 Cor. 15:51-52[/link]) are all mysteries that were hidden in the times of the ages ([link]Rom. 16:25[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:5[/link]; [link]Col. 1:26[/link]). All these mysteries will be completed, finished, and will be over at the trumpeting of the seventh trumpet.
At the trumpeting of the seventh trumpet, not only God's judgment of wrath upon the earth but also the mystery of God are finished.
Or, completed.

In the seventh trumpet the good news that God announced to His own slaves the prophets, as in [link]Isa. 2:2-4[/link]; [link]11:1-10[/link]; [link]65:17-20[/link]; [link]66:22[/link], will be fulfilled; that is, the kingdom in its manifestation will come ([link]11:15[/link]), and the new heaven and new earth with the New Jerusalem will follow ([link]21:1-3[/link]).

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]voice which I heard out of heaven, I heard again speaking with me and saying, Go, take the opened [xref]b[/xref]scroll in the hand of the Angel who is [xref]c[/xref]standing on the sea and on the land.

And I went to the Angel and told Him to give me the little scroll. And He said to me, Take [i]it[/i] and [xref]a[/xref]devour it, and it will make your stomach bitter, but in your mouth it will be as [xref]b[/xref]sweet as honey.
And I took the little scroll out of the hand of the Angel and [note]1[/note]devoured it, and it was as [note]2[/note]sweet as honey in my mouth; and when I had eaten it, my stomach became bitter.
verse.note: The writer of this book not only received but also devoured the scroll. To devour anything is to receive it into one's being. We must receive the divine revelation, especially the book of Revelation, in this way. Both Jeremiah and Ezekiel did this ([link]Jer. 15:16[/link]; [link]Ezek. 2:8[/link]; [link]3:1-3[/link]).
When we receive the divine revelation by devouring it, it is sweet as we eat it, but it becomes bitter as we digest it, that is, as we experience it.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]they said to me, You must prophesy [note]2[/note]again over many [xref]a[/xref]peoples and nations and tongues and kings.
verse.note: Referring to the angels.

The prophecy of this book is composed of two sections. From the first seal to the sixth trumpet ([link]chs. 6-10[/link]) is the first section; it is in secret. From the seventh trumpet to the new heaven and new earth ([link]chs. 11-22[/link]) is the second section; it is openly manifested. John prophesied in the first section. He must prophesy [i]again,[/i] that is, prophesy in the second section of the prophecy of this book, the section that concerns Christ's coming to possess the earth as His kingdom ([link]11:15[/link]). This is the content of the little scroll, the last part of God's economy.

verse.text: And there was given to me a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reed like a [note]1[/note]rod, [i]and someone[/i] said, Rise and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]measure the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]temple of God and the [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]altar and those who [xref]e[/xref]worship in it.
verse.note: A reed, as in [link]21:15[/link] and [link]Ezek. 40:3[/link]; [link]42:16-19[/link], is for measuring, which is for taking possession, whereas a rod implies punishment ([link]Prov. 10:13[/link]; [link]Isa. 10:5[/link]; [link]11:4[/link]). Hence, [i]a reed like a rod[/i] indicates measuring with punishment in order to possess.

I.e., sanctify, preserve, and possess ([link]Num. 35:2[/link], [link]5[/link]; [link]Ezek. 45:1-3[/link]; [link]42:15[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]48:8[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]15[/link]). The measuring of the temple of God and the incense altar in the heavens indicates that during the great tribulation the heavens will be preserved from being damaged, because in that three and a half years Satan will be cast out of heaven and down to earth.
The Greek word refers to the inner temple.
The altar here is the golden altar of incense, because it is with the temple; it is not the bronze altar of sacrifice in the court that is outside the temple ([link]v. 2[/link]).

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]court which is outside the [note]2[/note]temple cast out and do not measure it, because it has been given to the [xref]b[/xref]Gentiles, and they will trample the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]holy city for [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]forty-two months.
verse.note: The court is on earth. The earthly temple and Jerusalem on earth will be given over to be trampled by Antichrist and the Gentiles.
See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup][/link].
The holy city here is the earthly Jerusalem ([link]Isa. 52:1[/link]; [link]Matt. 27:53[/link]).

At the end of this age Antichrist will make a firm covenant with the Jews for one week (seven years), which will be the last week of the seventy weeks that God appointed for the Jewish nation in [link]Dan. 9:24-27[/link]. In the middle of the last week (that is, after the first half of the seven years) Antichrist will break the covenant and destroy the worship of God ([link]Dan. 9:27[/link]). Then he will blaspheme God and persecute His people for three and a half years ([link]13:5-7[/link]; [link]Dan. 7:25[/link]; [link]12:7[/link]), which is the forty-two months mentioned here and the last half of the last week in [link]Dan. 9:27[/link], during which Antichrist will also destroy the holy city, Jerusalem. According to [link]Matt. 24:15[/link] and [link]21[/link], these last three and a half years must be the time of the great tribulation, which comes as a trial on the inhabitants of the earth ([link]3:10[/link]).

verse.text: And I will [note]1[/note]cause My [note]2[/note]two [xref]a[/xref]witnesses to prophesy a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]thousand two hundred and sixty days, clothed in [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]sackcloth.
verse.note: Lit., give.

Two witnesses give an adequate testimony ([link]Deut. 17:6[/link]; [link]19:15[/link]; [link]Matt. 18:16[/link]). The two witnesses here are Moses and Elijah. What they do in [link]vv. 5-6[/link] is the same as what Moses and Elijah did ([link]Exo. 7:17[/link], [link]19[/link]; [link]9:14[/link]; [link]11:1[/link]; [link]2 Kings 1:10-12[/link]; [link]1 Kings 17:1[/link]). Moses and Elijah appeared before the Lord on the mount of transfiguration ([link]Matt. 17:1-3[/link]). Moses, representing the law, and Elijah, representing the prophets ([link]Luke 16:16[/link]), both testified for God. Elijah's mission was predicted ([link]Mal. 4:5[/link]; [link]Matt. 17:11[/link]). They are the two olive trees, the two sons of oil, in [link]Zech. 4:3[/link], [link]11-14[/link] (see note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in Matt. 25[/link]).

This is the forty-two months mentioned in [link]v. 2[/link], the period of time during which Antichrist will blaspheme God ([link]13:5-6[/link]) and persecute His people ([link]12:6[/link], [link]14[/link]). Under Antichrist's evil power and persecution, the two witnesses will prophesy, speak for God, and testify against the evildoings of Antichrist.

Sackcloth is a symbol of mourning ([link]2 Sam. 3:31[/link]). The two witnesses will wear funeral clothes as a warning to the inhabitants of the earth, telling them to stay away from the worship of Antichrist that they may escape God's judgment.

verse.text: These are the [xref]a[/xref]two [note]1[/note]olive trees and the two [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]lampstands which stand before the [xref]c[/xref]Lord of the earth.
verse.note: The olive trees produce oil for the lamps. Oil signifies the Holy Spirit. In [link]Zech. 4:14[/link] the two witnesses here are called "the two sons of oil," indicating that they are full of the Holy Spirit.

The lampstands give light by means of the oil of the olive trees. In the church age, the churches are the lampstands for God's testimony ([link]1:20[/link]), whereas in the last three and a half years of this age, the two witnesses will be the lampstands for God's testimony.

verse.text: And if anyone desires to harm them, [xref]a[/xref]fire proceeds out of their mouth and devours their enemies. And if anyone desires to harm them, thus must he be killed.

These have the authority to [xref]a[/xref]shut heaven that no [xref]b[/xref]rain may fall during the days of their prophecy; and they have authority over the waters to turn them into [xref]c[/xref]blood and to smite the earth with every [xref]d[/xref]plague as often as they desire.

And when they have completed their [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]testimony, the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]beast who comes up out of the [xref]c[/xref]abyss will make [xref]d[/xref]war with them and will overcome them and kill them.
verse.note: During the great tribulation the two witnesses will give an adequate testimony for God ([link]v. 4[/link]) and against Antichrist.

The beast here is Antichrist, who will come up out of the abyss ([link]17:8[/link]) and out of the sea ([link]13:1[/link]) and who will make war with the two witnesses and with the saints ([link]13:7[/link]).

verse.text: And their corpses will be on the street of the [note]1[/note]great [xref]a[/xref]city, which spiritually is called [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Sodom and [xref]c[/xref]Egypt, [xref]d[/xref]where also their Lord was crucified.
verse.note: The great city is the holy city mentioned in [link]v. 2[/link], the earthly Jerusalem.

After the restoration of the nation of Israel in 1948, the Jews who returned to their fathers' land were still in unbelief. They will be as sinful as Sodom (cf. [link]Isa. 1:9-10[/link]; [link]3:9[/link]; [link]Jer. 23:14[/link]) and as worldly as Egypt (cf. [link]Ezek. 23:3[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]27[/link]) until the return of Christ, their Messiah, at which time all Israel will be saved ([link]Rom. 11:26[/link]).

verse.text: And those of the [xref]a[/xref]peoples and tribes and tongues and nations see their corpses for three and a half days, and they do not allow their [xref]b[/xref]corpses to be placed in a tomb.
And those who [xref]a[/xref]dwell on the earth rejoice over them and make merry; and they will send gifts to one another because these two prophets tormented those who dwell on the earth.

And after the [note]1[/note]three and a half days, the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]breath of life out of God entered into them, and they [note]3[/note]stood on their feet; and great fear fell upon those beholding them.
verse.note: The three and a half days must be included in the one thousand two hundred and sixty days in which they prophesy and bear testimony for the Lord; otherwise, those days would extend beyond the great tribulation.
Or, Spirit of life.
That they stood on their feet indicates that they had been resurrected. Their resurrection is separate from the one predicted in [link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link].

verse.text: And they heard a loud voice out of heaven saying to them, Come up here. And they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]went up into heaven in the cloud, and their enemies beheld them.
verse.note: Indicating that they are raptured. Their being killed, resurrected, and raptured are a part of their testimony and must all be within the one thousand two hundred and sixty days of their ministry. Thus, their rapture must take place on the last day of their ministry, which is also the last day of the great tribulation. It will be on the same day as the rapture predicted in [link]1 Thes. 4:17[/link], and it may even be at the same time, or it may be later.

verse.text: And in that hour there was a great [xref]a[/xref]earthquake, and the tenth part of the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]city fell; and seven thousand [note]2[/note]men were killed in the earthquake, and the rest became terrified and gave [xref]c[/xref]glory to the [xref]d[/xref]God of heaven.
verse.note: The city here is the great city in [link]v. 8[/link], Jerusalem. A tenth part of the city of Jerusalem fell because of the earthquake mentioned in this verse. In the last earthquake the city will be divided into three parts, as mentioned in [link]16:19[/link].
Lit., names of men; implying people of renown.

verse.text: The second [xref]a[/xref]woe has passed; behold, the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]third woe is coming quickly.
verse.note: The third woe is a part of the negative contents of the seventh trumpet (see note [link]15[sup]1[/sup][/link]), which consists of the seven bowls of God's wrath ([link]ch. 16[/link]). Since the trumpeting of the seventh trumpet is recorded after the vision concerning the destruction of Jerusalem during the last three and a half years ([link]v. 2[/link]), and since the seven bowls are the last plagues at the consummation of God's wrath ([link]15:1[/link]; [link]16:1[/link]), the woe of the seventh trumpet must mark the end of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]). See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link] and note [link chapter="11"]2[sup]4[/sup][/link] in this chapter.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seventh angel [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]trumpeted; and there were loud [xref]c[/xref]voices in heaven, saying, The [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]kingdom of the world has become the [xref]e[/xref][i]kingdom[/i] of our Lord and of [xref]f[/xref]His Christ, and He will [note]4[/note][xref]g[/xref]reign forever and ever.
verse.note: The seventh trumpet, the last one ([link]1 Cor. 15:52[/link]), has two aspects, the negative and the positive.[br][br]The negative aspect includes (1) the last plagues, the plagues of the seven bowls, in which the wrath of God is finished ([link]15:1[/link]; [link]16:1-21[/link]), as the last woe to those who dwell on the earth ([link]8:13[/link]; [link]9:12[/link]; [link]11:14[/link]) — [link]v. 18[/link]; and (2) the destruction of the destroyers of the earth immediately upon the Lord's coming back to the earth ([link]17:14[/link]; [link]18:1-2[/link]; [link]19:19-20:3[/link]) — [link]v. 18[/link].[br][br]The positive aspect includes (1) the coming of the eternal kingdom of Christ, which is the kingdom in its manifestation — [link]vv. 15[/link], [link]17[/link]; (2) the judgment of the dead (see note [link]18[sup]2[/sup][/link]) before the resurrection of the saints — [link]v. 18[/link]; and (3) the giving of the reward, at the judgment seat of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]), to the prophets and the saints after the resurrection and rapture of the saints ([link]1 Cor. 15:23[/link], [link]52[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:16-17[/link]), and the giving of the reward, at the throne of God's glory ([link]Matt. 25:31-34[/link]), to those who fear God's name ([link]14:6-7[/link]) — [link]v. 18[/link].[br][br]Hence, the seventh trumpet comprises all the things from the end of the great tribulation to eternity future, such as the last plagues, i.e., the seven bowls ([link]ch. 16[/link]); the resurrection and rapture of the saints (including the two witnesses); the rewarding of the saints; the marriage of the Lamb ([link]19:7-9[/link]); the coming back of Christ to the earth; the destruction of Antichrist, the false prophet, their followers, the material Babylon the Great, and Satan ([link]18:1-19:4[/link]; [link]19:11-20:3[/link]); the reigning in the millennial kingdom ([link]20:4-6[/link]); the final judgment upon the earth and Satan ([link]20:7-10[/link]); the final judgment of the dead ([link]20:11-15[/link]); and the ultimate consummation in the new heaven and new earth with the New Jerusalem for eternity ([link]21:1-22:5[/link]).

At the sounding of the seventh trumpet, not only will the great tribulation end, but also this age will close, the mystery of God will be finished ([link]10:7[/link]), and another age, the age of the kingdom, the millennium, will begin.
The kingdom of the world becomes the kingdom of Christ at His coming back after He executes His judgment upon the nations ([link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]; [link]2:44-45[/link]).

Here the Lord's reigning forever and ever is the Lord's reigning in the millennial kingdom and in the new heaven and new earth for eternity ([link]22:5[/link]). This indicates that the seventh trumpet includes the new heaven and new earth with the New Jerusalem.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]twenty-four elders who sit before God on their thrones fell on their faces and worshipped God,
Saying, We thank You, [xref]a[/xref]Lord God the Almighty, He who is and who was, because You have taken Your great [xref]b[/xref]power and have reigned.

And the [xref]a[/xref]nations became angry, and Your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]wrath came, and the time came for the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]dead to be judged, and [i]the time[/i] to give the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]reward to Your slaves the prophets and to the saints and to those who [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]fear Your name, to the small and to the great, and to destroy [note]5[/note]those who destroy the earth.
verse.note: The wrath here refers to the wrath contained in the seven bowls in [link]ch. 16[/link], which are a part of the negative contents of the seventh trumpet.

Since [i]for the dead to be judged[/i] is mentioned before [i]to give the reward to Your slaves[/i]..., the former must not refer to the judgment of the dead at the great white throne after the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]). Rather, it refers to the fact that at the close of this age, before the millennium, according to [link]John 5:27-29[/link], the dead will be judged concerning who should share in the resurrection of life before the millennium ([link]1 Cor. 15:23[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4-6[/link]) and who should be left to the resurrection of condemnation after the millennium ([link]Rev. 20:11-12[/link]).

The reward will be given by the Lord to His faithful ones at His coming back ([link]22:12[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:27[/link]). After the resurrection and rapture of the saints ([link]1 Cor. 15:23[/link], [link]52[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:16-17[/link]), Christ at His judgment seat will judge the prophets and the saints ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]) to determine who among the saved persons is worthy of a reward and who needs further discipline.

Those who fear God's name are the "sheep" mentioned in [link]Matt. 25:33-40[/link]. They are those who will heed the eternal gospel, fearing God and worshipping Him and not worshipping Antichrist and his image ([link]14:6-7[/link]). During the great tribulation they will care for the Lord's needy people, His little brothers (the believers who suffer persecution and the Jews who fear God). Hence, they will be transferred into the millennial kingdom to become there the nations on the earth ([link]2:26[/link]; [link]12:5[/link]).

Those who destroy the earth are Babylon the Great ([link]18:2-3[/link]), Antichrist ([link]13:3[/link]), the false prophet ([link]13:14[/link]), and Satan ([link]20:7-10[/link]), and the people who follow them ([link]17:12-14[/link]; [link]19:19[/link]; [link]20:8-9[/link]). All of them will be destroyed in the seventh trumpet.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]temple of God which is in heaven was opened, and the [xref]b[/xref]Ark of His Covenant was seen in His [note]1[/note]temple; and there were [xref]c[/xref]lightnings and voices and thunders and an [note]2[/note]earthquake and great [xref]d[/xref]hail.
verse.note: The Greek word refers to the inner temple. This verse is continued by [link]15:5[/link]. On the negative side, the throne with the rainbow ([link]4:2-3[/link]) is the center of all the judgments executed over the earth in [link]chs. 6-11[/link], whereas, on the positive side, the temple with the Ark is the center of all God's accomplishments in the universe carried out in [link]chs. 12-22[/link].

Four earthquakes are predicted in this book. The first, in [link]6:12[/link], occurs at the time of the sixth seal; the second, in [link]8:5[/link], before the seven trumpets; the third, in [link]11:13[/link], at the time of the rapture of the two witnesses, which should be on the day of the beginning of the seventh trumpet, before the pouring out of the seven bowls; and the fourth, in this verse, still at the time of the seventh trumpet, that is, in [link]16:17-20[/link], at the time of the seventh bowl, which constitutes the most severe calamity of the negative contents of the seventh trumpet.

verse.text: And a great [xref]a[/xref]sign was seen in heaven: a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]woman clothed with the [xref]c[/xref]sun, and the moon underneath her feet, and on her head a crown of twelve stars;
verse.note: The first section of this book, composed of the first eleven chapters, covers all things that occur from Christ's ascension to eternity. The second section, composed of the last eleven chapters, gives details of the important things and crucial matters occurring from the last three and a half years of the present age, which will be the period of the great tribulation, to the eternal age of the new heaven and new earth. The first of the important things and crucial matters revealed in this section is a woman who brought forth a man-child.[br][br]This woman is "clothed with the sun, and the moon underneath her feet, and on her head a crown of twelve stars." In [link]Gen. 37:9[/link], Joseph in his dream saw the sun, the moon, and the eleven stars, signifying his father, his mother, and his eleven brothers. There the sun, the moon, and the eleven stars, plus Joseph himself, signified the totality of God's people on the earth. Based on the principle of that dream, the sun, the moon, and the twelve stars here must signify the totality of God's people on earth, which is symbolized here by a woman. Most of her being is clothed with the sun. The sun signifies God's people in the New Testament age. Before Christ came to the world, it was the dark night of the Old Testament age. When Christ as the rising sun came from on high ([link]Luke 1:78[/link]), the age of the sun came. Before that, it was the age of the moon, which signifies God's people in the Old Testament time. The moon is underneath the feet of the woman, for the age of the moon was the age of the law, which should not be exalted as the stars are. The stars, which signify the patriarchs, God's people before the law was given, are on her head as a crown. All God's people in these three ages, who together constitute this woman, are light bearers. Hence, she is the bright woman shining throughout all generations.

verse.text: And she was with [note]1[/note]child, and she [note]2[/note]cried out, [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]travailing in birth and being in [xref]b[/xref]pain to bring forth.
verse.note: The child here, being a man-child ([link]v. 5[/link]), signifies the stronger part of God's people. Throughout all generations there are some stronger ones among God's people. These are considered in the Bible a collective unit fighting the battle for God and bringing God's kingdom down to earth.
To cry out here is to pray.

[i]Travailing in birth and being in pain to bring forth[/i] signifies that throughout all generations God's people have been suffering the travail of delivery ([link]Isa. 26:17-18[/link]; [link]Jer. 6:24[/link]; [link]13:21[/link]; [link]30:6[/link]; [link]Micah 4:9-10[/link]; [link]5:3[/link]; [link]Gal. 4:19[/link]) to bring forth the man-child that he may fight for God's kingdom.

verse.text: And another sign was seen in heaven; and behold, [i]there was[/i] a great red [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dragon, having [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]seven heads and ten horns, and on his heads [note]3[/note]seven [xref]c[/xref]diadems.
verse.note: The dragon signifies Satan ([link]v. 9[/link]). In [link]Gen. 3[/link] Satan was a serpent, a smaller creature, a subtle one. Here he has become a dragon, much larger than a serpent and cruel. Hence, he is called "a great red dragon." Red here signifies the shedding of blood caused by Satan's murders ([link]John 8:44[/link]).
The seven heads and ten horns are those of the beast, Antichrist ([link]13:1[/link]). This indicates that the dragon and the beast are one and shows that Antichrist is the embodiment of Satan.

The seven diadems indicate the glory of the seven Caesars' extraordinary kingship. Since each of these seven Caesars was one with Satan, each assumed deity, claimed to be God, and forced the people to worship him as God.

verse.text: And his tail drags away the third part of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]stars of heaven, and he cast them to the earth. And the [note]2[/note]dragon stood before the woman who was about to bring forth, so that when she brings forth he might [xref]b[/xref]devour her child.
verse.note: The stars of heaven here signify the angels ([link]Job 38:7[/link]; [link]Isa. 14:12[/link]). The third part of the stars of heaven must be the fallen angels, who followed Satan in his rebellion against God. Satan drags all of them away, and as the angels of Satan they will be cast to the earth with Satan ([link]v. 9[/link]). Hence, at that time the earth will be filled with these fallen angels, who will damage the dwelling place of the people who rebel against God. The earth will thus become a dreadful place.

That the dragon stood before the woman signifies that Satan is always against the people of God, opposing them. From the time of [link]Gen. 3:15[/link] to this day, Satan, the ancient serpent, has been fighting continually against the woman with the intention of devouring her child.

verse.text: And she [note]1[/note]brought forth a son, a [note]2[/note]man-child, who is to [xref]a[/xref]shepherd all the nations with an iron rod; and her child was [note]3[/note]caught up to God and to His throne.
verse.note: [i]Brought forth[/i] here signifies resurrection, as in [link]Acts 13:33-34[/link]. The man-child is composed of the overcoming saints who have died and been resurrected. This is proved by the words [i]unto death[/i] in [link]v. 11[/link].

In the Bible, woman signifies the weaker one and man the stronger one ([link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]). Hence, the man-child here signifies the stronger part of God's people. That the man-child is to shepherd all the nations with an iron rod indicates that the man-child consists of the overcomers, as mentioned in [link]2:26-27[/link].

See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Thes. 4[/link]. To be caught up is to be raptured. The rapture of the man-child differs from that of the majority of the believers, which is mentioned in [link]1 Thes. 4:17[/link]. There, the majority of the believers are raptured (1) to the air, and (2) at the last trumpet ([link]1 Cor. 15:52[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]), which is the seventh trumpet ([link]11:15[/link]). But here, the man-child is raptured (1) to the throne of God, and (2) before the one thousand two hundred and sixty days, which is the time of the great tribulation of three and a half years (forty-two months, [link]v. 14[/link]; [link]13:5[/link]; [link]11:2[/link]), beginning from the sixth seal, before the fifth trumpet ([link]9:1[/link]).

verse.text: And the woman fled into the [note]1[/note]wilderness, where she has a place there prepared by God so that they might nourish her there a [xref]a[/xref]thousand two hundred and sixty days.
verse.note: After the rapture of the man-child, the woman is left on earth to suffer persecution ([link]v. 13[/link]). During the time of the great tribulation, God will prepare a place where she can be nourished for a thousand two hundred and sixty days before He brings His people into the millennial kingdom. (This is similar to the time when Pharaoh persecuted the children of Israel and God brought His people to the wilderness, where He nourished them before bringing them into the good land.) That the woman (the remaining and living majority of the believers) will be preserved and nourished by God for a thousand two hundred and sixty days during the great tribulation is a strong proof that their rapture will take place on the last day of the three and a half years of the great tribulation, that is, the last day of the one thousand two hundred and sixty days.

verse.text: And there was [note]1[/note]war in heaven: [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Michael and his angels went to war with the dragon. And the dragon warred and [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]his angels.
verse.note: Immediately after the man-child is raptured to heaven, Michael and his angels begin to war against Satan. This indicates that the man-child, the stronger part of God's people, is always engaged in fighting God's enemy, Satan. They have been fighting Satan continually on earth. Heaven is waiting for them to arrive that a war may be waged to cast Satan out of heaven.

The Bible reveals the names of two angels — Michael and Gabriel. Gabriel is a reporter bringing news to God's people ([link]Dan. 8:16[/link]; [link]9:21-22[/link]; [link]Luke 1:19[/link], [link]26[/link]), whereas Michael is a fighter contending for God's people ([link]Dan. 10:13[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]11:1[/link]; [link]12:1[/link]; [link]Jude 9[/link]).
These angels must be the fallen angels, who follow Satan to rebel against God ([link]Matt. 25:41[/link]). See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And they did not prevail, neither was their place found any longer in heaven.

And the great dragon was [note]1[/note]cast down, the [note]2[/note]ancient [xref]a[/xref]serpent, he who is called the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Devil and [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]Satan, he who [xref]d[/xref]deceives the whole inhabited earth; he was [xref]e[/xref]cast to the earth, and his angels were cast down with him.
verse.note: Satan, the enemy of God, was judged by the Lord Jesus on the cross ([link]John 12:31[/link]; [link]16:11[/link]). After that, the overcoming believers are needed for the carrying out of that judgment, for the executing of that sentence. The war waged by the overcoming believers against Satan is actually the executing of the Lord's judgment upon him. Eventually, through their fighting, he is cast out of heaven. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].
By the time of [link]Rev. 12[/link], Satan has become old; hence, he becomes the ancient serpent.
See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].
The word [i]Satan[/i] means [i]adversary.[/i] Satan is not only God's enemy outside God's kingdom but also God's adversary from within God's kingdom, rebelling against God.

verse.text: And I heard a loud voice in heaven saying, Now has come the salvation and the power and the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]kingdom of our God and the authority of His Christ, for the [note]2[/note]accuser of our brothers has been cast down, who [xref]b[/xref]accuses them before our God day and night.
verse.note: The overcoming believers fight against Satan to usher in God's kingdom. The Lord taught us to pray for the coming of the kingdom ([link]Matt. 6:10[/link]). Along with our praying for the kingdom's coming, we need to fight for it. The coming of the kingdom has two aspects: the reality of the kingdom ([link]Matt. 5:3[/link]), which is in the proper church life today ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link]), and the manifestation of the kingdom in the millennium, which will be brought in through the overcoming believers.[br][br]When the manifestation of the kingdom comes, the salvation of God will come in full with the kingdom. God's salvation has already been manifested to us today, but it will come in full in the kingdom age. It is the same with the power of God and the authority of His Christ. We have participated in God's power and Christ's authority today, but our full enjoyment of them will be in the kingdom age.
The accuser is the devil, who accused Job ([link]Job 1:9[/link]; [link]2:4-5[/link]) and Joshua ([link]Zech. 3:1-2[/link]) and who is now accusing the believers before God, even day and night.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]they [xref]a[/xref]overcame him because of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]blood of the [xref]c[/xref]Lamb and because of the [note]3[/note]word of their testimony, and they [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]loved not their soul-life even [note]5[/note][xref]e[/xref]unto death.
verse.note: Referring to the overcoming believers who constitute the man-child in [link]v. 5[/link]. These have been opposed and slandered by God's enemy, Satan, whom they overcame.

The blood of the Lamb, which is for our redemption, answers before God all the accusations of the devil against us and gives us the victory over him. We need to apply this blood whenever we sense the accusation of the devil.

The word of their testimony is their word that testifies that the devil has been judged by the Lord. Whenever we sense the devil's accusation, we should verbally testify how the Lord has already dealt with him. We must declare with the uttered word the Lord's victory over him.

Because of Adam's fall, Satan joined himself to man's soul-life — man's self ([link]Matt. 16:23-24[/link]). Hence, to overcome Satan we must not love our soul-life; rather, we must hate it and deny it ([link]Luke 14:26[/link]; [link]9:23[/link]).
[i]Unto death[/i] indicates martyrdom. The overcoming believers who constitute the man-child do not love their soul-life even unto death.

verse.text: Therefore be glad, O heavens and [xref]a[/xref]those who [note]1[/note]dwell in them. [xref]b[/xref]Woe to the earth and the sea because the devil has come down to you and has [note]2[/note]great rage, knowing that he has [i]only[/i] a [note]3[/note]short time.
verse.note: Lit., tabernacle.
The dragon is angry because he has been cast down and limited to the earth, thereby losing his territory in the heavens and in the air.
The short time here will be the three and a half years of the great tribulation ([link]v. 14[/link]; [link]13:5[/link]; [link]11:2[/link]).

verse.text: And when the dragon saw that he was cast to the earth, he [note]1[/note]persecuted the woman who brought forth the man-child.
verse.note: Satan, the angry dragon, will concentrate his hatred upon God's people.

verse.text: And to the woman there were given the two wings of the [note]1[/note]great [xref]a[/xref]eagle that she might [xref]b[/xref]fly into the wilderness into her place, where she is nourished for [note]2[/note]a [xref]c[/xref]time and times and half a time from the face of the serpent.
verse.note: The great eagle signifies God, and the two wings signify His strength to rescue ([link]Exo. 19:4[/link]; [link]Deut. 32:11-12[/link]). As He brought the children of Israel out from Pharaoh's persecution, so He will bring His people away from Satan's persecution in the great tribulation.
[i]A time and times and half a time[/i] denotes three and a half years, that is, one thousand two hundred and sixty days.

verse.text: And the serpent cast [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]water as a river out of his mouth after the woman that he might cause her to be carried away by its current.
verse.note: Water here signifies the armies (see marginal references) that will be sent by Satan to destroy the people of God.

verse.text: And the earth helped the woman, and the earth [note]1[/note]opened its mouth and swallowed the river which the dragon cast out of his mouth.
verse.note: The earth will open, just as in [link]Num. 16:31-33[/link], and swallow the armies sent by Satan.

verse.text: And the dragon became angry with the woman and went away to make [xref]a[/xref]war with the [note]1[/note]rest of her seed, who [xref]b[/xref]keep the commandments of God and have the [xref]c[/xref]testimony of Jesus.
verse.note: [i]The rest of her seed[/i] signifies the people of God other than the man-child; those people constitute the weaker part of the woman. Among them, some are the Jews, who keep the commandments of God, and some are the believers, who have the testimony of Jesus. Both will pass through the great tribulation and suffer the dragon's persecution and attack.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]he stood on the sand of the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]sea.
verse.note: [i]He[/i] denotes the dragon.

The sea here is the same as that in [link]13:1[/link], the Mediterranean Sea. The sand of the sea here should be the seashore of the Holy Land, where the nation of Israel is. That the dragon will stand on the sand of the sea and that the holy city, Jerusalem, will be trampled for forty-two months ([link]11:2[/link]) indicate that Satan's persecution during the great tribulation will be carried out mainly in the land of Israel.

verse.text: And I saw a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]beast coming up out of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]sea, having [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]ten horns and [xref]d[/xref]seven heads, and on his horns ten diadems, and on his heads [xref]e[/xref]names of [note]4[/note]blasphemy.
verse.note: This beast, the fourth beast mentioned in [link]Dan. 7:7[/link], is Antichrist. In [link]9:11[/link] he is the king of the locusts.

The sea here is the Mediterranean Sea, out of which Antichrist will come. In [link]9:11[/link], [link]11:7[/link], and [link]17:8[/link] we are told that Antichrist will come up out of the abyss. Here we are told that he will come up out of the sea, as is mentioned also in [link]Dan. 7:3[/link]. This indicates that Antichrist will come from two sources. His spirit, which exists in the abyss before he is born, will come up out of the abyss. (See notes [link chapter="17"]8[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link], and [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].) His body will come from one of the Gentile nations around the Mediterranean Sea. In biblical figure, the land signifies the nation of Israel and the sea signifies the Gentile nations ([link]17:15[/link]; [link]Isa. 57:20[/link]).[br][br]That Antichrist will come up out of both the abyss and the sea may indicate also that the sea is the mouth of the abyss, because the abyss is in the heart of the earth ([link]Rom. 10:7[/link]; [link]Matt. 12:40[/link]) and the sea is above the earth.

The ten horns and seven heads of the beast are those of the dragon ([link]12:3[/link]). This indicates that the beast is one with the dragon. The ten horns are the ten coming kings ([link]17:12[/link]; [link]Dan. 7:24[/link]); the seven heads are the seven Caesars ([link]17:10[/link]). The ten horns correspond with the ten toes of the great image mentioned in [link]Dan. 2:42-44[/link]. The word here indicates that the Roman Empire, Antichrist, and the ten kings are one with Satan.
The seven Caesars symbolized by the seven heads of the beast claimed deity and called for their people to worship them as gods. That was truly a blasphemy against God.

verse.text: And the beast which I saw was [note]1[/note]like a [xref]a[/xref]leopard, and his feet like those of a [xref]b[/xref]bear, and his mouth like the mouth of a [xref]c[/xref]lion. And the [xref]d[/xref]dragon [xref]e[/xref]gave him his [note]2[/note]power and his [xref]f[/xref]throne and great [xref]g[/xref]authority.
verse.note: The beast, Antichrist, is "like a leopard, and his feet like those of a bear, and his mouth like the mouth of a lion." According to [link]Dan. 7:4-6[/link], the leopard, which is characterized by swift and cruel movement, was the symbol of Alexander the Great, the king of Greece. The bear, characterized by its destroying feet, was the symbol of the monarchy of Medo-Persia. The lion, characterized by its devouring mouth, was a symbol of Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon. Since Antichrist, the beast, is like these three, he will have all their characteristics, as mentioned in [link]Dan. 7:4-7[/link]. He is the totality of all the evil powers in human history.

That the dragon gives his power, his throne, and great authority to the beast indicates that he makes the beast one with him so that on behalf of the dragon the beast can resist God and persecute God's people on the earth.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]one of his heads was as it were slain to death, and his death stroke was healed. And the whole earth [xref]a[/xref]marveled after the beast.
verse.note: [i]One of his heads[/i] refers to one of the Caesars, who will be slain and resuscitated. [i]His death stroke was healed[/i] means that the Caesar will be resuscitated from death. (See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].) Because of this the whole earth will marvel and follow after him.

verse.text: And they worshipped the dragon because he gave his authority to the beast; and they [xref]a[/xref]worshipped the beast, saying, Who is like the beast? And who can make war with him?
And there was given to him a mouth [xref]a[/xref]speaking great things and blasphemies, and authority was given to him to act for [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]forty-two months.
verse.note: The forty-two months here and in [link]11:2[/link] are the three and a half years in [link]12:14[/link], and are also the one thousand two hundred and sixty days in [link]11:3[/link] and [link]12:6[/link], the time of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]). At the end of this age Antichrist will make a seven-year covenant with the nation of Israel. Three and a half years after the covenant is made, he will break it, terminate all the Jewish worship and service to God ([link]Dan. 9:27[/link]), persecute the saints ([link]v. 7[/link]), and destroy the holy city ([link]11:2[/link]) for three and a half years.

verse.text: And he opened his mouth for blasphemies against God, to blaspheme His name and His [xref]a[/xref]tabernacle, which tabernacle in heaven.
And [i]permission[/i] was given to him to make [xref]a[/xref]war with the [note]1[/note]saints and to overcome them; and authority was given to him over every tribe and people and tongue and nation.
verse.note: The saints here constitute the rest of the woman's seed mentioned in [link]12:17[/link], which consists of the Jews, who keep God's commandments, and the believers, who bear the testimony for Christ. This proves that in the great tribulation there will still be believers on the earth who are not yet raptured.

verse.text: And all those [xref]a[/xref]dwelling on the earth will worship him, [i]everyone[/i] whose name is not [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]written in the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]book of life of the [xref]d[/xref]Lamb who was slain [xref]e[/xref]from the foundation of the world.
verse.note: Or, written from the foundation of the world in the book of life of the Lamb who was slain.
Lit., scroll.

verse.text: If anyone has an [xref]a[/xref]ear, let him hear.

If anyone is for captivity, into captivity he goes; if anyone [xref]a[/xref]kills with the sword, with the sword he is to be killed. Here is the [xref]b[/xref]endurance and the [xref]c[/xref]faith of the [note]1[/note]saints.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And I saw [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]another beast coming up out of the [note]2[/note]earth, and he had two horns [note]3[/note]like a lamb, and he spoke like a [xref]b[/xref]dragon.
verse.note: This other beast is the false prophet ([link]16:13[/link]; [link]19:20[/link]; [link]20:10[/link]).

This other beast will come up out of the earth. Since the earth, the land, signifies the nation of Israel, as mentioned in note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link], this other beast, the false prophet, will come out of the Jews. This one may be Judas Iscariot ([link]John 6:70-71[/link]), because after Judas died, he went to "his own place" ([link]Acts 1:25[/link]), not to his people as others did ([link]Gen. 25:17[/link]; [link]35:29[/link]). Geographically, this false prophet will come up out of the earth, and figuratively, he will come out of the Jews.
The false prophet looks like a lamb but speaks like a dragon. That he appears to be a lamb but speaks like the dragon, Satan, indicates his falsity.

verse.text: And he exercises all the authority of the first beast [xref]a[/xref]in his sight, and he causes the earth and those who dwell in it to [xref]b[/xref]worship the first beast, whose [xref]c[/xref]death stroke was healed.
And he does great [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]signs, so that he even makes [xref]b[/xref]fire come down out of heaven to the earth before men.
verse.note: The false prophet will employ satanic power to perform great signs, such as calling down fire out of heaven as Elijah did ([link]1 Kings 18:36-38[/link]); thus, it will be difficult for people to distinguish the real prophets from the false prophet (cf. [link]11:5[/link]).

verse.text: And he [xref]a[/xref]deceives those who dwell on the earth on account of the signs which he was given [i]power[/i] to do before the beast, [note]1[/note]commanding those who dwell on the earth to make an [xref]b[/xref]image to the beast, who had the [xref]c[/xref]stroke of the sword and revived.
verse.note: Lit., telling.

verse.text: And [i]power[/i] was given to him to give [note]1[/note]breath to the image of the beast that the image of the beast might even [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]speak and cause whoever would [xref]b[/xref]not worship the image of the beast to be killed.
verse.note: Or, spirit.

No idol made by man has ever been able to speak ([link]Psa. 115:5[/link]), but this last idol will be enabled to speak as a living image. This surely will be a marvelous sign to those who dwell on the earth, and will cause them all to worship the idol.

verse.text: And he causes all, the small and the great, and the rich and the poor, and the freemen and the slaves, to be given a [xref]a[/xref]mark on their right hand or on their [xref]b[/xref]forehead,
And that no one may be able to buy or sell except him who has the mark, [i]that is,[/i] the name of the beast or the [xref]a[/xref]number of his name.
Here is wisdom. Let him who has [note]1[/note]understanding calculate the [note]2[/note]number of the beast, for it is the number of a man; and his number is six hundred sixty-six.
verse.note: Lit., mind.

The number of the beast is the number of a man. This man is Caesar Nero, who is the coming Antichrist. (See notes [link chapter="17"]8[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link], and [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].) The number represented by the Hebrew letters of the name Caesar Nero is 666, as follows:[br][br]Because the book of Revelation was written during the time of the Roman Empire, John did not mention the name of Nero but indicated it with a number. Therefore, wisdom is needed to understand.

verse.text: And I saw, and behold, the [xref]a[/xref]Lamb standing on Mount [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Zion, and with Him a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]hundred and forty-four thousand, having [note]3[/note]His [xref]d[/xref]name and the [xref]e[/xref]name of His Father written on their foreheads.
verse.note: Zion here is not the Zion on the earth but the one in the heavens ([link]Heb. 12:22[/link]).

This must be an actual number with a symbolic meaning. One hundred forty-four thousand is one thousand times twelve times twelve. Twelve is the number of completion in God's eternal administration. One hundred forty-four ([link]21:17[/link]) is twelve times twelve, which signifies the completion of completions, the ultimate completion in the fullest way. The number here is one thousand times this ultimate completion.

That these early overcomers have the name of the Lamb and the name of the Father written on their foreheads signifies that they are one with the Lamb and with the Father and that they belong to the Lamb and to the Father. They are in contrast to those who worship the beast and have the name of the beast written on their foreheads ([link]13:16-17[/link]).

verse.text: And I heard a voice out of heaven like the sound of [note]1[/note]many [xref]a[/xref]waters and like the sound of [note]2[/note]loud [xref]b[/xref]thunder; and the voice which I heard was like [i]the sound[/i] of [note]3[/note]harp-singers playing on their [xref]c[/xref]harps.
verse.note: [i]Many waters[/i] signifies the tumultuousness of the sound.
[i]Loud thunder[/i] signifies the solemnity of the sound.
[i]Harp-singers[/i] signifies the pleasantness of the sound.

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]sing a [xref]b[/xref]new song before the throne and before the [xref]c[/xref]four living creatures and the [xref]d[/xref]elders; and [note]1[/note]no one could learn the song except the hundred and forty-four thousand, who have been [xref]e[/xref]purchased [note]2[/note]from the earth.
verse.note: No one can learn the new song sung by these first overcomers, a song that must be in accord with their experiences of the Lamb, because no one else has their specific and particular experiences of Christ.
[i]From the earth[/i] proves that they are no longer on the earth but have been raptured to the heavens.

verse.text: These are they who have not been defiled with women, for they are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]virgins. These are they who [xref]b[/xref]follow the Lamb wherever He may go. These were purchased from among men [i]as[/i] [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]firstfruits to God and to the Lamb.
verse.note: This should be the virginity mentioned by the Lord in [link]Matt. 19:11-12[/link]. However, the same principle could be applied to the sisters ([link]1 Cor. 7:7[/link], [link]37[/link]).

These early overcomers will be the first-ripe ones in God's field. Hence, they will be reaped before the harvest as firstfruits to God and to the Lamb. The harvest will be reaped later, in [link]vv. 14-16[/link]. This means that the overcomers will be raptured to the heavens before the harvest, just as the firstfruits of the good land were reaped and brought into the temple of God before the harvest ([link]Lev. 23:10-11[/link]; [link]Exo. 23:19[/link]). The events recorded in [link]vv. 6-13[/link], all of which will take place during the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]), indicate clearly and prove strongly that the first overcomers, the firstfruits in [link]vv. 1-5[/link], will be raptured before the great tribulation, and that the harvest in [link]vv. 14-16[/link], composed of the majority of the believers, will be raptured at the end of the great tribulation. See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].

verse.text: And in their mouth [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]no lie was found; they are [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]without blemish.
verse.note: The devil is the father of all liars, and lies come out of him ([link]John 8:44[/link]). That no lie was found in the mouth of the overcomers indicates that there is nothing of Satan in their expression.

[i]Without blemish[/i] indicates that they are without spot or wrinkle and are perfect in the holiness of God ([link]Eph. 5:27[/link]), absolutely sanctified to God and fully saturated with God ([link]1 Thes. 5:23[/link]).

verse.text: And I saw another angel flying in [xref]a[/xref]mid-heaven, having an [note]1[/note]eternal gospel to announce to those [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]dwelling on the earth, even to every nation and tribe and tongue and people,
verse.note: The eternal gospel, which will be preached during the time of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]), differs from the gospel of grace ([link]Acts 20:24[/link]) preached in the church age. The basic contents of the gospel of grace are repentance unto God and faith in the Lord Jesus ([link]Acts 20:21[/link]) that men may be forgiven of their sins and be born again as the children of God ([link]Luke 24:47[/link]; [link]John 1:12[/link]); whereas the basic content of the eternal gospel is that men should fear God and worship God that they may not be deceived and follow Antichrist but may be brought back to the genuine worship of God, who made heaven and earth ([link]v. 7[/link]). Only man is privileged to preach the gospel of grace on the earth today ([link]Acts 10:3-6[/link]). But the eternal gospel will be preached by the angel in the air at the close of this age.
Lit., sitting.

verse.text: Saying with a loud voice, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Fear God and [xref]b[/xref]give Him glory because the hour of His [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]judgment has come; and [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]worship Him who has [xref]e[/xref]made heaven and earth and the sea and the [xref]f[/xref]springs of waters.
verse.note: "Fear God and give Him glory" is a commandment given to those who dwell on the earth. It counters the false prophet's deceit that says that men should follow Antichrist and neutralizes the death threat against those who refuse to worship Antichrist during the great tribulation ([link]13:14-15[/link]).

The judgment here is the judgment that Christ will execute over all the nations at His coming back to earth, as He predicted in [link]Matt. 25:31-46[/link]. This judgment will be executed on the living. It differs from the judgment on the dead, which will take place after the millennium, as mentioned in [link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]. All the people of the nations who remain at the Lord's coming back to earth will be judged according to the eternal gospel preached by the angel during the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]). If in fearing and worshipping God they have treated well the Christians and Jews, the Lord's brothers suffering poverty and imprisonment under Antichrist's persecution during the great tribulation, they will be justified by the Lord so that they can enter into the earthly part of the millennium to partake of the kingdom prepared by God for them from the foundation of the world ([link]Matt. 25:34[/link]). If in following Antichrist and worshipping his image they have ill-treated the Christians and Jews, they will be condemned and cast into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels ([link]Matt. 25:41[/link]).
The worship of Him who has made heaven and earth is in contrast to the worship of Antichrist and his image in [link]v. 9[/link].

verse.text: And another angel, a second one, followed, saying, [xref]a[/xref]Fallen, fallen is [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Babylon the Great, who has made all the nations [xref]c[/xref]drink of the [note]2[/note]wine of the fury of her fornication!
verse.note: The modifying clause [i]who has made all the nations drink[/i]... indicates that Babylon here is the religious, mysterious Babylon, which is the Roman Catholic Church, as in [link]17:2-6[/link], not the material Babylon, as in [link]18:2[/link]. Antichrist will destroy all religions when he breaks the covenant with Israel in the middle of the last week (seven years — [link]Dan. 9:27[/link]; [link]11:31[/link]). This will be the beginning of the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:21[/link]), which will last for three and a half years. Antichrist will exalt himself above all gods and force people to worship him ([link]Dan. 8:9-11[/link]; [link]11:36-37[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:3-4[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:4-6[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]14-15[/link]). At that time, he will destroy the religious Babylon, the apostate Roman Catholic Church ([link]17:16[/link]). Hence, the religious Babylon will fall at the beginning of the great tribulation, whereas the material Babylon will fall at the end of the great tribulation ([link]18:2[/link]).

[i]Wine of[/i]...her fornication refers to the spiritual fornication of the Roman Catholic Church, of which she has made all the nations drink ([link]17:2-6[/link]). While she commits her fornication, she is furious with the saints who do not consent to her fornication. This is the fury of her fornication. Hence, the wine of her fornication is also called "the wine of the fury of her fornication."

verse.text: And another angel, a third one, followed them, saying with a loud voice, If anyone [xref]a[/xref]worships the beast and his [xref]b[/xref]image and receives a [xref]c[/xref]mark on his forehead or on his hand,

He also shall drink of the [xref]a[/xref]wine of the fury of God, which is mixed undiluted in the [xref]b[/xref]cup of His wrath; and he shall be tormented in [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]fire and brimstone before the holy angels and before the Lamb.
verse.note: This is the fire and brimstone in the lake of fire ([link]19:20[/link]; [link]20:10[/link], [link]14[/link]).

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]smoke of their tormenting goes up forever and ever; and they have no rest day and night, those who worship the beast and his [xref]b[/xref]image, and whoever receives the mark of his name.
Here is the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]endurance of the [note]2[/note]saints, those who [xref]b[/xref]keep the commandments of God and the [xref]c[/xref]faith of Jesus.
verse.note: The endurance to suffer Antichrist's persecution will be needed by the saints who remain in the great tribulation.
The saints who remain in the great tribulation are of two peoples: the Jews, who keep the commandments of God, and the believers, who keep the faith of Jesus.

verse.text: And I heard a voice out of heaven, saying, Write, Blessed are the [note]1[/note]dead who [xref]a[/xref]die in the Lord from now on. Yes, says [note]2[/note]the [xref]b[/xref]Spirit, that they may [xref]c[/xref]rest from their labors; for their works follow with them.
verse.note: The dead here are those who are martyred under the persecution of Antichrist during the great tribulation. This is proved by [link]20:4[/link].
This book, written in the time of the degradation of the church, stresses the Spirit. It does not say here "says the Scripture," but "says the Spirit."

verse.text: And I saw, and behold, [i]there was[/i] a white cloud, and [note]1[/note]on the [xref]a[/xref]cloud One like the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Son of Man sitting, having a [note]3[/note]golden [xref]c[/xref]crown on His head and a [note]4[/note]sharp sickle in His hand.
verse.note: In [link]10:1[/link] Christ is still clothed with a cloud, whereas here He is on the cloud. His being on the cloud corresponds with [link]1 Thes. 4:17[/link] and indicates that at this point the Lord's coming back is made public in the air.
At His coming back, the Lord Jesus will still be the Son of Man. As the Son of Man, He is qualified to execute God's judgment on everyone ([link]John 5:27[/link]).
The golden crown on the Lord's head indicates that the Lord is the One crowned with glory ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]).
The sharp sickle in the Lord's hand indicates that the Lord is the One who reaps God's field.

verse.text: And another angel [xref]a[/xref]came out of the [xref]b[/xref]temple, crying with a loud voice to Him who sat on the cloud, Send forth Your sickle and reap, for the hour to reap has come because the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]harvest of the earth is [note]2[/note]ripe.
verse.note: The harvest of the earth is God's people on earth, the believers in Christ ([link]1 Cor. 3:9[/link]). At His first coming to the earth, the Lord sowed Himself into His believers ([link]Matt. 13:3-8[/link], [link]24[/link]). All the believers since that time, who have received Him as the seed of life, have become God's crop on the earth. The first-ripe ones will be reaped as the firstfruits to God before the great tribulation, as indicated in [link]vv. 1-5[/link]. The majority will ripen with the help of the sufferings in the great tribulation and will be reaped, raptured, at the end of the great tribulation.

Lit., dried. To be ripe is to be "dried" of all the earthly water. The suffering of the great tribulation, like the parching sun, will dry up the earthly waters from the believers who are left on the earth in the great tribulation, enabling the believers to ripen.

verse.text: And He who sat on the cloud thrust His [note]1[/note]sickle upon the earth, and the earth was [note]2[/note]reaped.
verse.note: The sickle here signifies the angels sent by the Lord to reap the harvest ([link]Matt. 13:39[/link]).

The reaping here will take place after Antichrist forces people to worship him and his image ([link]v. 9[/link]). Hence, it refers to the rapture of the majority of the believers, who are left on the earth to pass through the great tribulation.

verse.text: And another angel came out of the temple which is in heaven, he also having a sharp sickle.

And another angel came out of the [xref]a[/xref]altar, he who has authority over fire, and he cried with a loud voice to [note]1[/note]him who had the sharp sickle, saying, Send forth your sharp sickle and gather the clusters of the [note]2[/note]vine of the earth, for her grapes are fully ripened.
verse.note: [i]Him[/i] refers not to the Lord but to the angel in [link]v. 17[/link].

In the Bible the Jews are likened to the fig tree ([link]Matt. 24:32[/link]), the believers are likened to wheat ([link]Matt. 13:25[/link], [link]30[/link]), and the wicked Gentiles are likened to the grapevine ([link]v. 19[/link]), which is a counterfeit of the true vine composed of Christ and His members ([link]John 15:1-6[/link]). The wheat is ripe when its water content is dried up, whereas the grapes are ripe when the water has filled them up. [i]Fully ripened[/i] indicates that the Gentiles as the grapevine are filled to the brim with their sin and that the time of their judgment has come.

verse.text: And the angel thrust his sickle into the earth and gathered the vine of the earth and cast [i]it[/i] into the great [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]winepress of the fury of God.
verse.note: The great winepress of the fury of God is the war at Armageddon ([link]16:12-16[/link]), which is in the valley of Jehoshaphat ([link]Joel 3:9-16[/link]). All the Gentile evil worldly forces will be gathered there, and the Lord with His overcoming saints will fight against them and destroy them there ([link]19:11-21[/link]; [link]Joel 3:9-13[/link]; [link]Isa. 63:1-6[/link]).

verse.text: And the winepress was trodden outside the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]city, and [xref]b[/xref]blood came out of the winepress up to the bridles of the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]horses for a [note]3[/note]thousand six hundred [note]4[/note]stadia.
verse.note: The city here is the city of Jerusalem.
The horses here correspond with the horses in [link]19:18[/link].
A thousand six hundred stadia, 182 miles, is the distance from Bozrah ([link]Isa. 63:1[/link]) to Armageddon ([link]16:16[/link]).
A stadion equals about six hundred feet.

verse.text: And I saw another [xref]a[/xref]sign in heaven, great and wonderful, [xref]b[/xref]seven angels having [note]1[/note]seven [xref]c[/xref]plagues, the last [i]plagues;[/i] for in them the [xref]d[/xref]fury of God was finished.
verse.note: The seven plagues are the fury of God contained in the seven bowls ([link]16:1[/link]). These plagues constitute the third woe ([link]11:14[/link]), which comes at the sounding of the seventh trumpet ([link]11:15[/link], [link]18[/link]).

verse.text: And I saw as it were a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glassy sea mingled with fire and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]those who come away victorious from the [xref]c[/xref]beast and from his [xref]d[/xref]image and from the [xref]e[/xref]number of his name [note]3[/note]standing on the glassy sea, having [xref]f[/xref]harps of God.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

These are the late overcomers who will pass through the great tribulation and overcome Antichrist and the worshipping of Antichrist. They will be martyred under the persecution of Antichrist and then resurrected to reign with Christ in the millennium ([link]20:4[/link]).

[i]Standing on the glassy sea[/i] signifies that these ones have been (1) resurrected from the dead and (2) raptured to be above the lake of fire (which the glassy sea refers to and which is the second death — note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]; [link]20:14[/link]), that is, to be above God's eternal, fiery judgment ([link]14:9-11[/link]).

verse.text: And they sing the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]song of Moses, the [xref]b[/xref]slave of God, and the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]song of the Lamb, saying, [xref]d[/xref]Great and [xref]e[/xref]wonderful are Your [note]3[/note]works, [xref]f[/xref]Lord God the Almighty! [xref]g[/xref]Righteous and true are Your [note]3[/note][xref]h[/xref]ways, O [xref]i[/xref]King of the [note]4[/note]nations!
verse.note: The song of Moses, recorded in [link]Exo. 15:1-18[/link], praises God for the victory over the forces of Pharaoh gained by God's triumphant deliverance through the judging waters of the Red Sea. Moses and the children of Israel sang that song on the shore of the Red Sea. Now these late overcomers sing the song again, on the glassy sea, indicating that they are victorious over the power of Antichrist, who will be judged by God with the fire of the glassy sea ([link]19:20[/link]).

The song of Moses, indicating God's triumphant judgment over the enemy of His people, praises God for His judgment, which is on the negative side; whereas the song of the Lamb, indicating Christ's redemption experienced by God's people in the presence of their enemy, praises God for Christ's redemption, which is on the positive side. The late overcomers are positioned to stand on the glassy sea because of two facts: (1) God's judgment over the enemy and (2) Christ's redemption for God's people.

God's ways are His governing principles, while God's works are His judgments ([link]v. 4[/link]). Moses knew God's ways (principles), but the children of Israel knew only His works (acts) ([link]Psa. 103:7[/link]). God's ways are righteous in His principles and true in His promises, while His works are great in manifestation and wonderful in nature. [i]Your works[/i] here refers mainly to God's judgment, God's verdict, upon Antichrist ([link]14:17-20[/link]).
Some MSS read, ages.

verse.text: Who will not [xref]a[/xref]fear, O Lord, and glorify Your name? For You alone are [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]holy; for [xref]c[/xref]all the nations will come and worship before You, for Your [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]righteous judgments have been manifested.
verse.note: The Greek word refers to the sum of the qualities that fit and form the divine character. Hence, [i]holy[/i] refers to God's nature, while [i]righteous[/i] refers to God's principles.
Judgments that are made according to righteousness.

verse.text: And after these things I saw, and the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]temple of the [xref]b[/xref]Tabernacle of the [note]2[/note]Testimony in heaven was opened,
verse.note: See note [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

The testimony is the law of God, which testifies God and was put into the Ark ([link]Exo. 25:16[/link]). Because the Ark was put in the tabernacle, the tabernacle was called "the Tabernacle of the Testimony." The tabernacle here is the one in heaven.

verse.text: And the seven angels who had the seven plagues [xref]a[/xref]came out of the temple, [note]1[/note]clothed in clean bright [xref]b[/xref]linen and [xref]c[/xref]girded around the breasts with golden girdles.
verse.note: The seven angels are clothed like priests ([link]Ezek. 44:17[/link]).

verse.text: And one of the [xref]a[/xref]four living creatures gave to the seven angels seven golden [xref]b[/xref]bowls full of the fury of God, who [xref]c[/xref]lives forever and ever.

And the [xref]a[/xref]temple was filled with [xref]b[/xref]smoke from the [xref]c[/xref]glory of God and from His power, and [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]no one could enter into the temple until the seven plagues of the seven angels were finished.
verse.note: This means that no one can enter the temple to pray in order to appease the fury of God until it is fully poured out upon the rebellious people instigated by Satan and influenced by Antichrist.

verse.text: And I heard a loud voice out of the [xref]a[/xref]temple, saying to the [xref]b[/xref]seven angels, Go and pour out the seven [note]1[/note]bowls of the [xref]c[/xref]fury of God into the earth.
verse.note: The bowls here signify that though the seven last plagues, the plagues of the seven bowls, are the ultimate fury of God, His fury is limited; otherwise, the entire earth with its inhabitants would be destroyed. For the fulfillment of His eternal purpose, God, in His judgment upon the earth, still places a limit on His ultimate fury.

verse.text: And the first went and poured out his bowl into the [xref]a[/xref]earth; and there came to be an evil and malignant [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sore upon the men who have the [xref]c[/xref]mark of the beast and worship his image.
verse.note: In His ultimate fury God will mark the rebellious ones with a sore on their skin because they bear the mark of the beast. This shows that what God does in His ultimate fury toward the rebellious ones is a reaction to what Antichrist does.

verse.text: And the second poured out his bowl into the [xref]a[/xref]sea, and it became [xref]b[/xref]blood like that of a dead man; and [note]1[/note]every living soul that was in the sea died.
verse.note: Or, every soul of life; referring to every animal that has a soul.
