verse.text: And the third poured out his bowl into the [xref]a[/xref]rivers and the springs of waters; and they became blood.

And I heard the angel [i]who had power over[/i] the waters saying, You are [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]righteous, [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]who is and who was, the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Holy One, because You have [xref]d[/xref]judged these things;
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

Unlike [link]1:8[/link] and [link]4:8[/link], neither this verse nor [link]11:17[/link] says "who is coming." This proves that the Lord's coming back must be after [link]4:8[/link] and before [link]11:17[/link]. See note [link]4[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: For they poured out the [xref]a[/xref]blood of saints and prophets, and You have given them blood to drink; they are worthy [i]of it.[/i]
And I heard the [xref]a[/xref]altar saying, [note]1[/note]Yes, [xref]b[/xref]Lord God the Almighty, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]true and righteous are Your judgments.
verse.note: This is the praise from the altar concerning God's judgments over Antichrist's territory.
See note [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

verse.text: And the fourth poured out his bowl upon the [xref]a[/xref]sun; and it was given to it to burn men with fire.

And men were burned with great heat, and they [xref]a[/xref]blasphemed the name of God, who has the authority over these plagues, and they did [xref]b[/xref]not repent so as to [xref]c[/xref]give Him glory.
And the fifth poured out his bowl upon the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]throne of the beast; and his [xref]b[/xref]kingdom became [xref]c[/xref]darkened; and they gnawed their tongues for pain
verse.note: The throne here indicates that the seven bowls are for the judging of the beast and of his kingdom and territory.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]blasphemed the [xref]b[/xref]God of heaven for their pains and for their [xref]c[/xref]sores; and they did [xref]d[/xref]not repent of their works.

And the [note]1[/note]sixth poured out his bowl upon the great river [xref]a[/xref]Euphrates; and its water was [xref]b[/xref]dried up that the way of the kings from the [xref]c[/xref]rising of the sun might be prepared.
verse.note: The plague of the second bowl is more severe than that of the second trumpet ([link]8:8-9[/link]); the plague of the third bowl is more severe than that of the third trumpet ([link]8:10-11[/link]); and the plague of the fourth bowl is more severe than that of the fourth trumpet ([link]8:12[/link]). The plague of the fifth bowl, the judgment upon the throne of Antichrist and his kingdom, is related to the fifth trumpet, in which Antichrist, as the king of the demon-possessed locusts, torments men ([link]9:7-11[/link]); and the plague of the sixth bowl is related to the sixth trumpet ([link]9:14[/link]), because the plagues of both the sixth bowl and the sixth trumpet are related to the same river, the Euphrates.

verse.text: And I saw, out of the mouth of the [xref]a[/xref]dragon and out of the mouth of the [xref]b[/xref]beast and out of the mouth of the [xref]c[/xref]false prophet, three [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]unclean spirits as [xref]e[/xref]frogs;
verse.note: The unclean spirits will stir up the rebellious kings ([link]v. 14[/link]) to send forth their forces to persecute God's people. Being spirits, the unclean spirits should be in the heavenlies, but having become frogs, they can move about only on the earth. This indicates that Satan and his power to act will be confined to the earth.

verse.text: For they are [xref]a[/xref]spirits of demons doing [xref]b[/xref]signs, which go forth to the kings of the [xref]c[/xref]whole inhabited earth to gather them to the [xref]d[/xref]war of the [xref]e[/xref]great day of God the Almighty.
(Behold, I [note]1[/note]come as a [xref]a[/xref]thief. Blessed is he who [xref]b[/xref]watches and keeps his [xref]c[/xref]garments that he may not walk [xref]d[/xref]naked and they see his shame.)
verse.note: According to the context, this word must be spoken by the Lord at the end of the great tribulation, before the war at Armageddon. This proves that at that time there will still be believers (the remaining, living majority of the believers) left on the earth. To them, the appearing of the Lord in His coming back will still be like the coming of a thief, at an hour unknown to them.

verse.text: And they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gathered them to the place which in Hebrew is called, [note]2[/note]Armageddon.
verse.note: At the end of the great tribulation three unclean spirits out of the mouths of Satan, Antichrist, and the false prophet will go forth to stir up the kings of the whole inhabited earth and to gather their forces ([link]vv. 13-14[/link]) — including the two hundred million horsemen mentioned in [link]9:14-16[/link] (see note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link]) — to the war at Armageddon, which will be the last war among mankind before the millennium. In that war Satan's intention will be to destroy Israel ([link]Zech. 14:2[/link]) and fight against Christ and His army. For this he will use all of rebellious mankind ([link]17:12-14[/link]; [link]19:11-19[/link]). Christ and His chosen overcomers will defeat and destroy them all ([link]19:20-21[/link]; [link]Micah 4:11-13[/link]; [link]Zeph. 3:8[/link]; [link]Zech. 14:3[/link], [link]12-15[/link]; [link]12:4[/link], [link]9[/link]) and will save the nation of Israel ([link]Zech. 12:3-8[/link]; [link]14:4-5[/link]; [link]Joel 3:14-17[/link]). This is the treading of the winepress, which is recorded in [link]14:17-20[/link], [link]Isa. 63:1-6[/link], and [link]Joel 3:9-13[/link].

The word is a Hebrew compound of [i]Har,[/i] meaning [i]mountain,[/i] and [i]Megiddon,[/i] i.e., Megiddo ([link]Judg. 5:19[/link]; [link]2 Kings 23:29[/link]; [link]Zech. 12:11[/link]), meaning [i]slaughter;[/i] hence, [i]the mountain of[/i] slaughter.

verse.text: And the seventh poured out his bowl upon the air; and a loud voice came out of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]temple from the [xref]b[/xref]throne, saying, It is [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]done.
verse.note: The temple is for God's testimony, whereas the throne is for God's judgment. [i]Out of the temple from the throne[/i] indicates that God's judgment comes out of God's testimony and is for God's testimony. Once the last bowl has been poured out, marking the end of the great tribulation, every negative thing will have been eradicated, and then the bride will appear ([link]19:7-9[/link]).
Or, over, passed, accomplished. This refers to the fact that everything has been accomplished for God's judgment and for God's expression, God's testimony.

verse.text: And there were [xref]a[/xref]lightnings and voices and thunders; and there was a great [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]earthquake, such as had [xref]c[/xref]not been since man appeared on the earth, such an earthquake, so great.
verse.note: This earthquake is the same as that associated with the seventh trumpet ([link]11:19[/link]). See note [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]great city was [i]divided[/i] into three parts, and the cities of the nations fell. And [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Babylon the Great was [xref]c[/xref]remembered before God to give her the [xref]d[/xref]cup of the [note]3[/note]wine of the fury of His wrath.
verse.note: The great city is the city of Jerusalem. See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

The religious, mysterious Babylon mentioned in [link]14:8[/link] will be destroyed at the beginning of the great tribulation (see note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 14[/link]); therefore, Babylon the Great here, which will be destroyed immediately after the war at Armageddon at the end of the great tribulation, must be the material Babylon, the city of Rome. The Babylon in [link]14:8[/link] corresponds with the one in [link]ch. 17[/link], while the Babylon here corresponds with the one in [link]ch. 18[/link]. The sketches of the two Babylons are recorded in [link]14:8[/link] and this verse; the details are given in [link]chs. 17[/link] and [link book="Rev."]18[/link].
Rome gave the wine of the fury of her fornication to the nations ([link]18:3[/link]). Now God in His vengeance gives her the wine of the fury of His wrath.

verse.text: And every [xref]a[/xref]island fled, and the mountains were not found.

And great [xref]a[/xref]hail, [i]every stone[/i] about the weight of a [note]1[/note]talent, came down out of heaven upon men; and men [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]blasphemed God for the plague of the hail, because the plague of it is exceedingly great.
verse.note: A talent equals about one hundred pounds.
This proves that the people have no intention of repenting; rather, they will oppose God to the end.

verse.text: And one of the [xref]a[/xref]seven angels who had the [xref]b[/xref]seven bowls came and spoke with me, saying, [xref]c[/xref]Come here; I will show you the [note]1[/note][xref]d[/xref]judgment of the [note]2[/note]great [note]3[/note]harlot who sits upon the [xref]e[/xref]many waters,
verse.note: Or, sentence, condemnation.
[i]Great[/i] here corresponds with [i]greater[/i] in [link]Matt. 13:32[/link].
[i]Harlot[/i] here refers to the apostate Roman Catholic Church. A harlot does not have a husband. This indicates that God never admitted having any relationship with the apostate Roman Church.

verse.text: With whom the kings of the earth have committed [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fornication, and those who [xref]b[/xref]dwell on the earth have been made [xref]c[/xref]drunk with the [note]2[/note]wine of her fornication.
verse.note: What the apostate church commits is not adultery, the sin of an unfaithful spouse, but fornication, the sin of a harlot. This is more sinful than adultery. The fornication of the apostate church consists of her having sinful relationships with the kings of the earth for her profit, just as a harlot commits sin for gain. Hers is spiritual fornication. The kings of the earth commit fornication with her directly.

Wine here signifies the heretical doctrines of the apostate church in her fornicating relationships with the governments on the earth. These heretical doctrines confound, as wine does, those who become involved in her religion. This is the wine of her fornication. It is in an indirect manner that those who dwell on the earth are made drunk with this wine.

verse.text: And he [xref]a[/xref]carried me away in [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]spirit into a [note]2[/note]wilderness; and I saw a [xref]c[/xref]woman sitting upon a [note]3[/note]scarlet [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]beast, full of [xref]e[/xref]names of [note]5[/note]blasphemy, having [note]6[/note][xref]f[/xref]seven heads and [xref]g[/xref]ten horns.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

A wilderness is a desert place. This indicates that the apostate church is in a desert, where there are no springs of water prepared by God. In order to show the apostle John that the apostate church is in such a desolate place, the angel carried him there.
Scarlet is dark red, and red is the color of the great dragon (see note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]). This indicates that Antichrist will be one with Satan in appearance.
The beast here is both the Roman Empire and Antichrist.
Nearly all the Caesars called themselves god. This was sheer blasphemy against God.
See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 13[/link] and notes [link chapter="17"]9[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link] in this chapter.

verse.text: And the woman was [xref]a[/xref]clothed in [note]1[/note]purple and [note]2[/note]scarlet, and gilded with [note]3[/note]gold and precious stone and pearls, having in her hand a [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]golden cup full of [xref]c[/xref]abominations [note]5[/note]and the [xref]d[/xref]unclean things of her fornication.
verse.note: Purple signifies dignity with authority ([link]John 19:2-3[/link]). The color purple is a blend of blue and red; it signifies the blending of heavenly things with earthly. This is the appearance of the apostate church.
Scarlet, dark red, is characteristic of the apostate Roman Church. It is found in many places in the Vatican; the most striking use of it is in the garb of the cardinals.

Gold, precious stone, and pearls are the materials with which the New Jerusalem is built ([link]21:18-19[/link], [link]21[/link]). But the woman here, the apostate church, is not built in a solid way with these precious things; she is only gilded with these treasures as ornaments for outward display. This is a deception intended to entice people. It is the harlot's false appearance.

In figure, gold signifies the divine nature of God. Hence, the golden cup here indicates that in outward appearance the apostate church does have something of God. But within, her "golden cup" is full of abominations and the unclean things of her fornication, full of idolatry, pagan practices, and satanic things in a heretical religious relationship. Therefore, although the apostate Roman Catholic Church has certain holy things, she has mixed in many evil and unclean things.
Or, even.

verse.text: And on her [xref]a[/xref]forehead there was a name written, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]MYSTERY, [xref]c[/xref]BABYLON THE GREAT, THE [note]2[/note]MOTHER OF THE HARLOTS AND THE [note]3[/note]ABOMINATIONS OF THE EARTH.
verse.note: [i]Mystery[/i] here indicates that Babylon the Great in this chapter is not the material Babylon in [link]ch. 18[/link] but the religious one. The religious Babylon, the apostate church, is truly mysterious in what she is, in what she practices, and in what she teaches.

Since the mother of the harlots is the apostate church, the harlots, the daughters of the apostate church, must be all the different sects and groups in Christianity that hold to some extent the teaching, practices, and traditions of the apostate Roman Church. The pure church life has no evil that has been transmitted from the apostate church.
Abominations are idols ([link]Deut. 7:25-26[/link]), with which the apostate Roman Church is filled.

verse.text: And I saw the woman [note]1[/note]drunk with the [xref]a[/xref]blood of the saints and with the blood of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]witnesses of Jesus. And I marveled [i]with[/i] great marvel when I saw her.
verse.note: The Roman Church does not kill the saints directly but does so indirectly through the Roman Empire. She is drunk with the blood of the saints and with the blood of the witnesses of Jesus.

Or, martyrs. The saints are those who are separated, sanctified, unto God and who live a holy life for God, even unto death. The witnesses are those who are a living testimony of the Lord Jesus and who are faithful unto death. The witnesses of Jesus are also saints; however, the saints may just live a separated and holy life, not complying with the apostate church, and may not come forward to testify against the apostasy of the Roman Church as did witnesses such as Antipas in [link]2:13[/link].

verse.text: And the angel said to me, Why did you marvel? I will tell you the mystery of the woman and of the beast who bears her, who has the seven heads and the ten horns.

The [note]1[/note]beast that you saw was and is not and is about to [xref]a[/xref]come up out of the [xref]b[/xref]abyss and [note]2[/note]go into [xref]c[/xref]perdition. And those who [xref]d[/xref]dwell on the earth, [i]those[/i] whose names are not [xref]e[/xref]written from the foundation of the world in the [note]3[/note][xref]f[/xref]book of life, will [xref]g[/xref]marvel when they see the beast, that he was and is not and will be present.
verse.note: The beast, who is Antichrist, "was" in the person of Caesar Nero before John wrote this book. He "is not" at the time of John's writing, because Nero had died by that time. That he "is about to come up out of the abyss" implies that Nero's spirit is now in the abyss and is about to emerge from it to take possession of the body of the slain and resuscitated Antichrist, as indicated in [link]13:3[/link].
This indicates that Antichrist will perish, as described in [link]19:20[/link] and [link]20:10[/link]; that is, he will be thrown into the lake of fire.
Lit., scroll.

verse.text: Here is the mind which has [xref]a[/xref]wisdom. The [xref]b[/xref]seven heads are the [note]1[/note]seven mountains where the woman sits
verse.note: The city of Rome is built on seven mountains. These are signified by the seven heads of the beast on which the harlot sits.

verse.text: And are [note]1[/note]seven kings: five have fallen, one is, the other has not yet come; and when he comes, he must remain [i]only[/i] a short time.
verse.note: The seven kings are seven Caesars of the Roman Empire. The first five "have fallen"; i.e., they died unnaturally ([link]Judg. 3:25[/link]; [link]2 Sam. 1:10[/link], [link]25[/link], [link]27[/link]). Those five are Julius Caesar, Tiberius, Caligula, Claudius, and Nero, all of whom either were murdered or committed suicide before John wrote this book. The sixth, Domitian, who was also murdered, was living when this book was written; therefore, it is said of him that he "is." "The other," the seventh, is Antichrist; he had "not yet come" at that time. When he comes, he will remain only a short time and then will be slain and will be resuscitated by the spirit of the fifth, who is Nero, to become the eighth.

verse.text: And the beast who was and is not, he himself is [note]1[/note]also the eighth and is out of the seven and goes into perdition.
verse.note: Antichrist will be the coming seventh Caesar. But he is also the eighth. According to [link]13:3[/link], Antichrist will be slain and resuscitated. In that resuscitation the spirit of Nero (the fifth Caesar), which will come up out of the abyss (when Satan is cast down to the earth — [link]12:10[/link], [link]13[/link]), will animate and resuscitate the dead body of the seventh Caesar, Antichrist, thereby imitating the resurrection of Christ. This one, composed of the fifth and seventh Caesars, is the eighth. Hence, he is "out of the seven," having the body of the seventh and the spirit of the fifth. Therefore, he will be all the more capable, all the more intelligent, and all the more powerful to charm, deceive, and allure people, capturing those who do not believe in Christ. It is no wonder that people will marvel at the sight of such an extraordinary person and will follow him ([link]v. 8[/link]; [link]13:3[/link]).

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]ten horns which you saw are [note]1[/note]ten kings, who have not yet received a [xref]b[/xref]kingdom but receive authority as kings for [xref]c[/xref]one hour with the beast.
verse.note: Ten kings will be raised up in the revived Roman Empire before the great tribulation. They will be one with Antichrist in opposing God and persecuting His people — the Jews and the believers. These ten kings are likened to the ten toes of the great image seen by Nebuchadnezzar in his dream ([link]Dan. 2:42[/link]). They will submit themselves and their kingdoms to Antichrist ([link]v. 17[/link]).

verse.text: These have one [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]mind, and they give their power and authority to the beast.
verse.note: The mind expressed as opinion.

verse.text: These will make [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]war with the [xref]b[/xref]Lamb, and the Lamb will [xref]c[/xref]overcome them, for He is [xref]d[/xref]Lord of lords and King of kings; and they who are [xref]e[/xref]with Him, the called and [note]2[/note][xref]f[/xref]chosen and [xref]g[/xref]faithful, [i]will also overcome them.[/i]
verse.note: The war here is the same as that mentioned in [link]19:11-21[/link]; it is the war at Armageddon ([link]16:14[/link], [link]16[/link]).

[i]Chosen[/i] is mentioned after [i]called.[/i] To be called is to be saved, whereas to be chosen is to be approved by the Lord by virtue of an overcoming life. Today many are called, but in the future few will be chosen ([link]Matt. 22:14[/link]).

verse.text: And he said to me, The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]waters which you saw, where the harlot sits, are [xref]b[/xref]peoples and multitudes and nations and tongues.
verse.note: The harlot's sitting on the waters, which are peoples and multitudes and nations and tongues, is fulfilled by the historical fact of the apostate Roman Church's riding on peoples and nations throughout the world.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]ten horns which you saw and the beast, these will [note]1[/note]hate the harlot and will make her [xref]b[/xref]desolate and naked and will eat her flesh and [xref]c[/xref]burn her utterly with fire.
verse.note: That the ten horns and the beast will hate the harlot and make her desolate means that Antichrist and the ten kings will persecute the apostate Roman Church. This will take place at the beginning of the great tribulation. (See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 14[/link].) They will make the Roman Church "desolate and naked," meaning that they will destroy her, rob her of her riches, and expose her; they will "eat her flesh," meaning that they will kill her members; and they will "burn her utterly with fire," meaning that they will annihilate her altogether. This too indicates that Babylon the Great in this chapter is the religious Babylon.

verse.text: For [note]1[/note]God has put [i]it[/i] into their hearts to perform His [note]2[/note]mind and to perform one [xref]a[/xref]mind and to give their [xref]b[/xref]kingdom to the beast until the [xref]c[/xref]words of God are accomplished.
verse.note: It is of God that Antichrist and his ten kings destroy the apostate Roman Church. This kind of destruction should not be considered martyrdom but the avenging judgment of God.
See note [link]13[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]woman whom you saw is the [xref]a[/xref]great city, which has a kingdom over the kings of the earth.
verse.note: While the harlot in [link]v. 16[/link] denotes the religious Babylon, signifying the Roman Church, the woman here denotes the material Babylon, signifying the city of Rome. This city is called "the great city, which has a kingdom over the kings of the earth." When John wrote this book, Rome was the city that had a kingdom over the kings of the earth. What Antichrist and his ten kings will hate is the harlot, the Roman Church, not the woman, the city of Rome, where their administration will be based.

verse.text: After these things I saw [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]another Angel [note]2[/note]coming down out of heaven, having great authority; and the earth was [xref]b[/xref]illumined with His glory.
verse.note: This Angel with great authority is Christ. As He comes down out of heaven, the earth is illumined with His glory. In [link]10:1[/link] Christ is still clothed with a cloud, and in [link]14:14[/link] He is sitting on the cloud; whereas here His glory shines over the earth, indicating that His coming back to earth is nearer at hand than the coming mentioned in [link]10:1[/link] and [link]14:14[/link]. He will come out of heaven, first in the cloud secretly, then on the cloud openly; eventually, He will shine over the earth to destroy Babylon the Great, the city of Rome, with His great authority.

This is Christ's coming (parousia) reaching the earth at the end of the great tribulation for Him to take full possession of the earth as His kingdom. At this time the material Babylon the Great will suffer judgment and fall.

verse.text: And He cried with a strong voice, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Fallen, fallen is Babylon the Great! And she has become a [xref]b[/xref]dwelling place of demons and a [note]2[/note]hold of every [xref]c[/xref]unclean spirit and a [note]2[/note]hold of every unclean and hateful bird;
verse.note: This is the fall of the material Babylon, the city of Rome, at the end of the great tribulation (see notes [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 14[/link], [link]19[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 16[/link], and [link chapter="17"]5[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link]). The Bible reveals three aspects of Babylon: (1) the literal aspect, referring to ancient Babel or Babylon ([link]Gen. 11:9[/link]), today's Iraq; (2) the religious aspect, referring to the Roman Catholic Church, spoken of in [link]ch. 17[/link]; and (3) the material aspect, referring to the city of Rome, mentioned in this chapter.
Or, prison.

verse.text: For all the nations [note]1[/note]have [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]drunk of the wine of the fury of her fornication, and the kings of the earth have [xref]b[/xref]committed fornication with her, and the [xref]c[/xref]merchants of the earth have become [xref]d[/xref]rich by the power of her [xref]e[/xref]luxury.
verse.note: Some MSS read, have fallen by.

Rome, signified by Babylon the Great in a twofold way, has both religious and material aspects. [i]The nations have drunk of the wine[/i]...and the kings of the earth have committed... refers to the religious aspect ([link]14:8[/link]; [link]17:2[/link]), while [i]the merchants of the earth have become[/i]... refers to the material aspect.

verse.text: And I heard another voice out of heaven, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Come out of her, My people, that you do not participate in her sins and that you do not receive her plagues;
verse.note: Since Babylon the Great has two aspects, to come out of her is to come out of both the religious Babylon and the material Babylon. God's people should come out of these two aspects of Babylon.

verse.text: For her sins have [note]1[/note]accumulated up [xref]a[/xref]to heaven, and God has [xref]b[/xref]remembered her [note]2[/note]unrighteousnesses.
verse.note: Lit., joined together.
Or, crimes, misdeeds.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Pay her back even as she has paid, and [note]1[/note]double [i]to her[/i] double according to her works; in the [xref]b[/xref]cup which she has mixed, mix to her double.
verse.note: Double recompense was required according to the Levitical law ([link]Exo. 22:4[/link], [link]7[/link], [link]9[/link]). Here, that double recompense is doubled.

verse.text: As much as she has [xref]a[/xref]glorified herself and lived [xref]b[/xref]luxuriously, as much torment and sorrow give to her; for she says in her heart, I sit a [xref]c[/xref]queen, and I am not a [xref]d[/xref]widow, and I shall by no means see sorrow.

Therefore in [xref]a[/xref]one day her plagues will come, death and sorrow and famine, and she will be utterly [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]burned with fire; for the Lord God who [xref]c[/xref]judges her is strong.
verse.note: In [link]17:16[/link] the religious Babylon is utterly burned. Here, the material Babylon is utterly burned. [link]Chapter 17[/link] records the destruction of the religious Babylon; [link]ch. 18[/link], the destruction of the material Babylon.

verse.text: And the kings of the earth, who have [xref]a[/xref]committed fornication and lived luxuriously with her, will [xref]b[/xref]weep and lament over her when they see the [xref]c[/xref]smoke of her burning,

[xref]a[/xref]Standing afar off because of fear of her torment, saying, [xref]b[/xref]Woe, woe, the [xref]c[/xref]great city, [xref]d[/xref]Babylon, the strong city, for in [xref]e[/xref]one hour your [xref]f[/xref]judgment has come!
And the merchants of the earth weep and mourn over her because no one buys their cargo anymore:

[note]1[/note]Cargo of gold and silver and precious stone and pearls and fine linen and purple and silk and scarlet, and every [i]kind[/i] of [note]2[/note]thyine wood, and every vessel of ivory, and every vessel of most precious wood and brass and iron and marble,
verse.note: That the cargo listed in [link]vv. 12-13[/link] consists of various material things proves that Babylon the Great in this chapter is the material Babylon. The cargo is of seven categories: (1) ornaments, from [i]gold[/i] to [i]pearls;[/i] (2) clothing, from [i]fine linen[/i] to [i]scarlet;[/i] (3) furniture and decorations, from [i]thyine wood[/i] to [i]marble;[/i] (4) spices, from [i]cinnamon[/i] to [i]frankincense;[/i] (5) food, from [i]wine[/i] to [i]sheep;[/i] (6) transportation, [i]horses[/i] and [i]chariots;[/i] and (7) employment, [i]slaves[/i] and [i]souls of men.[/i]
An aromatic and coniferous tree.

verse.text: And cinnamon and [note]1[/note]amomum and incense and ointment and frankincense and wine and oil and fine flour and wheat and cattle and sheep, and [i]cargo[/i] of horses and chariots and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]slaves and [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]souls of men.
verse.note: A spice plant.
Lit., bodies; referring to the bodies of those who are in slavery.

Of the cargo sold by Babylon, the first item is gold and the last is the souls of men. [i]Souls of men[/i] refers to men who sell themselves for employment. This depicts not only the coming Babylon but also today's world. People sell their soul, their life, i.e., themselves, to their occupation, neglecting God and their eternal destiny.

verse.text: And the ripe fruits of your soul's lust have gone away from you, and all the sumptuous and splendid things have perished from you; and [i]men[/i] will find them no more at all.
The merchants of these things, who became rich by her, will stand afar off because of the fear of her torment, weeping and mourning,
Saying, Woe, woe, the great city, which was [xref]a[/xref]clothed in fine linen and purple and scarlet, and gilded with gold and precious stone and pearl;
For in one hour such great wealth has become [xref]a[/xref]desolate! And every ship captain and everyone sailing to a place and sailors and all who work on the sea stood afar off
And cried out, seeing the [xref]a[/xref]smoke of her burning, saying, What [i]city[/i] is like the great city?

And they cast dust on their heads and cried out, weeping and mourning, saying, Woe, woe, the great city, by which all those who have ships on the sea became rich from her [note]1[/note]wealth, for in [note]2[/note]one hour she has become desolate!
verse.note: Lit., costliness.

Antichrist and his armies will be destroyed by Christ in one hour ([link]17:12-14[/link]; [link]19:19-21[/link]), and the material Babylon the Great also will be destroyed by the Lord in one hour. Perhaps both of them will be destroyed by the Lord in the same hour of His coming to the earth in His shining glory ([link]18:1[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:8[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Be glad over her, O heaven and saints and [xref]b[/xref]apostles and prophets, because God has [note]1[/note]judged [xref]c[/xref]judgment for you upon her.
verse.note: This is a part of the answer to the martyrs' prayer in [link]6:9-10[/link].

verse.text: And a strong angel took up a [xref]a[/xref]stone like a great millstone and threw [i]it[/i] into the sea, saying, Thus will Babylon, the great city, be [note]1[/note]thrown down with violence and shall be found no more at all.
verse.note: This will probably occur through the earthquake mentioned in [link]16:18-20[/link].

verse.text: And the sound of [xref]a[/xref]harp-singers and musicians and flutists and trumpeters shall be heard no more at all in you, and no craftsman of any craft shall be found any more at all in you, and the [xref]b[/xref]sound of a millstone shall be heard no more at all in you,

And the [xref]a[/xref]light of a lamp shall shine no more at all in you, and the voice of bridegroom and bride shall be heard no more at all in you; for your merchants were the [xref]b[/xref]great ones of the earth, for by your [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]sorcery all the nations were deceived.
verse.note: Or, enchantment, poisonous charm.

verse.text: And in her was found the [xref]a[/xref]blood of prophets and of saints and of all who have been slain on the earth.

After these things I heard as it were a [xref]a[/xref]loud voice of a [xref]b[/xref]great multitude in heaven, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]Hallelujah! The [xref]d[/xref]salvation and the [xref]e[/xref]glory and the power are of our God.
verse.note: The word, from Hebrew, is a compound of [i]hallelu,[/i] praise, and [i]jah,[/i] a shortened form of the name Jehovah; hence, it means [i]praise Jehovah.[/i] It is used in [link]Psa. 104:35[/link] and at the beginning and end of [link]Psa. 146-150[/link].

verse.text: For [xref]a[/xref]true and righteous are His judgments; for He has judged the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]great harlot who corrupted the earth with her [xref]c[/xref]fornication, and He avenged the [xref]d[/xref]blood of His slaves [note]2[/note]at her hand.
verse.note: Babylon the Great, in both its religious aspect and its material aspect. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 18[/link].
Lit., from her hand.

verse.text: And a second time they said, Hallelujah! And her [xref]a[/xref]smoke goes up forever and ever.

And the [xref]a[/xref]twenty-four elders and the [xref]b[/xref]four living creatures [xref]c[/xref]fell down and worshipped God, [xref]d[/xref]who sits upon the throne, saying, [note]1[/note][xref]e[/xref]Amen, Hallelujah!
verse.note: The "Hallelujah" in [link]vv. 1[/link] and [link]3[/link] is the praise of the great multitude of saints. Here, the twenty-four angelic elders and the four living creatures say "Amen" to the praise of the saints, and then, like the saints, they praise by saying "Hallelujah!" Hence, taken together, this is the praise of the saints, angels, and all creatures; it is their praise to the Triune God from the past to the present and for eternity.

verse.text: And a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]voice came out from the throne, saying, [xref]b[/xref]Praise our God, all His slaves and those who [xref]c[/xref]fear Him, the small and the great.
verse.note: This may be the voice of Christ as the Angel of God ([link]7:2[/link]; [link]8:3[/link]; [link]10:1[/link]).

verse.text: And I heard as it were the [xref]a[/xref]voice of a great multitude and like the sound of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]many waters and like the sound of [note]1[/note]mighty [xref]c[/xref]thunders, saying, Hallelujah! For the [xref]d[/xref]Lord our God the Almighty [xref]e[/xref]reigns.
verse.note: Like the sound of many waters, the praise of the great multitude of saints proceeds continually, and like the sound of mighty thunders, it displays solemnity.

verse.text: Let us [xref]a[/xref]rejoice and exult, and let us give the glory to Him, for the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]marriage of the Lamb has come, and His [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]wife has made herself [xref]d[/xref]ready.
verse.note: After the rapture of the majority of the saints ([link]14:16[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:15-17[/link]) and the judgment at the judgment seat of Christ for the giving of the reward ([link]11:18[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]), the events that immediately follow should be the marriage of the Lamb, and then the destruction of Antichrist and Babylon the Great ([link]19:19-21[/link]; [link]18:1-19:4[/link]), which bring in the reign of God — the kingdom of God ([link]v. 6[/link]). For this reason, the great multitude of the saved rejoice and praise with hallelujahs ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]3[/link], [link]6[/link]), and the twenty-four elders and the four living creatures join them in praising God ([link]v. 4[/link]).[br][br]The reign of God, the kingdom, is related to the marriage of the Lamb, and the marriage of the Lamb is the issue of the completion of God's New Testament economy. God's economy in the New Testament is to obtain for Christ a bride, the church, through His redemption and divine life. By the continual working of the Holy Spirit through all the centuries, this goal will be attained at the end of this age. Then the bride, the overcoming believers, will be ready, and the kingdom of God will come. This corresponds with the Lord's prophecy in [link]Matt. 26:29[/link].

[i]His wife[/i] refers to the church ([link]Eph. 5:24-25[/link], [link]31-32[/link]), the bride of Christ ([link]John 3:29[/link]). However, according to [link]vv. 8-9[/link], the wife, the bride of Christ, here consists only of the overcoming believers during the millennium; whereas the bride, the wife, in [link]21:2[/link] is composed of all the saved saints after the millennium for eternity. The readiness of the bride depends on the maturity in life of the overcomers. Furthermore, the overcomers are not separate individuals but a corporate bride. For this aspect, building is needed. The overcomers not only are mature in life but also are built together as one bride.

verse.text: And it was given to her that she should be [xref]a[/xref]clothed in fine linen, bright [i]and[/i] [note]1[/note]clean; for the fine linen is the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]righteousnesses of the saints.
verse.note: Or, pure. [i]Clean[/i] refers to the nature, whereas [i]bright[/i] refers to the expression.

Or, righteous acts. The righteousnesses (plural) here are not the righteousness (i.e., Christ) that we received for our salvation ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). The righteousness we received for our salvation is objective and enables us to meet the requirement of the righteous God, whereas here the righteousnesses of the overcoming saints are subjective ([link]Phil. 3:9[/link]) and enable them to meet the requirement of the overcoming Christ. In [link]Psa. 45:13-14[/link] the queen has two garments: one corresponds with the objective righteousness, which is for our salvation, and the other with the subjective righteousnesses, which are for our victory. The second garment is equivalent to the wedding garment in [link]Matt. 22:11-12[/link].

verse.text: And he said to me, Write, [xref]a[/xref]Blessed are they who are called to the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]marriage [note]2[/note]dinner of the Lamb. And he said to me, These are the [xref]c[/xref]true words of God.
verse.note: The marriage dinner of the Lamb here is the wedding feast in [link]Matt. 22:2[/link]. It will be a reward to the overcoming believers. Only the overcomers will be called to it; not all the saved ones will participate in it. The five foolish virgins in [link]Matt. 25:8-13[/link] will miss it. However, after being dealt with by the Lord in the kingdom age, they will participate in the New Jerusalem for eternity. Hence, to be called to the marriage dinner of Christ, which will usher the overcoming believers into the enjoyment of the millennium, is to be blessed. The overcoming believers, who will be called to the marriage dinner of the Lamb, will also be the bride of the Lamb.
The chief meal, taken usually in the evening.

verse.text: And I [xref]a[/xref]fell before his feet to worship him. And he said to me, Do not do this. I am your fellow slave and [i]a fellow slave[/i] of your brothers who have the [xref]b[/xref]testimony of Jesus. [xref]c[/xref]Worship God. For the testimony of Jesus is the [note]1[/note]spirit of the [xref]d[/xref]prophecy.
verse.note: The spirit of the prophecy is the reality, substance, disposition, and characteristic of the prophecy. Thus, the testimony of Jesus is the reality, substance, disposition, and characteristic of the prophecy of this book.

verse.text: And I saw [xref]a[/xref]heaven opened, and behold, a [xref]b[/xref]white horse, and [note]1[/note]He who sits on it called [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Faithful and True, and in [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]righteousness He judges and makes [xref]e[/xref]war.
verse.note: After the marriage dinner, Christ will come as a fighting General with His bride (the overcoming believers called to the marriage dinner) as His army to fight against Antichrist and the kings under him with their armies at Armageddon.

Christ is faithful both to God and to those who believe in Him. In His faithfulness He defeats and destroys those who oppose God and persecute the believers. He is also true in carrying out God's economy and in caring for those who believe in Him.

Christ is faithful and true both to God and to His believers, and He is righteous to those who oppose and rebel against God. In righteousness He will defeat Antichrist and judge the rebels who follow him.

verse.text: And His [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]eyes are a flame of fire, and on His head are [note]2[/note]many [xref]b[/xref]diadems, [i]and[/i] He has a [xref]c[/xref]name written [note]3[/note]which no one knows but Himself.
verse.note: Christ's flaming eyes are for the carrying out of His judgment.

Because Christ has been crowned with many kinds of glory ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:11[/link] and note 6), He wears many diadems. Every kind of glory is a diadem. These crowns of glory are the issues of the things that Christ accomplished. In the glorious issues of His accomplishments He will fight for God and destroy all those who rebel against God, putting them to shame for eternity.
This indicates that there are certain aspects of Christ that we have not experienced and that only He Himself knows. It also indicates that the Christ whom we experience is inexhaustible.

verse.text: And He is clothed with a [xref]a[/xref]garment [note]1[/note]dipped in blood; and His name is called the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Word of God.
verse.note: Christ's being clothed with a garment dipped in blood is related to His treading the winepress of the fury of the wrath of God ([link]v. 15[/link]; [link]Isa. 63:1-3[/link]) at Armageddon ([link]16:14[/link], [link]16[/link]), where the blood will rise up to the bridles of the horses ([link]14:20[/link]).

The Word of God is the definition, explanation, and expression of God. As the Word of God, Christ imparts life as grace to God's chosen people in the Gospel of John ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]4[/link], [link]14[/link]), but He executes God's judgment upon the rebellious people in the Revelation of John.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]armies which are in heaven [xref]b[/xref]followed Him on white horses, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]dressed in fine linen, white [i]and[/i] clean.
verse.note: The armies here are the called and chosen believers in [link]17:14[/link] and those who are called to the marriage dinner of the Lamb in [link]v. 9[/link], that is, those who constitute the bride of Christ.
The garment of the overcoming believers qualifies them both to attend the marriage dinner of the Lamb ([link]vv. 8-9[/link]) and to fight with the Lord against His enemy.

verse.text: And out of His [xref]a[/xref]mouth proceeds a sharp [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]sword, that with it He might [xref]c[/xref]smite the nations; and He will [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]shepherd them with an iron rod; and He treads the [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]winepress of the fury of the wrath of God the [xref]f[/xref]Almighty.
verse.note: The sword, which proceeds out of the mouth of Christ, who is the Word of God, is the word that will judge the rebellious ([link]John 12:48[/link]).

To shepherd here is to rule; the iron rod signifies strong power. First, with His judging word Christ will smite the nations; then, with His strong power He will shepherd those who remain. His ruling with strong power is His shepherding. He will rule over the nations by shepherding them.
See note [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 14[/link].

verse.text: And He has on His [note]1[/note]garment and on His thigh a [xref]a[/xref]name written, [xref]b[/xref]KING OF KINGS AND LORD OF LORDS.
verse.note: Christ's garment signifies Christ's attributes, His character, especially His righteousness in His humanity; whereas His thigh signifies His standing strength, His stability. His title [i]King of kings and Lord of lords[/i] is exhibited in His righteousness and stability.

verse.text: And I saw an angel standing in the sun, and he cried out with a loud voice, saying to all the [xref]a[/xref]birds that fly in [xref]b[/xref]mid-heaven, Come here; gather yourselves to the [note]1[/note]great dinner of God,
verse.note: The great dinner of God is in contrast to the marriage dinner of the Lamb. The latter is for the called overcomers; the former is for the invited birds.

verse.text: That you may [xref]a[/xref]eat the flesh of kings and the flesh of [note]1[/note]generals and the flesh of mighty men and the flesh of horses and of those who sit on them and the flesh of all men, both [xref]b[/xref]free and slave and small and great.
verse.note: Lit., captains over one thousand men.

verse.text: And I saw the [xref]a[/xref]beast and the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]kings of the earth and their [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]armies [xref]d[/xref]gathered together to make [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]war with Him who sits on the horse and with His [xref]f[/xref]army.
verse.note: The kings of the earth ([link]16:12-14[/link]) include especially the ten kings under Antichrist ([link]17:12-14[/link]).
The armies include the two hundred million horsemen from the rising of the sun ([link]9:14-16[/link]; [link]16:12[/link]).

This war will take place at Armageddon ([link]16:14[/link], [link]16[/link]), at the valley of Jehoshaphat ([link]Joel 3:9-16[/link]; [link]Zech. 14:2-3[/link], [link]12-15[/link]), which is very close to Jerusalem. This war will be the treading of the great winepress of the fury of God (see [link]14:17-20[/link] and note [link]19[sup]1[/sup][/link] there).

verse.text: And the beast was seized, and with him the [xref]a[/xref]false prophet, who in his presence had done the [xref]b[/xref]signs by which he deceived those who received the [xref]c[/xref]mark of the beast and those who [xref]d[/xref]worshipped his image. These two were [note]1[/note][xref]e[/xref]cast alive into the [xref]f[/xref]lake of fire, which burns with [xref]g[/xref]brimstone.
verse.note: Antichrist and the false prophet will be the first to be cast into the lake of fire (cf. [link]20:10[/link], [link]15[/link]). Unlike all the others who perish, they will be cast alive into the lake of fire, without passing through death and resurrection.[br][br]At this point we can see that once the seventh trumpet is sounded, on the same day, the last day of the great tribulation, the following events will all take place: (1) the kingdom of the world will become the kingdom of Christ; (2) the dead saints will be resurrected and will be raptured with the living saints; (3) the two witnesses will be resurrected and raptured; (4) Christ will execute the judgment at His judgment seat for the rewarding of the overcomers; (5) the marriage of the Lamb and the overcomers will take place; (6) Christ and His newly-wed overcomers will come to the earth to defeat Antichrist and destroy those who destroy the earth in the war at Armageddon, and to cast Antichrist and the false prophet into the lake of fire; (7) by the war at Armageddon Christ will rescue Israel from Antichrist's besieging, and the whole house of Israel will repent and be saved; (8) the material Babylon the Great will be destroyed; and (9) at the same time the seven bowls will be poured out. The war at Armageddon will occur at the time of the sixth bowl. The various plagues of the seven bowls will be executed by God on the same day, perhaps at the time when the few positive events mentioned previously will occur.

verse.text: And the rest were killed with the [xref]a[/xref]sword which proceeds out of the mouth of Him who sits on the horse, and all the birds were filled with their flesh.
And I saw an angel coming down out of heaven, having the [xref]a[/xref]key of the [xref]b[/xref]abyss and a great [xref]c[/xref]chain in his hand.
And he laid hold of the [xref]a[/xref]dragon, the ancient [xref]b[/xref]serpent, who is the Devil and Satan, and [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]bound him for a thousand years
verse.note: After the defeat of Antichrist, Satan is bound and imprisoned that the rebellious earth may be cleared up and the kingdom of Christ may come ([link]vv. 4-6[/link]).

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]cast him into the abyss and [xref]b[/xref]shut [i]it[/i] and sealed [i]it[/i] over him, that he might not [xref]c[/xref]deceive the nations any longer until the thousand years were completed; after these things he must be [xref]d[/xref]loosed for a little while.

And I saw [xref]a[/xref]thrones, and [note]1[/note]they sat upon them, and judgment was given to them. And I saw the [xref]b[/xref]souls of [note]2[/note]those who had been beheaded because of the [xref]c[/xref]testimony of Jesus and because of the word of God, and [i]of[/i] [note]3[/note][i]those[/i] who had not [xref]d[/xref]worshipped the beast nor his image, and had not received the [xref]e[/xref]mark on their forehead and on their hand; and they [note]4[/note]lived and [xref]f[/xref]reigned with Christ for a thousand years.
verse.note: [i]They[/i] refers to the overcomers. They are now sitting upon thrones, and authority to judge has been given to them. Having authority to judge means having the kingdom (cf. [link]Dan. 7:10[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]22[/link]). This indicates that they have received the kingdom and are enjoying it.
These are the ones who are martyred throughout the church age, as mentioned in [link]6:9[/link].
These are the ones who are martyred during the great tribulation ([link]13:7[/link], [link]15[/link]).
I.e., were resurrected.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rest of the dead did not live [i]again[/i] until the thousand years were completed. This is the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]first resurrection.
verse.note: These are the unsaved who will participate in the resurrection of judgment after the millennium ([link]John 5:28-29[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:23-24[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:12[/link]).

Or, best. The first resurrection is the best one. It is not only the resurrection of life ([link]John 5:29[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:23b[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 4:16[/link]) but also the resurrection of reward ([link]Luke 14:14[/link]), the out-resurrection, i.e., the outstanding resurrection, which the apostle Paul sought ([link]Phil. 3:11[/link]), the resurrection of kingship as a reward to the overcomers, which enables them to reign as co-kings with Christ in the millennial kingdom ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]6[/link]). Hence, blessed is he who has part in the first resurrection ([link]v. 6[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Blessed and [xref]b[/xref]holy is he who has part in the [note]2[/note]first resurrection; over these the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]second death has no authority, but they will be [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]priests of God and of Christ and will reign with Him for [note]5[/note]a thousand years.
verse.note: Or, happy. The highest blessing is to inherit the kingdom of God manifested on earth and even to be the co-kings of Christ within the kingdom.

Not only the resurrected overcomers, such as the man-child in [link]12:5[/link] and the later martyrs in [link]15:2[/link], but also the raptured living overcomers, such as the firstfruits in [link]14:1-5[/link], have part in the issue of the first resurrection.
See note [link]11[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

The overcomers will be priests, drawing near to God and Christ, and kings, reigning over the nations with Christ in the millennium ([link]2:26-27[/link]; [link]12:5[/link]). As priests, they satisfy God and Christ, who enjoy their service, and as kings they reign for God and represent God, shepherding man for man's enjoyment and satisfaction. This is a reward to the overcomers. The believers who are defeated in this age will forfeit this reward. However, after being dealt with by the Lord in the millennium, these defeated ones will participate in the blessing of this reward, which will be to serve God and represent God in the kingship in the new heaven and new earth for eternity ([link]22:3[/link], [link]5[/link]).
Some ancient authorities have the definite article [i]the.[/i]

verse.text: And when the thousand years are completed, Satan will be released from his [note]1[/note]prison
verse.note: The abyss ([link]v. 3[/link]) will be a temporary prison for the devil. After the thousand years, he will be released from his prison to be God's tool to test mankind for the last time.

verse.text: And will go out to [xref]a[/xref]deceive the nations which are in the [xref]b[/xref]four corners of the earth, [note]1[/note]Gog and [xref]c[/xref]Magog, to [xref]d[/xref]gather them together for the [note]2[/note]war. Their number is like [i]that of[/i] the sand of the sea.
verse.note: Gog and Magog, according to [link]Ezek. 38:2-3[/link] and [link]39:1-2[/link], must be Russia. [link]Ezekiel 38:2[/link] indicates that Gog and Magog are of Rosh, Meshech, and Tubal, which correspond with Russia, Moscow, and Tobolsk. [link]Ezekiel 39:2[/link] refers to these places as "the remotest parts of the north." What is mentioned concerning Gog and Magog in [link]Ezek. 38[/link] and [link book="Ezek."]39[/link] will occur before the millennium, whereas what is recorded concerning them in this chapter will take place after the millennium. This verse shows that Satan's deceiving of the nations that are in the four corners of the earth is his deceiving of Gog and Magog. This may indicate that in mankind's last rebellion against God, which will be instigated by Satan, Gog and Magog will take the lead and the nations will follow.

This will be the last war on earth. It will be caused by mankind's last rebellion, which will be instigated by Satan, God's enemy, after the millennium. Although mankind will be in a restored state for one thousand years, man's rebellious nature will still remain. It will be exposed by Satan's last instigation and will be purged away by the Lord's final judgment on mankind.

verse.text: And they [xref]a[/xref]went up upon the breadth of the earth and surrounded the [note]1[/note]camp of the saints and the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]beloved city; and [xref]c[/xref]fire came down [note]2[/note]out of heaven and devoured them.
verse.note: The camp of the saints is the lodging place of the overcoming believers, who compose the heavenly armies ([link]19:14[/link]) camping on earth. The beloved city is the city of Jerusalem, the dwelling place of the remnant of Israel. The overcoming believers and the remnant of Israel are God's faithful people on earth in the millennium, who stand with God and for God. At the end of the millennium, Satan will instigate rebellious mankind from the uttermost parts of the north to attack God's people.
Some ancient authorities insert, from God.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]devil, who deceived them, was cast into the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]lake of fire and brimstone, where also the beast and the false prophet were; and they will be [xref]c[/xref]tormented day and night forever and ever.
verse.note: The lake of fire has been prepared for the devil and his angels ([link]Matt. 25:41[/link]). However, the beast and the false prophet, as well as the "goats" in [link]Matt. 25:32-33[/link], [link]41[/link], are cast into it a thousand years earlier than the devil ([link]19:20[/link]). After the thousand years, the devil also is thrown into it.

verse.text: And I saw a great [note]1[/note]white throne and [note]2[/note]Him who sat upon it, from whose face [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]earth and heaven fled away, and no place was found for them.
verse.note: White here signifies righteous, indicating that the Lord's great throne, which is for His judgment, is righteous.

[i]Him[/i] must refer to the Lord Jesus. God the Father has given all judgment to the Son ([link]John 5:22[/link]) and has ordained Him to be the Judge of the living and the dead ([link]Acts 10:42[/link]; [link]17:31[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:1[/link]; [link]Rom. 2:16[/link]). [link]Matthew 25:31-46[/link] speaks of the Lord as the One who will judge the living before the millennium. Here, the Lord is the One who will judge the dead after the millennium.

The old heavens and the old earth will be changed ([link]Heb. 1:11-12[/link]). The old heavens will pass away, their elements being burned and dissolved, and the old earth will be burned up ([link]2 Pet. 3:10[/link]). Out of this change will issue the new heaven and new earth ([link]21:1[/link]) as the universe of the new creation, which will serve as the location for the New Jerusalem in eternity.

verse.text: And I saw the [xref]a[/xref]dead, the great and the small, [note]1[/note]standing before the throne, and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]scrolls were opened; and another [note]3[/note]scroll was opened, which is [xref]c[/xref][i]the book[/i] of life. And the dead were judged by the things which were written in the [note]2[/note]scrolls, [xref]d[/xref]according to their works.
verse.note: [i]Standing[/i] here indicates that the dead have been resurrected. This is the resurrection of the unbelievers, the resurrection of judgment, after the millennium ([link]John 5:28-29[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:23-24[/link]).
These scrolls are the record of the unbelievers' works and deeds; the unbelievers will be judged according to what is recorded in the scrolls.
This is the record of the names of the believers ([link]13:8[/link]; [link]17:8[/link]; [link]Luke 10:20[/link]).

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sea gave up the dead which were in it, and death and [xref]b[/xref]Hades gave up the dead which were in them; and they were judged, each [i]of them,[/i] according to their works.
verse.note: Since the dead unbelievers who were drowned in the sea are included among those in Hades, the dead given up by the sea must not include any unbelieving human beings; they may be the spirits (the demons today — [link]Matt. 8:31-32[/link]; [link]12:43[/link]) of the living beings of the preadamic age (see [i]Life-study of Genesis,[/i] Message Two). This may indicate that today's demons will be judged at the great white throne along with the unbelieving human beings.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]death and Hades were cast into the [xref]b[/xref]lake of fire. This is the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]second death, the lake of fire.
verse.note: The lake of fire is the "trash can" for the entire universe, into which all negative things, including death and Hades, will be cast. Death will be the last enemy destroyed by the Lord ([link]1 Cor. 15:26[/link]).

In the first death, the soul and spirit of fallen men are separated from their body and perish in the section of suffering in Hades ([link]Luke 16:22-24[/link]). In the second death, their soul and spirit, after being rejoined to their body in resurrection, are cast with their body into the lake of fire. This means that the unbelievers' whole being — spirit, soul, and body — will perish in eternal torment in the lake of fire.

verse.text: And if [note]1[/note]anyone was not found [xref]a[/xref]written in the [note]2[/note]book of life, he was cast into the [note]3[/note]lake of fire.
verse.note: The perishing unbelievers will be judged according to the scrolls, which are a record of their works ([link]vv. 12-13[/link]), but they will be cast into the lake of fire according to the book of life. This indicates that they are condemned by the Lord because of their evil deeds but perish because of their unbelief, which issues in their not having their names written in the book of life. Not believing in the Lord Jesus is the unique sin that causes people to perish ([link]John 16:9[/link]).
Lit., scroll.

The lake of fire has been prepared for the devil and his angels ([link]Matt. 25:41[/link]). Since the unbelievers have followed the devil, they will share the devil's judgment ([link]John 16:11[/link]) and will become joint partakers of the devil's eternal torment. The demons, also having followed the devil, will share the same destiny.

verse.text: And I saw a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]new heaven and a new earth; for the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]first heaven and the first earth passed away, and the [note]3[/note]sea is no more.
verse.note: In eternity past God purposed to have a corporate expression that He might be fully expressed and glorified ([link]Eph. 3:9-11[/link]; [link]1:9-12[/link]). For this, He created the heavens, the earth, and mankind. After the creation of the world, there are four dispensations: the dispensation of the patriarchs, from Adam to Moses ([link]Rom. 5:14[/link]); the dispensation of law, from Moses to Christ ([link]John 1:17[/link]); the dispensation of grace, from Christ's first coming to the restoration of all things at Christ's second coming ([link]Acts 3:20-21[/link]); and the dispensation of the kingdom, from Christ's second coming to the end of the millennium ([link]11:15[/link]; [link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). God uses these four dispensations to perfect and complete His chosen people that they may be His eternal corporate expression for the accomplishing of His purpose. All four dispensations belong to the old heaven and old earth. Although the dispensation of the kingdom is the dispensation of restoration, it still will take place in the old heaven and old earth, because God's perfecting and completing work in His chosen people will not be finished until the end of that dispensation. When God finishes this work through the dispensation of the kingdom, the old heaven and old earth will pass away through fire and be renewed to become the new heaven and new earth ([link]2 Pet. 3:10-13[/link]), into which the New Jerusalem will come to be God's eternal expression.

According to the principle revealed in the Bible, God does not want the first, whether man or thing ([link]Exo. 12:12[/link]), but the second. Hence, whatever is the first, whether heaven, earth, man, or thing, will be annulled ([link]v. 4[/link]; cf. [link]1 Cor. 15:47[/link]; [link]Heb. 8:7[/link], [link]13[/link]). If the Greek word for [i]first[/i] is rendered [i]former,[/i] the spiritual significance is missed.

The sea is a result of the waters of judgment, which God used to judge the preadamic world (see [i]Life-study of Genesis,[/i] Message Two). The work of God's re-creation was to recover the land by restricting the result of the waters of judgment ([link]Gen. 1:9-10[/link]; [link]Jer. 5:22[/link]). The living creatures of the preadamic world, after being judged by the waters, became the sea's inhabitants, the demons. After they have been dealt with by Christ and His believers ([link]Matt. 8:29-32[/link]; [link]Luke 10:17[/link]; [link]Acts 16:16-18[/link]; [link]19:12[/link]) and the sea has given them up to the judgment of the great white throne ([link]20:13[/link]), the sea will not be needed. Since the work of God's re-creation, God's intention has been to abolish the sea by dealing with Satan and his demons. Hence, [i]the sea is no more[/i] indicates that Satan and his evil followers will all be dealt with and will not be found in the new heaven and new earth.

verse.text: And I saw the [xref]a[/xref]holy city, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]New Jerusalem, [note]2[/note]coming down out of heaven from God, [xref]c[/xref]prepared as a [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]bride adorned for her [xref]e[/xref]husband.
verse.note: The revelation of this book is composed of signs (see note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]). Because of the profundity of the great and important matters in this book, it is difficult for man to speak of them exhaustively in plain words. Thus, all these matters are symbolized and depicted by signs, such as the lampstands, signifying the churches, and stars, signifying the messengers of the churches ([link]ch. 1[/link]); Jezebel, signifying the degraded, fornicating Roman Church ([link]ch. 2b[/link]); jasper and precious stones, signifying life and the redeeming God ([link]4:3[/link]); the Lion and the Lamb, signifying the overcoming and redeeming Christ ([link]ch. 5[/link]); the four horses, signifying the gospel, war, famine, and the spreading abroad of death ([link]ch. 6a[/link]); the universal woman, signifying God's redeemed throughout the generations, her child, signifying the strong, overcoming ones among God's redeemed, and the dragon, the serpent, signifying the cruel and subtle Satan, the devil ([link]ch. 12[/link]); the beast out of the sea, signifying Antichrist, and the beast out of the earth, signifying the false prophet ([link]ch. 13[/link]); the harvest, signifying the people growing under God's cultivation, and the firstfruits, signifying the ones who ripen early among those who are growing under God's cultivation ([link]ch. 14[/link]); Babylon the Great, signifying Rome, in both its religious aspect and its material aspect ([link]chs. 17-18[/link]); and the bride, signifying the saints who are mature and are prepared to be Christ's counterpart (ch. 19a). Besides these, there are many other signs. The final sign, which is also the greatest, is the New Jerusalem, signifying the composition of the totality of God's redeemed saints throughout the generations, who have been regenerated, transformed, and glorified. It is not a material, lifeless city but a corporate living person as the bride, having Christ, such a wonderful person, as her husband ([link]v. 2[/link]).[br][br]The New Jerusalem is a living composition of all the saints redeemed by God throughout all generations. It is the bride of Christ as His counterpart ([link]John 3:29[/link]) and the holy city of God as His habitation, His tabernacle ([link]v. 3[/link]). This is the heavenly Jerusalem ([link]Heb. 12:22[/link]), which God has prepared for us and which Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob long after ([link]Heb. 11:10[/link], [link]16[/link]). This is also the Jerusalem which is above and which is our mother ([link]Gal. 4:26[/link]). As the bride of Christ, the New Jerusalem comes out of Christ, her Husband, and becomes His counterpart, just as Eve came out of Adam, her husband, and became his counterpart ([link]Gen. 2:21-24[/link]). She is prepared by participating in the riches of the life and nature of Christ. As the holy city of God, she is wholly sanctified unto God and fully saturated with God's holy nature to be His habitation.[br][br]In both the Old Testament and the New Testament, God likens His chosen people to a spouse ([link]Isa. 54:6[/link]; [link]Jer. 3:1[/link]; [link]Ezek. 16:8[/link]; [link]Hosea 2:19[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:31-32[/link]) and a dwelling place for Himself ([link]Exo. 29:45-46[/link]; [link]Num. 5:3[/link]; [link]Ezek. 43:7[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]Psa. 68:18[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:16-17[/link]; [link]6:19[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 6:16[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]). The spouse is for His satisfaction in love, and the dwelling place is for His rest in expression. Both of these aspects will be ultimately consummated in the New Jerusalem. In her, God will have the fullest satisfaction in love and the utmost rest in expression for eternity.

After all God's redeemed saints are raptured to the heavens, they will constitute the New Jerusalem, which comes down out of heaven from God. This indicates that our dwelling place for eternity will not be heaven but the New Jerusalem on the new earth.

The New Jerusalem is a bride, indicating that she is not a material city but a corporate person. To Christ she is a bride for His satisfaction; to God she is a tabernacle in which He can rest and through which He can express Himself.

verse.text: And I heard a [xref]a[/xref]loud voice out of the throne, saying, Behold, the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]tabernacle of God is with men, and He will [xref]c[/xref]tabernacle with them, and [xref]d[/xref]they will be His peoples, and God Himself will be with them [i]and be[/i] their God.
verse.note: As God's habitation, the New Jerusalem will be the tabernacle of God with men for eternity. The tabernacle made by Moses was a type of this tabernacle ([link]Exo. 25:8-9[/link]; [link]Lev. 26:11[/link]). That type was first fulfilled in Christ as God's tabernacle among men ([link]John 1:14[/link]) and will eventually be fulfilled in the fullest way in the New Jerusalem, which will be the enlargement of Christ as God's dwelling place. This tabernacle will also be the eternal dwelling place of God's redeemed people. God will overshadow us with Christ. (See note [link]15[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].) Hence, the New Jerusalem will be a mutual habitation for both God and us.

verse.text: And He will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wipe away every tear from their eyes; and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]death will be no more, nor will there be [xref]c[/xref]sorrow or crying or pain anymore; for the [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]former things have passed away.
verse.note: In the new heaven and new earth there will be full satisfaction and rest; there will be no more cause for tears.
Since death will be wholly swallowed up by life ([link]1 Cor. 15:54[/link]) and will be cast into the lake of fire ([link]20:14[/link]), in the new heaven and new earth there will be no more death.
Lit., first.

verse.text: And He [xref]a[/xref]who sits on the throne said, Behold, I make all things [xref]b[/xref]new. And He said, Write, for these words are [xref]c[/xref]faithful and true.

And He said to me, [note]1[/note]They have come to pass. I am the [xref]a[/xref]Alpha and the Omega, the [xref]b[/xref]Beginning and the End. I will give to him who [xref]c[/xref]thirsts from the [xref]d[/xref]spring of the [xref]e[/xref]water of life freely.
verse.note: [i]They[/i] refers to [i]these words[/i] in [link]v. 5[/link].

verse.text: He who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]overcomes will inherit these things, and [xref]b[/xref]I will be God to him, and he will be a [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]son to Me.
verse.note: The meaning of [i]overcomes[/i] here is different from that in [link]chs. 2[/link] and [link book="Rev."]3[/link], where the word is used seven times. Here it means to overcome by believing, as in [link]1 John 5:4-5[/link]. The overcoming in [link]chs. 2[/link] and [link book="Rev."]3[/link] qualifies the overcoming believers to participate in the enjoyment of the millennial kingdom as a particular reward in God's dispensational administration, whereas the overcoming here qualifies all believers to participate in the New Jerusalem with all its enjoyment as the common portion of God's eternal salvation.

The peoples in [link]v. 3[/link] will be the nations in [link]v. 24[/link]. In the new heaven and new earth they will be God's people and not God's sons. They will live on the new earth outside the New Jerusalem and will enjoy the common blessings in the new heaven and new earth. (See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup][/link].) [i]Son[/i] in this verse does not refer to God's people but to God's redeemed saints throughout the generations. The sons of God will dwell in the New Jerusalem, participate in all its enjoyment, serve God and the Lamb, and reign for eternity ([link]22:3-5[/link]).

verse.text: But the cowardly and unbelieving and [xref]a[/xref]abominable and murderers and [xref]b[/xref]fornicators and sorcerers and idolaters and all the [note]1[/note]false, their part will be in the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]lake which burns with fire and brimstone, which is the [xref]d[/xref]second death.
verse.note: I.e., liars.

In the old heaven and old earth there is the sea of water to hold the result of God's judgment, whereas in the new heaven and new earth there will be the lake of fire to replace the sea. All negative and filthy things, after being judged by God, will be cast into the lake of fire, where they will suffer the second death and be tormented by being burned in fire and brimstone for eternity ([link]14:10-11[/link]). According to [link]22:15[/link], the lake of fire will be outside the New Jerusalem, as Gehenna (which signifies the lake of fire — [link]Matt. 5:22[/link] and note 8), that is, as Topheth, a place for filthy things ([link]Jer. 19:11-13[/link]), was outside the old Jerusalem ([link]2 Kings 23:10[/link]; [link]Isa. 30:33[/link]). The lake of fire is much more restricted than the sea of water.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]one of the [xref]a[/xref]seven angels who had the seven bowls full of the seven last plagues came and spoke with me, saying, [xref]b[/xref]Come here; I will show you the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]bride, the [xref]d[/xref]wife of the Lamb.
verse.note: It was one of the seven angels who executed the seven last plagues who showed the New Jerusalem to John. This signifies that the judgment of the seven bowls is for the New Jerusalem.

A bride is mainly for the wedding day, while a wife is for the entire life. The New Jerusalem will be the bride in the millennium for one thousand years, which is like one day ([link]2 Pet. 3:8[/link]), and will be the wife in the new heaven and new earth for eternity, to the ages of the ages without end.

verse.text: And he [xref]a[/xref]carried me away [xref]b[/xref]in spirit onto a [note]1[/note]great and high mountain and showed me the [xref]c[/xref]holy city, Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God,
verse.note: The great and high mountain is in contrast to the wilderness in [link]17:3[/link]. That he might see Babylon, the great harlot, John was carried to the wilderness. That he might see the bride, the New Jerusalem, John was carried to a great and high mountain. We need to be lifted up to a "high mountain" that we may see God's dwelling place for the fulfilling of His eternal purpose.

verse.text: Having the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory of God. Her [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]light was like a most [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]precious stone, like a [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]jasper stone, as clear as [xref]e[/xref]crystal.
verse.note: The glory of God is the expression of God, God expressed. We have been predestined for this glory and called to this glory ([link]1 Cor. 2:7[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 5:10[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 2:12[/link]). We are being transformed into this glory ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]) and will be brought into it ([link]Heb. 2:10[/link]). Eventually, we will be glorified with Christ ([link]Rom. 8:17[/link], [link]30[/link]) and bear the glory of God for God's expression in the New Jerusalem.

Lit., luminary, or, light-bearer. Today the believers, as children of light ([link]Eph. 5:8[/link]), are the light of the world ([link]Matt. 5:14[/link]), shining in the midst of a crooked and perverted generation ([link]Phil. 2:15[/link]). Eventually, the New Jerusalem, as a composition of all the saints, will be the light-bearer, shining forth God as light over the nations around her ([link]v. 24[/link]).

The precious stone is not the light but the light-bearer. It does not have light in itself, but the light, which is God, has been wrought into it and shines out through it. This indicates that since we are part of the coming New Jerusalem, we must be transformed into precious stones, with God being wrought into our being as the shining light, that we may be the light-bearer shining as God's expression.
God's appearance is like jasper ([link]4:3[/link] and note 1). The light of the New Jerusalem is like jasper stone. The New Jerusalem bears the appearance of God and expresses God by her shining.

verse.text: It had a [note]1[/note]great and high [xref]a[/xref]wall and had [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]twelve [xref]c[/xref]gates, and at the gates twelve [note]3[/note]angels, and names inscribed, which are the names of the twelve tribes of the sons of [note]4[/note]Israel:
verse.note: The wall is for separation and protection. New Jerusalem will be absolutely separated unto God and will fully protect the interests of God. Its wall will be great and high. Today all believers need such a great and high wall for their separation and protection.

The gates are for communication, for coming in and going out. Twelve is the number of absolute perfection and eternal completion in God's administration. Hence, [i]twelve gates[/i] indicates that the communication in the New Jerusalem is absolutely perfect and eternally complete for God's administration.

In God's eternal economy, angels are ministering spirits ([link]Heb. 1:14[/link]). They serve those who inherit salvation and who participate in the eternal blessing of the New Jerusalem, the center of the new heaven and new earth. They will be the gatekeepers of our possession, while we will be the enjoyers of the rich inheritance in God's eternal economy.

Israel here represents the law of the Old Testament, indicating that the law is represented at the gates of the New Jerusalem. The law watches and observes to insure that all the communications, the comings in and goings out, of the holy city meet the law's requirements. That the names of the twelve tribes of Israel are inscribed on the twelve gates signifies that the twelve tribes of Israel are the entrance into the holy city; as such, they lead people, through the preaching of the gospel, into the riches of the Triune God to enjoy the supply in the city.[br][br]The mentioning of Israel here also indicates that the New Jerusalem includes all the redeemed saints of the Old Testament.

verse.text: On the [note]1[/note]east three gates, and on the [note]1[/note]north three gates, and on the [note]1[/note]south three gates, and on the [note]1[/note]west three gates.
verse.note: The city lies square ([link]v. 16[/link]), with three gates on each of the four sides. The east side, at the front, toward the glory of the sunrise, ranks first; the north side, at the top, ranks second; the south side, at the bottom, ranks third; and the west side, at the rear, ranks fourth. The gates on the four sides face the four directions of the earth, signifying that the entrance into the holy city is available to all the peoples on earth. (Cf. the four heads of the river in [link]Gen. 2:10-14[/link].) That there are three gates on each side signifies that the three of the Trinity — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit — work together to bring people into the holy city. This is indicated in the three parables in [link]Luke 15[/link] and implied in the Lord's word in [link]Matt. 28:19[/link]. To be baptized into the Father, the Son, and the Spirit is the real entrance into the holy city. That there are three gates on each of the four sides, three times four being twelve, also implies that the Triune God is mingled with man, the creature. (The number four signifies the creatures — [link]4:6[/link].)

verse.text: And the wall of the city had twelve [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]foundations, and on them the twelve names of the [xref]b[/xref]twelve [note]2[/note]apostles of the Lamb.
verse.note: The foundations here are not the foundation that is Christ, mentioned in [link]1 Cor. 3:10-11[/link]. Rather, they are the twelve apostles of the Lamb. Today the church is built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets ([link]Eph. 2:20[/link]). Since in eternity there will be no more need for the prophets, the foundations of the holy city will consist only of the apostles.

The apostles here represent the grace of the New Testament, signifying that the New Jerusalem is built upon the grace of God. While entrance into the holy city is according to the law of God, the city is built upon the grace of God. [i]Apostles[/i] here implies that the New Jerusalem is composed not only of the Old Testament saints, represented by Israel, but also of the New Testament saints, represented by the apostles.

verse.text: And he who spoke with me had a [note]1[/note]golden reed as a measure that he might [xref]a[/xref]measure the city and its gates and its wall.
verse.note: A reed is for measuring, and measuring is for taking possession ([link]Ezek. 40:5[/link]; [link]Zech. 2:1-2[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:1[/link]). Since gold signifies the divine nature of God, [i]golden[/i] here indicates that the city, its gates, and its wall are measured according to God's divine nature. Anything that does not match the divine nature of God does not belong to the New Jerusalem.
