The entire city, with its gates and wall, can pass the measuring and testing of the divine nature of God; hence, it is fit to be God's possession.

verse.text: And the city lies [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]square, and its length is as great as the breadth. And he measured the city with the reed to [i]a length of[/i] [note]2[/note]twelve thousand [note]3[/note]stadia; the [note]4[/note]length and the breadth and the height of it are [xref]b[/xref]equal.
verse.note: [i]Square[/i] here indicates that the New Jerusalem is perfect and complete in every way, absolutely straight, and not in the least oblique.
Twelve thousand is one thousand times twelve. Since twelve signifies absolute perfection and eternal completion in God's administration, twelve thousand signifies a thousand times this.
A stadion equals about six hundred feet.

The dimensions of the Holy of Holies, in both the tabernacle and the temple, were equal in length, breadth, and height ([link]Exo. 26:2-8[/link]; [link]1 Kings 6:20[/link]). Hence, that the length and the breadth and the height of New Jerusalem are equal signifies that the entire New Jerusalem will be the Holy of Holies. In it, all God's redeemed ones will serve and worship God, will see and touch God's presence, and will live and dwell in God's presence for eternity.

verse.text: And he measured its wall, a [note]1[/note]hundred and forty-four cubits, [i]according to[/i] the measure of a [note]2[/note]man, that is, of an [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]angel.
verse.note: A hundred and forty-four is twelve times twelve. Twelve times twelve signifies the absolute perfection and eternal completion of absolute perfections and eternal completions. How perfect and complete is the wall of the holy city in God's eternal administration![br][br]The city proper is like a mountain with a height of twelve thousand stadia, whereas the wall itself, from the foundation to the top, has a height of a hundred and forty-four cubits.

It is in resurrection that man will be like the angels ([link]Matt. 22:30[/link]). Hence, [i]the measure of a man, that is, of an angel[/i] indicates that the wall of the city is not natural but is in resurrection.

verse.text: And the building work of its wall was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]jasper; and the city was [note]2[/note]pure [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]gold, like [note]4[/note]clear glass.
verse.note: Jasper is a transformed precious stone ([link]1 Cor. 3:12[/link]). God's appearance is like jasper ([link]4:3[/link] and note 1 there). The jasper wall signifies that the whole city, as the corporate expression of God in eternity, bears the appearance of God.
Or, clear, clean.

Since gold signifies the divine nature of God, the city's being of pure gold signifies that New Jerusalem is altogether of God's divine nature and takes God's divine nature as its element. [i]Pure gold, like clear glass[/i] indicates that the whole city is transparent and is not in the least opaque.
Or, pure, clean.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]foundations of the wall of the city were adorned with every [xref]b[/xref]precious stone: the first foundation was [note]2[/note]jasper; the second, sapphire; the third, chalcedony; the fourth, emerald;
verse.note: The New Jerusalem is a city of foundations ([link]Heb. 11:10[/link]). These are the twelve apostles of the Lamb ([link]v. 14[/link]), each of whom is signified by a precious stone. Peter, the first of the twelve apostles, was originally named Simon. When Simon was brought to the Lord, the Lord changed his name to Peter, meaning [i]a stone[/i] ([link]John 1:42[/link]). Later, the Lord called him by that name when He spoke concerning the building of His church ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link]). Precious stones are not created but are produced by the transforming of things created. All the apostles were created as clay, but they were regenerated and were transformed into precious stones for God's eternal building. Every believer needs to be thus regenerated and transformed that he may be a part of the New Jerusalem.[br][br]The colors of the foundation's twelve precious stones, which signify the twelve apostles, are as follows: the first stone is green, the second and third are blue, the fourth is green, the fifth and sixth are red, the seventh is yellow, the eighth is bluish green, the ninth is yellow, the tenth is apple-green, the eleventh and twelfth are purple. The twelve layers of the foundation in the above colors have the appearance of a rainbow, signifying that the city is built upon and secured by God's faithfulness in keeping His covenant ([link]Gen. 9:8-17[/link]) and that the foundation of the city is trustworthy and reliable.

The first layer of the wall's foundation, as well as the entire wall of New Jerusalem, is built with jasper ([link]v. 18[/link]). This indicates that the main material in the building of the holy city is jasper. Since jasper signifies God expressed in His transmittable glory ([link]4:3[/link]), the main function of the holy city is to express God in bearing His glory ([link]v. 11[/link]).

verse.text: The fifth, [xref]a[/xref]sardonyx; the sixth, sardius; the seventh, chrysolite; the eighth, beryl; the ninth, topaz; the tenth, chrysoprase; the eleventh, jacinth; the twelfth, amethyst.

And the [xref]a[/xref]twelve gates were twelve [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]pearls; each one of the gates was, respectively, of [note]2[/note]one pearl. And the [note]3[/note]street of the city was pure [xref]c[/xref]gold, like [note]4[/note]transparent glass.
verse.note: Pearls are produced by oysters in the waters of death. When an oyster is wounded by a grain of sand, it secretes its life-juice around the grain of sand and makes it into a precious pearl. This depicts Christ as the living One coming into the death waters, being wounded by us, and secreting His life over us to make us into precious pearls for the building of God's eternal expression. That the twelve gates of the holy city are twelve pearls signifies that regeneration through the death-overcoming and life-secreting Christ is the entrance into the city. This meets the requirement of the law, which is represented by Israel and is under the observing of the guarding angels ([link]v. 12[/link]).[br][br]The New Jerusalem is built of three kinds of precious materials, signifying that she is built with the Triune God. First, the city proper, with its street, is of pure gold ([link]vv. 18[/link], [link]21[/link]). Gold, the symbol of the divine nature of God, signifies the Father as the source, from whom the element for the substantial existence of the city is produced. Second, the twelve gates of the city are pearls, which signify the Son's overcoming death and life-imparting resurrection, through which entrance to the city is gained. Third, the wall of the city and its foundation are built of precious stones, signifying the Spirit's work of transforming the redeemed and regenerated saints into precious stones for the building of God's eternal habitation that they may express God corporately in His all-permeating glory. In the garden of Eden these three kinds of treasures merely existed as materials ([link]Gen. 2:11-12[/link]), whereas in the city of New Jerusalem these precious materials become a builded city for the fulfillment of God's eternal purpose, which is to have a corporate expression.

Each gate of the holy city is one pearl, signifying that the entrance to the city is unique and is once for all; that is, we can enter the city only through the once-for-all regeneration accomplished by Christ's overcoming death and life-imparting resurrection.

The gates are for the entrance into the city, whereas the street is for the daily walk, the daily living, in the city. The entrance into the city is through Christ's death and resurrection, whereas the daily walk, the daily living, in the city is according to the divine nature of God, signified by the street being of pure gold. After the saints enter through regeneration, they must daily live and walk in God's divine nature as the way. The divine nature of God is their pathway.

The pure gold, which symbolizes the street and the city proper of the New Jerusalem, is like clear glass ([link]v. 18[/link]), signifying that the whole city is transparent. Although the pearls may be opaque, every one of them is a great open gate, which will not be shut by day or by night ([link]v. 25[/link]).

verse.text: And I saw [note]1[/note]no [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]temple in it, for the [xref]b[/xref]Lord God the Almighty and the [xref]c[/xref]Lamb are its [note]2[/note][xref]d[/xref]temple.
verse.note: In the Old Testament the tabernacle of God was a precursor of the temple of God. New Jerusalem as the tabernacle of God ([link]v. 3[/link]) will be the temple of God. This indicates that in the new heaven and new earth the temple of God will be enlarged into a city. That the three dimensions of the city are equal ([link]v. 16[/link]) indicates that the city as a whole will be the Holy of Holies, the inner temple. Hence, there will be no temple in it.

The Greek word denotes the inner temple. This inner temple is the Lord God the Almighty and the Lamb, signifying that God and the Lamb Themselves will be the place in which we serve God. The holy city as the tabernacle of God is for God to dwell in, and God and the Lamb as the temple are for the redeemed saints to dwell in. In the new heaven and new earth, the New Jerusalem will be a mutual dwelling place for God and man for eternity.

verse.text: And the city has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]no need of the sun or of the moon that they should shine in it, for the [xref]b[/xref]glory of God illumined it, and its [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]lamp is the Lamb.
verse.note: In the millennium the light of the sun and the moon will be intensified ([link]Isa. 30:26[/link]). But in the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth there will be no need of the shining of the sun or of the moon. The sun and moon will be present in the new heaven and new earth, but their shining will not be needed in the New Jerusalem, for God, the divine light, will shine much more brightly there.

The Lamb as the lamp will shine with God as the light to illumine the city with the glory of God, the expression of the divine light. Since the holy city will be illumined by such a divine light, it will need no other light, whether created by God or made by man ([link]22:5[/link]).

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]nations will walk by its [note]2[/note]light; and the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]kings of the earth bring their [note]4[/note]glory into it.
verse.note: At the end of this age a great part of the inhabitants of the earth will be killed as a result of the sixth and seventh trumpets. The rest will be judged by Christ at the throne of His glory when He comes back to earth. The condemned ones, the "goats," will be cursed and will perish in the lake of fire, while the justified ones, the "sheep," will be blessed and will inherit the kingdom prepared for them from the foundation of the world ([link]Matt. 25:31-46[/link]). Unlike the New Testament believers, the "sheep" will not be saved and regenerated; they will only be restored to the original state of man as he was created by God. They will be the nations as citizens of the millennial kingdom, in which the overcoming believers will be the kings ([link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]) and the saved remnant of Israel will be the priests ([link]Zech. 8:20-23[/link]). After the millennial kingdom, a part of these nations, deceived by the devil, will rebel against the Lord and will be consumed by fire from heaven ([link]20:7-9[/link]). The rest will be transferred to the new earth to be the nations, which will live around the New Jerusalem and walk by its light. They will be the peoples mentioned in [link]vv. 3[/link] and [link]4[/link]. They, as created but unregenerated men, will be maintained to live forever in their created state through the healing of the leaves of the tree of life ([link]22:2[/link]). Even for them there will be no more death ([link]v. 4[/link]). Under the shining of the New Jerusalem with the divine glory, neither will they be in darkness.
Cf. [link]Isa. 2:5[/link].

The kings of the earth here are the kings of the nations in the new earth. The redeemed and regenerated saints will be kings over these kings ([link]22:5[/link]), and Christ will be the King of kings for eternity.
[i]Glory[/i] here refers to splendor ([link]Matt. 5:16[/link]; see note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 2[/link]).

verse.text: And its gates shall by [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]no means be shut by day, for there will be no [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]night there.
verse.note: The wall of the city will separate the city from the nations, but the gates will keep the city continually open to them.

In the new heaven and new earth there will still be the distinction between day and night, but in the New Jerusalem there will be no such distinction, for there, God Himself as the brighter light will shine continuously day and night.

verse.text: And they will bring the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]glory and the [note]2[/note]honor of the nations into it.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]4[/sup][/link].
[i]Honor[/i] refers to preciousness in status and dignity in position (cf. [link]Esth. 1:4[/link]).

verse.text: And anything [xref]a[/xref]common and he who makes an [xref]b[/xref]abomination and a [xref]c[/xref]lie shall by no means [xref]d[/xref]enter into it, but only [note]1[/note]those who are [xref]e[/xref]written in the Lamb's [note]2[/note]book of life.
verse.note: Since the nations living on the new earth outside the New Jerusalem will bring their glory and honor into the city, they surely are included among those who are written in the Lamb's book of life.
Lit., scroll.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]he [xref]a[/xref]showed me a [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]river of [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]water of life, bright as [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]crystal, [xref]e[/xref]proceeding out of the [note]5[/note][xref]f[/xref]throne of God and of the Lamb in the middle of its [note]6[/note][xref]g[/xref]street.
verse.note: [i]He[/i] refers to the angel in [link]21:9[/link].

The river here, typified by the rivers in [link]Gen. 2:10-14[/link], [link]Psa. 46:4[/link], and [link]Ezek. 47:5-9[/link], signifies the abundance of life in its flow. It is one river, flowing to the four corners of the holy city, like the one river in [link]Gen. 2:10-14[/link], which parts into four heads. As indicated in [link]John 7:38[/link], this one river with its riches becomes many rivers in our experience of the different aspects of the riches of God's Spirit of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]; [link]15:30[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 1:6[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 2:13[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:22-23[/link]).

The water of life is a symbol of God in Christ as the Spirit flowing Himself into His redeemed people to be their life and life supply. It is typified by the water that came out of the riven rock ([link]Exo. 17:6[/link]; [link]Num. 20:11[/link]) and symbolized by the water that flowed out of the pierced side of the Lord Jesus ([link]John 19:34[/link]). Here, the water of life becomes a river, proceeding out of the throne of God and of the Lamb to supply and saturate the entire New Jerusalem. Thus this city is filled with the divine life that it may express God in His glory of life.
The water of life is bright as crystal, having no dimness or opaqueness. When this water of life flows in us, it purifies us and makes us as transparent as crystal.

[i]The throne of God and of the Lamb,[/i] showing that there is one throne for both God and the Lamb, indicates that God and the Lamb are one — the Lamb-God, the redeeming God, God the Redeemer. In eternity the very God who sits on the throne is our redeeming God, from whose throne proceeds the river of water of life for our supply and satisfaction. This depicts how the Triune God — God, the Lamb, and the Spirit, who is symbolized by the water of life — dispenses Himself to His redeemed under His headship (implied in the authority of the throne) for eternity.

The street of the holy city is pure gold ([link]21:21[/link]). Gold symbolizes the divine nature. That the river of water of life proceeds "in the middle of its street" signifies that the divine life flows in the divine nature as the unique way for the daily life of God's redeemed people. Where the divine life flows, there the divine nature is as the holy way by which God's people walk; and where the holy way of the divine nature is, there the divine life is flowing. The divine life and the divine nature as the holy way always go together. Thus, God's river of water of life is available along this divine way, and we enjoy the river by walking in this way of life.

verse.text: And on this [xref]a[/xref]side and on that side of the river was the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]tree of life, producing twelve [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]fruits, yielding its fruit [note]3[/note]each [note]4[/note]month; and the [note]5[/note][xref]d[/xref]leaves of the tree are for the [xref]e[/xref]healing of the [xref]f[/xref]nations.
verse.note: That the one tree of life grows on the two sides of the river signifies that the tree of life is a vine that spreads and proceeds along the flow of the water of life for God's people to receive and enjoy. This tree fulfills for eternity what God intended from the beginning ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]). The tree of life was closed to man because of his fall ([link]Gen. 3:22-24[/link]), but it was opened to the believers through the redemption of Christ ([link]Heb. 10:19-20[/link]). Today the enjoyment of Christ as the tree of life is the believers' common portion ([link]John 6:35[/link], [link]57[/link]). In the millennial kingdom the enjoyment of Christ as the tree of life will be a dispensational reward to the overcoming believers ([link]2:7[/link]). Eventually, in the new heaven and new earth for eternity, the enjoyment of Christ as the tree of life will be the eternal portion of all God's redeemed ([link]vv. 14[/link], [link]19[/link]). Christ as the tree of life is the life supply available along the flow of the Spirit as the water of life. Where the Spirit flows, there the life supply of Christ is found. This is all in and with the divine nature as our holy way, signified by the street. This is the supply of the holy city, and this is the way the city is supplied.

The fruits of the tree of life will be the food of God's redeemed for eternity. They will be continually fresh, being produced every month, twelve fruits yearly. That the tree of life bears twelve fruits means that the fruit of the tree of life is rich and is sufficient for the carrying out of God's eternal administration.
Lit., according to each month.

[i]Month[/i] indicates that in the new heaven and new earth the moon still will be there to divide the twelve months. The sun also will be there to separate day and night into periods of twelve hours each. While the number that represents the church is seven, signifying that God in His present dispensation is added to His creature, man, the number that represents the New Jerusalem is twelve, signifying that God in His eternal administration is mingled with His creature, man. In the New Jerusalem are the twelve foundations, inscribed with the names of the twelve apostles; the twelve gates, which are twelve pearls, inscribed with the names of the twelve tribes; and the twelve fruits of the tree of life. With regard to space, the city proper is twelve thousand stadia, one thousand times twelve, in each of its three dimensions, and its wall is one hundred forty-four cubits, twelve times twelve, in height. With regard to time, in the new heaven and new earth there are twelve months yearly, twelve hours daily, and twelve hours nightly.

The leaves of the tree of life are for the healing of the nations. In the Bible, leaves are a symbol of man's deeds ([link]Gen. 3:7[/link]). The leaves of the tree of life symbolize the deeds of Christ. The regenerated believers eat the fruit of the tree of life, receiving Christ as their inward life and life supply, that they may enjoy the divine life for eternity, whereas the restored nations are healed by the leaves of the tree of life, taking the deeds of Christ as their outward guide and regulation, that they may live the human life forever.

verse.text: And there will no longer be [note]1[/note]a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]curse. And the [note]3[/note]throne of God and of the Lamb will be in it, and His [xref]b[/xref]slaves will [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]serve [note]5[/note]Him;
verse.note: Or, anything accursed.

The curse came in through Adam's fall ([link]Gen. 3:17[/link]) and was dealt with by Christ's redemption ([link]Gal. 3:13[/link]). Since in the new heaven and new earth the fall will be no more, there will no longer be a curse.

The throne of God and of the Lamb is one of the blessings that God's redeemed will enjoy in eternity. They will no longer suffer any curse; the throne of God and of the Lamb will be their eternal portion.
The Greek word denotes serving as priests. To serve God and the Lamb also will be a blessing to God's redeemed in eternity.
[i]Him,[/i] like [i]His[/i] in [link]v. 4[/link], refers to God and the Lamb; God and the Lamb are one in eternity.

verse.text: And they will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]see His [xref]b[/xref]face, and His [xref]c[/xref]name will be on their foreheads.
verse.note: To see the face of God and of the Lamb and to have His name on their foreheads also will be blessings of the Triune God enjoyed by God's redeemed in eternity.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]night will be no more; and they have [xref]b[/xref]no need of the [note]2[/note]light of a lamp and of the light of the sun, for the [note]3[/note]Lord God will shine upon them; and they will [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]reign forever and ever.
verse.note: See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].
The light of a lamp is made by man, and the light of the sun is created by God.
To be shined upon by the Lord God will be another blessing to God's redeemed in eternity.
To reign forever will be the final blessing to God's redeemed in eternity.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]he said to me, These words are [xref]a[/xref]faithful and true; and the [note]2[/note]Lord, the [xref]b[/xref]God of the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]spirits of the [xref]d[/xref]prophets, has sent His angel to [xref]e[/xref]show to His slaves the things which must quickly take place.
verse.note: [i]He[/i] refers to the angel in [link]21:9[/link].
"The Lord, the God," who sent His angel to show the things in this book is the Lord Jesus ([link]1:1[/link]; [link]22:16[/link]).

In this book the Lord God is the God of the spirits of the prophets. This indicates that all the prophecies in this book are inspired by the very God who inspired the spirits of the prophets in both the Old Testament and the New Testament. It also indicates that these prophecies are related to those in the Old Testament and the New Testament, all of which were spoken by the prophets in their spirit, which was under the inspiration of God. Hence, to comprehend these prophecies, we too need to be in our spirit under God's anointing.

verse.text: And behold, [note]1[/note]I [xref]a[/xref]come quickly. [xref]b[/xref]Blessed is he who keeps the words of the prophecy of this scroll.
verse.note: "I come quickly" is the Lord's warning. If we heed this warning, we will be blessed; otherwise, we will forfeit the blessing.

verse.text: And I [xref]a[/xref]John am he who hears and sees these things. And when I heard and saw, I [xref]b[/xref]fell to worship before the feet of the angel who showed me these things.

And he said to me, [xref]a[/xref]Do not do that! I am your fellow slave and [i]a fellow slave[/i] of your brothers the [xref]b[/xref]prophets and of those who [xref]c[/xref]keep the words of this scroll. [xref]d[/xref]Worship God.
And he said to me, Do [note]1[/note]not [xref]a[/xref]seal the words of the [xref]b[/xref]prophecy of this scroll, for the [xref]c[/xref]time is near.
verse.note: Daniel's prophecies were sealed because they were given long before the time of the end, whereas the prophecies of this book should not be sealed, for the time is near.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Let [xref]a[/xref]him who does unrighteousness do unrighteousness still; and let him who is filthy be filthy still; and let him who is righteous do righteousness still; and let him who is holy be holy still.
verse.note: In the age of this book, whatever one is, whether unrighteous or righteous, whether filthy or holy, is a serious matter. To be righteous is to walk outwardly according to the righteous ways of God, whereas to be holy is to live inwardly according to the holy nature of God. In the age of this book we must walk and live in this way that we may receive the reward; otherwise, we will be condemned as unrighteous and filthy and will receive punishment at the Lord's coming back ([link]v. 12[/link]).

verse.text: Behold, [note]1[/note]I [xref]a[/xref]come quickly, and My [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]reward is with Me to render to each one as his work is.
verse.note: The Lord repeats His warning, "I come quickly," so that we will consider His reward, to be rendered at His coming back.

Lit., wages. At the Lord's coming, this reward will be rendered to each one of the believers, after their rapture, at the judgment seat of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 4:5[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:10[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:27[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I am the [xref]a[/xref]Alpha and the Omega, the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]First and the Last, the [xref]c[/xref]Beginning and the End.
verse.note: This is the Lord's declaration at the close of this book; it corresponds with what God declared in the opening of this book ([link]1:8[/link]). This indicates that the Lord Jesus is the very God.

The Lord Jesus is not only the First but also the Beginning, and not only the Last but also the End. [i]The First[/i] indicates that none is before Him, and [i]the Last[/i] that none is after Him; whereas [i]the Beginning[/i] indicates that He is the origination of all things, and [i]the End[/i] that He is the consummation of all things. Hence, the indication here is not only that there is nothing before or after the Lord Jesus but also that there is no origination or consummation without Him.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Blessed are those who [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]wash their [xref]c[/xref]robes that [note]3[/note]they may have [note]4[/note][xref]d[/xref]right to the [xref]e[/xref]tree of life and may [xref]f[/xref]enter [note]5[/note]by the [xref]g[/xref]gates into the city.
verse.note: This verse can be considered a promise of the enjoyment of the tree of life, which is Christ with all the riches of life; and the second half of [link]v. 17[/link] can be considered a call to take the water of life, which is the life-giving Spirit. Thus this book ends in a promise and a call, both of which are for eating and drinking the all-inclusive Christ as the life-giving Spirit.

The robes here symbolize the conduct of the believers. To wash their robes is to keep their conduct clean through the washing of the blood of the Lamb ([link]7:14[/link]; [link]1 John 1:7[/link]). This gives them the right to participate in the tree of life and to enter into the city. Both the tree of life and the city will be an enjoyment to them in eternity.
Lit., their authority will be over the tree of life and they may enter...

After being created, man was put before the tree of life ([link]Gen. 2:8-9[/link]), indicating that he was privileged to partake of it. But because of the fall of man, the way to the tree of life was closed to man by God's glory, holiness, and righteousness ([link]Gen. 3:24[/link]). Through Christ's redemption, which fulfilled all the requirements of God's glory, holiness, and righteousness, the way to the tree of life was opened again to believers ([link]Heb. 10:19-20[/link]). Hence, those who wash their robes in the redeeming blood of Christ have the right to enjoy the tree of life as their eternal portion in the holy city, the Paradise of God, in eternity ([link]2:7[/link]).

To enter by the gates into the city is to enter the New Jerusalem, as a realm of God's eternal blessing, by regeneration through the death-overcoming and life-imparting Christ. (See note [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].)

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Outside are the [xref]b[/xref]dogs and the sorcerers and the fornicators and the murderers and the idolaters and everyone who loves and [xref]c[/xref]makes a lie.
verse.note: [i]Outside[/i] means outside the city, where the lake of fire, which holds all the sinners who have perished, will be located. (See note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 21[/link].)

verse.text: I Jesus have [xref]a[/xref]sent My angel to testify to you these things [note]1[/note]for the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]churches. I am the [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]Root and the [xref]d[/xref]Offspring of David, the bright [note]4[/note][xref]e[/xref]morning star.
verse.note: Lit., upon, or, over.
The testimony of this book was made by the Lord Jesus for the churches. Hence, to comprehend and keep this testimony, we need to be in the churches and for the churches.

In His divinity, Christ is the Root, the source, of David; in His humanity, Christ is the Offspring, the issue, of David. Hence, He is the Lord as the Root of David, and He is also the son, the shoot, of David as the Offspring of David ([link]Matt. 22:42-45[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:3[/link]; [link]Jer. 23:5[/link]).

At His coming back Christ will be the rising sun to His people generally ([link]Mal. 4:2[/link]) but the morning star to His watching lovers particularly. The latter will be a reward to the overcomers ([link]2:28[/link]). Christ's being the Root and Offspring of David is related to Israel and the kingdom, whereas Christ's being the bright morning star is related to the church and the rapture. The morning star appears before the darkest hour, prior to the dawn. The great tribulation will be this darkest time, after which the day of the kingdom will dawn. In the kingdom the Lord will appear publicly to His people as the sun, but before the great tribulation He will appear privately to His overcomers as the morning star.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit and the [xref]b[/xref]bride say, [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Come! And let him who hears say, [xref]c[/xref]Come! And let him who is [xref]d[/xref]thirsty [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]come; let [note]4[/note]him who wills take the [xref]f[/xref]water of life freely.
verse.note: In [link]chs. 2[/link] and [link book="Rev."]3[/link] it was the Spirit speaking to the churches; here, at the end of the book, it is the Spirit and the bride, the church, speaking together as one. This indicates that the church's experience of the Spirit has improved to the extent that she has become one with the Spirit, who is the ultimate consummation of the Triune God.[br][br]The entire revelation of the Bible shows us the love story of a universal couple. That is, the sovereign Lord, who created the universe and all things, the Triune God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit — who went through the processes of incarnation, human living, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension, and who ultimately became the life-giving Spirit, is joined in marriage to the created, redeemed, regenerated, transformed, and glorified tripartite man — composed of spirit, soul, and body — who ultimately constitutes the church, the expression of God. In the eternity that is without end, by the divine, eternal, and surpassingly glorious life, they will live a life that is the mingling of God and man as one spirit, a life that is superexcellent and that overflows with blessings and joy.

"Come!" is the response of the Spirit and the bride to the Lord's word in [link]v. 16[/link] and to His repeated warning in [link]vv. 7[/link] and [link]12[/link]. It expresses the desire for the Lord's coming. Whoever hears this response also should say, "Come!" thus expressing a joint desire for the Lord's coming. All believers who love the Lord's appearing ([link]2 Tim. 4:8[/link]) should express such a joint desire.

The Spirit and the bride, on one hand, desire that the Lord will come, and, on the other hand, yearn that the thirsty sinner also will come to take the water of life for his satisfaction. When we have a sincere desire for the Lord's coming, we also have an earnest concern for the sinner's salvation.
See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note]I testify to everyone who hears the words of the [xref]a[/xref]prophecy of this scroll: If anyone [xref]b[/xref]adds to them, God will add to him the [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]plagues which are written in this scroll;
verse.note: The "I" here should be the Lord Jesus, in accordance with [link]vv. 16[/link] and [link]20[/link]; it may, however, refer to John, in accordance with [link]1:2[/link]. In any case, John was one in spirit with the Lord in this solemn warning.

The main items of the plagues unveiled in this book are the three woes of the great tribulation, and the second death, that is, the perishing of the whole man — spirit, soul, and body — in the lake of fire. The outstanding features of the blessing revealed in this book are the tree of life and the holy city. Whether one will suffer the plagues or share in the blessing depends on how one deals with the prophecy of this book. We should not add to the prophecy, nor should we take away anything from it. We must receive it as it is written.

verse.text: And if anyone [xref]a[/xref]takes away from the words of the scroll of this prophecy, God will take away his part from the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]tree of life and out of the [xref]c[/xref]holy city, which are written in this scroll.
verse.note: See note [link]18[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: He who testifies these things says, Yes, [note]1[/note]I [xref]a[/xref]come quickly. [xref]b[/xref]Amen. [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]Come, Lord Jesus!
verse.note: This is the third time in this chapter that the Lord warns us that He is coming quickly.

This is the apostle John's prayer and his response to the Lord's warning. It is also the last prayer in the Bible. After hearing this book, we should all pray such a prayer and have such a response — "Come, Lord Jesus!" The entire Bible concludes with the desire for the Lord's coming expressed as a prayer.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grace of the Lord Jesus[note]2[/note] be with all [note]3[/note]the [xref]b[/xref]saints. [xref]c[/xref]Amen.
verse.note: After seeing all the visions and hearing all the prophecies in this book, we still need the Lord's grace. Only the grace of the Lord Jesus can enable us to live and walk according to these visions and prophecies. Not only this book but also the entire Bible closes with this grace, the grace that enables us to experience the all-inclusive Christ and participate in the Triune God that we may become His eternal corporate expression for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose, that He and we may enjoy absolute satisfaction and complete rest mutually for eternity.
Some ancient authorities add, Christ.

Some ancient authorities omit, the saints. Amen.[br][br]The New Jerusalem, the last major item revealed in this book, is not only the conclusion of the entire Bible but also the ultimate consummation of all the important items revealed in the Bible. The Triune God, the Triune God's economy, Christ's redemption, God's salvation, the believers, the church, and the kingdom are all consummated in the New Jerusalem as the consummating item. Thus, to say that the New Jerusalem is a physical city is not logical; it does not correspond with this book's principle of using signs for the revelation of the mysterious things. According to the entire revelation of the complete Bible, the New Jerusalem, the conclusion of the complete Bible, is a divine mingling of the processed Triune God with the redeemed and transformed tripartite man, a mingling of divinity with humanity, issuing in a universal, corporate, mysterious person. This person is:[br][br](1) The wife of the Lamb ([link]21:9[/link]);[br][br](2) The ultimate consummation of God's tabernacle and temple, as the eternal mutual habitation of both God and man ([link]21:3[/link], [link]22[/link]);[br][br](3) The ultimate consummation of God's work of the new creation in the old creation throughout the generations ([link]Acts 4:11[/link]; [link]John 2:19[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:18[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:9-12[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:4-5[/link]); and[br][br](4) The ultimate consummation of God's eternal economy and God's divine accomplishments.
